lines.value: katumbiri atawa kuwung kuwung nyaeta hiji fenomena optik jeung meteorologis nu nyababkeun nembonganana spektrum cahya di awang awang nalika srangenge nyinaran cihujan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: katumbiri bentukna mangrupa busur warna warni beureum pangluarna bungur pangjerona
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: runtuyan warnana nyaeta beureum oranyeu koneng hejo bulao jeung bungur
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!panembong katumbiri mangrupakeun balukar tina dispersi cahya srangenge nalika karefraksikeun ku keclak cihujan nu meh buleud
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cahyana mimitina direfraksikeun nalika asup kana beungeut cihujan reflects off the back of the drop and is again refracted as it leaves the drop
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the overall effect is that the incoming light is reflected back over a wide range of angles with the most intense light at an angle of about 40°-42° regardless of the size of the drop
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the water of the raindrops is dispersive the amount that the sunlight is bent depends upon the wavelength colour of the light's constituent parts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: blue light is refracted at a greater angle than red light but because the area of the back of the droplet has a focal point inside the droplet the spectra crosses itself and thus the red light appears higher in the sky and forms the outer colour of the rainbow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: contrary to popular belief the light at the back of the raindrop does not undergo total internal reflection however light that emerges from the back of the raindrop does not create a rainbow between the observer and the sun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is because the emitted spectra there do not have a maximum of intensity as the other visible rainbows do
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus the colours blend together and do not form any rainbow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a rainbow does not actually exist at a location in the sky but is an optical phenomenon whose apparent position depends on the observer's location
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all raindrops refract and reflect the sunlight in the same way but only the light from some raindrops reaches the observer's eye
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these raindrops are perceived to constitute the rainbow by that observer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its position is always in the opposite direction of the sun with respect to the observer and the interior is actually a magnified image of the sun which can be seen to be slightly brighter than the exterior
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the bow is centred on the shadow of the observer's head or more exactly at the antisolar point which is below the horizon during the daytime appearing at an angle of approximately 40°-42° to the line between the observer's head and its shadow this means that if the sun is higher than 42° the rainbow is below the horizon and cannot be seen unless the observer is at the top of a mountain or a similar vantage point
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly it is difficult to photograph the complete arc of a rainbow which would require an angle of view of 84°
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for a 35 mm camera a lens with a focal length of 19 mm or less would be required whilst most photographers are only likely to have a 28 mm wide angle lens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from an aeroplane one has the opportunity to see the whole circle of the rainbow with the plane's shadow in the centre
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes a second dimmer rainbow is seen outside the primary bow caused by a double reflection of the sunlight inside the raindrops and appears at an angle of 50°-53°
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because of the extra reflection the colours of the bow are inverted compared to the primary bow with blue on the outside and red on the inside
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a triple rainbow is even more rarely seen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a few observers have reported seeing quadruple rainbows in which a dim outermost arc had a rippling and pulsating appearance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: occasionally another beautiful and striking rainbow phenomenon could be observed consisting of several faint rainbows on the inner side of the primary rainbow and very rarely also outside the secondary rainbow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are slightly detached and have pastel colour bands that do not fit the usual pattern
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are known as supernumerary rainbows and their very existence was historically a first indication of the wave nature of light
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first accurate theoretical explanation of a rainbow came from theodoric of freiberg in 1307 he postulated that when sunlight falls on individual drops of moisture the rays undergo two refractions upon ingress and egress and one reflection at the back side of the drop before transmission into the eye of the observer quoted from david c lindberg roger bacon's theory of the rainbow progress or regress isis vol
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 57 no
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 2 p 236.).descartes in 1637 further advanced this explanation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: knowing that the size of raindrops didn't appear to affect the observed rainbow he experimented with passing rays of light through a large glass sphere filled with water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by measuring the angles that the rays emerged he concluded that the primary bow was caused by a single internal reflection inside the raindrop and that a secondary bow could be caused by two internal reflections
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was able to back this up with a derivation of the law of refraction subsequently but independently of snell and correctly calculated the angles for both bows
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however he was unable to explain the colours
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: isaac newton was the first to demonstrate that white light was composed of the light of all the colours of the rainbow which a glass prism could split into the full spectrum of colours
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he also showed that red light gets refracted less than blue light which led to an essentially complete explanation of a rainbow's optical effect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina teori probabilitas teorema de finetti nerangkeun kunaon observasi bisa digantikeun mangrupa kondisional bebas tina sababaraha umumna kuantitas teu ka observasi nu mana epistemic probability sebaran bakal ditangtukeun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ieu ngaran keur ngahargaan ka bruno de finetti
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: salah sahiji beda antara bayesian jeung metoda frequentist dina statistical inference nyaeta frequentists often treat observations as independent that bayesians treat as exchangeable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a bayesian statistician will often seek the conditional probability distribution of that unobservable quantity given the observable data
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the concept of exchangeability see below was introduced by de finetti
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: de finetti's theorem explains the mathematical relationship between independence and exchangeability
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an infinite sequence both have the same probability distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the condition of exchangeability is stronger than the assumption of identical distribution of the individual random variables in the sequence and weaker than the assumption that they are independent and identically distributed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a random variable x has a bernoulli distribution if p(x = 0 or x = 1 = 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: de finetti's theorem states that the probability distribution of any infinite exchangeable sequence of bernoulli random variables is a mixture of the probability distributions of independent and identically distributed sequences of bernoulli random variables
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mixture in this sense means a weighted average but this need not mean a finite or countably infinite i.e discrete weighted average it can be an integral rather than a sum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: here is a concrete example
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose p = 2/3 with probability 1/2 and p = 9/10 with probability 1/2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppose the conditional distribution of the sequence given the event that p = 2/3 is described by saying that they are independent and indentically distributed and x 1 = 1 with probability 2/3 and x 1 = 0 with probability 1 2/3
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further the conditional distribution of the same sequence given the event that p = 9/10 is described by saying that they are independent and identically distributed and x 1 = 1 with probability 9/10 and x 1 = 0 with probability 1 9/10
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the independence asserted here is conditional independence i.e the bernoulli random variables in the sequence are conditionally independent given the event that p = 2/3 and are conditionally independent given the event that p = 9/10
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but they are not unconditionally independent they are positively correlated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in view of the strong law of large numbers we can say that rather than concentrating probability 1/2 at each of two points between 0 and 1 the mixing distribution can be any probability distribution supported on the interval from 0 to 1 which one it is depends on the joint distribution of the infinite sequence of bernoulli random variables
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another way of stating the conclusion of de finetti's theorem is that the bernoulli random variables are conditionally independent given the tail sigma field
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the conclusion of the first version of the theorem above makes sense if the sequence of exchangeable bernoulli random variables is finite but the theorem is not generally true in that case
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is true if the sequence can be extended to an exchangeable sequence that is infinitely long
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the very simplest example of an exchangeable sequence of bernoulli random variables that cannot be so extended is the one in which x 1 = 1 x 2 and x 1 is either 0 or 1 each with probability 1/2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this sequence is exchangeable but cannot be extended to an exchangeable sequence of length 3 let alone an infinitely long one.-->
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: man'yoshu sajak antologi heubeul ditulis dina taun 759 nu ditulis make skrip heubeul
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: kana sacara tradisional geus dipake ku buddhist priest kukai dina abad ka 9
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: kukai mawa skrip siddham basa mulang ti china dina taun 806 manehna miresep kana ucapan jeung tulisan nu nyabakeun manehna nyieun kasimpulan yen basa jepang leuwih hade digambarkeun ku alfabet fonetik tinimbang kanji nu geus ilahar dipake

lines.value: ieu dipake dina susunan gojuon あ い う え お … わ を ん oge susunan iroha nu dipake keur nomer nomer dina sababaraha aturan

lines.value: beda dina kamus nyaeta dina susunan bagean keur ngabedakeun panjang pondokna sora tsu leutik jeung diacritik
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sakabeh basa jepang teu make kecap lolongkrang iwal ti keur barudak taya susunan kecap ka kecap nu aya kana ka kana

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ikon ti basa yunani eikon gambar nyaeta hiji gambar atawa wawakil mangrupa tanda atawa panyarupaan anu diayakeun pikeun hiji objek ku cara nandaan atawa ngawakilan atawa ku jalan nyaruaan saperti dina semiotics dina komputer hiji ikon ikon mangrupa lambang monitor nu digunakeun pikeun nandaan parentah leuwih jauh deui ikon oge digunakeun hususna dina budaya moderen dina harti umum lambang - saperti ngaran beungeut gambar atawa malah hiji jalma anu geus dipikawanoh miboga harti anu kasohor atawa miboga kualitas tinamtu
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in eastern orthodoxy and other icon painting christian traditions the icon is generally a flat panel painting depicting a holy being or object such as jesus mary saints angels or the cross
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: icons may also be cast in metal carved in stone embroidered on cloth done in mosaic work printed on paper or metal etc
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: throughout history religion has often made use of images whether in two dimensions or three
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some such as hinduism have a very rich iconography called murti while others such as islam severely limit the use of visual representations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the function and degree to which images are used or permitted and whether they are for purposes of ornament instruction inspiration or treated as sacred objects of veneration or worship thus depends upon the tenets of a given religion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: christianity originated as a movement within judaism during a time when there was great concern about idolatry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is no evidence of the making and use of painted icons or of similar religious images by christians within the new testament writings
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however eastern orthodox theologian rev dr steven bigham writes early christian attitudes toward images orthodox research institute 2004 the first thing to note is that there is a total silence about christian and non idolatrous images
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is important to note that the silence is in the new testament texts and this silence should not be interpreted as describing all the activities of the apostles or 1st century christians
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: st john himself said that jesus did many other signs in the presence of the disciples which are not written in this book jn 20.30
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: we could easily add that the apostles also did and said many things not recorded in the new testament
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is obvious therefore that we do not have a complete account of the activities and sayings of the apostles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: so if we want to find out if the first christians made or ordered any kind of figurative art the new testament is of no use whatsoever
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the silence is a fact but the reason given for the silence varies from exegete to exeget depending on his assumptions in other words relying only upon the new testament as evidence of no painted icons amounts to an argument from silence.though the word eikon is found in the new testament see below it is never in the context of painted icons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there were of course christian paintings and art in the early catacomb churches
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many can still be viewed today such as those in the catacomb churchs of domitilla and san callisto in rome.the earliest written records available of christian images treated like icons are in a pagan or gnostic context
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: alexander severus ad 222 235 kept a domestic chapel for the veneration of images of deified emperors of portraits of his ancestors and of christ apollonius orpheus and abraham lampridius life of alexander severus xxix
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: irenaeus in his against heresies 1:25;6 says of the gnostic carpocratians they also possess images some of them painted and others formed from different kinds of material while they maintain that a likeness of christ was made by pilate at that time when jesus lived among them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they crown these images and set them up along with the images of the philosophers of the world that is to say with the images of pythagoras and plato and aristotle and the rest
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they have also other modes of honouring these images after the same manner of the gentiles [pagans] a criticism of image veneration is found in the apocryphal acts of john generally considered a gnostic work in which the apostle john discovers that one of his followers has had a portrait made of him and is venerating it 27 ...he [john] went into the bedchamber and saw the portrait of an old man crowned with garlands and lamps and altars set before it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and he called him and said lycomedes what do you mean by this matter of the portrait
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: can it be one of thy gods that is painted here
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for i see that you are still living in heathen fashion later in the passage john says but this that you have now done is childish and imperfect you have drawn a dead likeness of the dead in addition to the legend that pilate had made an image of christ the 4th century bishop eusebius in his church history provides another reference to a first icon of jesus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he relates that king abgar of edessa sent a letter to jesus at jerusalem asking jesus to come and heal him of an illness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this version there is no image
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then in the later account found in the syriac doctrine of addai a painted image of jesus is mentioned in the story and even later in the account given by evagrius the painted image is transformed into an image that miraculously appeared on a towel when christ pressed the cloth to his wet face veronica and her cloth kuryluk ewa basil blackwell cambridge 1991
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further legends relate that the cloth remained in edessa until the 10th century when it was taken to constantinople
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1204 it was lost when constantinople was sacked by crusaders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: elsewhere in his church history eusebius reports seeing what he took to be portraits of jesus peter and paul and also mentions a bronze statue at banias paneas of which he wrote they say that this statue is an image of jesus he 7:18 further he relates that locals thought the image to be a memorial of the healing of the woman with an issue of blood by jesus luke 8:43-48 because it depicted a standing man wearing a double cloak and with arm outstretched and a woman kneeling before him with arms reaching out as if in supplication
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some scholars today think it possible to have been a misidentified pagan statue whose true identity had been forgotten some have thought it to be aesculapius the god of healing but the description of the standing figure and the woman kneeling in supplication is precisely that found on coins depicting the bearded emperor hadrian reaching out to a female figure symbolizing a province kneeling before him see john francis wilson's caesarea philippi banias the lost city of pan ib tauris london 2004
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when christianity was legalized by the emperor constantine within the roman empire in the early 4th century huge numbers of pagans became converts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this created the opportunity for the transfer of allegiance and practice from the old gods and heroes to the new religion and for the gradual adaptation of the old system of image making and veneration to a christian context
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the early fifth century we know of the ownership of private icons of saints by c 480-500 we can be sure that the inside of a saint's shrine would be adorned with images and votive portraits a practice which had probably begun earlier pagans and christians robin lane fox alfred a knopf new york 1989
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the legalization of christianity under constantine and its adoption as the roman state religion under theodosius i christian art began to change not only in quality and sophistication but also in nature
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was in no small part due to christians being free for the first time to express their faith openly without persecution from the state in addition to the faith spreading to the non poor segments of society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: paintings of martyrs and their feats began to appear and early writers commented on their lifelike effect one of the elements a few christian writers criticized in pagan art - the ability to imitate life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the writers mostly criticized that the pagan works of art pointed to false gods and thusly constituted idolatry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nilus of sinai in his letter to heliodorus silentiarius records a miracle in which st plato of ankyra appeared to a christian in a dream
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the saint was recognized because the young man had often seen his portrait
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this recognition of a religious figure from likeness to an image was also a characteristic of pagan pious accounts of appearances of gods to humans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however in the old testament we read of prophets having dreams of various heavenly figures including a vision of god who appeared to daniel as an elderly man the ancient of days
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also in this period that the first mention of an image of mary painted from life appears though earlier paintings on cave walls bear resemblance to modern icons of mary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: theodorus lector in the history of the church 1:1 excerpted by nicephorus callistus xanthopoulos stated that eudokia wife of theodosius ii died 460 sent an image of the mother of god from jerusalem to pulcheria daughter of the emperor arcadius this is by some considered a later interpolation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the image was specified to have been painted by the apostle luke in later tradition the number of icons of mary attributed to luke would greatly multiply
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early icons such as those preserved at the monastery of st catherine at sinai are realistic in appearance in contrast to the later stylization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are very similar to the mummy portraits done in encaustic wax and found at faiyum in egypt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as we may judge from such items the first depictions of jesus were generic rather than portrait images generally representing him as a beardless young man
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was some time before the earliest examples of the long haired bearded face that was later to become standardized as the image of jesus appeared
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and when they began to appear there was still variation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: augustine of hippo 354-430 said that no one knew the appearance of jesus or that of mary de trinitatis 8:4-5 though it should be noted that augustine wasn't a resident of the holy lands and therefore wasn't familiar with the local populations and their oral traditions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gradually paintings of jesus took on characteristics of portrait images
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at this time the manner of depicting jesus was not yet uniform and there was some controversy over which of the two most common forms was to be favored
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first or semitic form showed jesus with short and frizzy hair the second showed a bearded jesus with hair parted in the middle the manner in which the god zeus was depicted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: theodorus lector remarked church history 1:15 that of the two the one with short and frizzy hair was more authentic he also relates a story excerpted by john of damascus that a pagan commissioned to paint an image of jesus used the zeus form instead of the semitic form and that as punishment his hands withered
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though their development was gradual we can date the full blown appearance and general ecclesiastical as opposed to simply popular or local acceptance of christian images as venerated and miracle working objects to the 6th century when as hans belting writes we first hear of the church's use of religious images...(likeness and presence university of chicago press,1994
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ...as we reach the second half of the sixth century we find that images are attracting direct veneration and some of them are credited with the performance of miracles patricia karlin hayter the oxford history of byzantium oxford 2002
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cyril mango writes in the post justinianic period the icon assumes an ever increasing role in popular devotion and there is a proliferation of miracle stories connected with icons some of them rather shocking to our eyes the art of the byzantine empire 312-1453 university of toronto press 1986
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the earlier references by eusebius and irenaeus indicate veneration of images and reported miracles associated with them as early as the second century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it must also be noted that what might be shocking to our contemporary eyes may not have been viewed as such by the early christians
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in acts 5:15 of the new testament it is written that people brought the sick into the streets and laid them on beds and mats so that at least peter's shadow might fall on some of them as he passed by
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :main article iconoclasm there was a continuing opposition to misuse of images within christianity from very early times
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whenever images threatened to gain undue influence within the church theologians have sought to strip them of their power belting hans likeness and presence chicago and london 1994
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further,"there is no century between the fourth and the eighth in which there is not some evidence of opposition to images even within the church kitzinger ernst the cult of images in the age before iconoclasm dumbarton oaks 1954 repeated by pelikan jaroslav the spirit of eastern christendom 600-1700 university of chicago press 1974
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nonetheless popular favoritism for icons guaranteed their continued existence while as yet no systematic apologia for or against icons or doctrinal authorization or condemnation of icons existed.the use of icons was seriously challenged by byzantine imperial authority in the 8th century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though by this time opposition to images was strongly entrenched in judaism and in the rising religion of islam attribution of the impetus toward an iconoclastic movement in eastern orthodoxy to muslims or jews seems to have been highly exaggerated both by contemporaries and by modern scholars see pelikan the spirit of eastern christendom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though significant in the history of religious doctrine the byzantine controversy over images is not seen as of primary importance in byzantine history
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: few historians still hold it to have been the greatest issue of the period patricia karlin hayter oxford history of byzantium oxford university press 2002
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the iconoclastic period began when images were banned by emperor leo iii sometime between 726 and 730
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: under his son constantine v an ecumenical council forbidding image veneration was held at hieria near constantinople in 754
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: image veneration was later reinstated by the empress regent irene under whom another ecumenical council was held reversing the decisions of the previous iconoclast council and taking its title as seventh ecumenical council
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the council anathemized all who hold to iconoclasm i.e those who held that veneration of images constitutes idolatry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then the ban was enforced again by leo v in 815
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and finally icon veneration was decisively restored by empress regent theodora
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: icons are used particularly among eastern orthodox oriental orthodox coptic and eastern rite catholic churches
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as was described above the icon painting tradition developed in byzantium with constantinople as the chief city
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: we have only a few icons from the 11th century and no icons dating from the two centuries that preceded it firstly because of the iconoclastic reforms during which many were destroyed secondly because of plundering by venetians in 1204 during the crusades and finally the taking of the city by the islamic turks in 1453
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was only in the comnenian period 1081-1185 that the cult of the icon became widespread in the byzantine world partly on account of the dearth of richer materials such as mosaics ivory and enamels but also because a special screen for icons was introduced in eccelsiastical practice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the style of the time was severe hieratic and distant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the late comnenian period this severity softened and emotion formerly avoided entered icon painting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: major monuments for this change include the murals at daphni ca 1100 and nerezi near skopje 1164
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the theotokos of vladimir ca 1115 illustrated to the right is probably the most representative monument to the new trend towards spirituality and emotion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the tendency toward emotionalism in icons continued in the paleologan period which began in 1261
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: paleologan art reached its pinnacle in mosaics such as those of the kariye camii former chora monastery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the last half of the 1300s paleologan saints were painted in an exaggerated manner very slim and in contorted positions that is in a style known as the paleologan mannerism of which is a superb example
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the fall of constantinople to the turks in 1453 the byzantine tradition was carried on in regions previously influenced by its religion and culture--the balkans and russia georgia and in the greek speaking realm on crete
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: crete at that time was under venetian control and became a thriving center of art of the scuola di san luca the school of st luke an organized guild of painters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cretan painting was heavily patronized both by catholics of venetian territories and by eastern orthodox
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for ease of transport cretan iconographers specialized in panel paintings and developed the ability to work in many styles to fit the taste of various patrons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1669 the city of heraklion on crete which at one time boasted at least 120 painters finally fell to the turks and from that time greek icon painting went into a decline with a revival attempted in the 20th century by art reformers such as photios kontoglou who emphasized a return to earlier styles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :main article russian icons russian icons are typically paintings on wood often small though some in churches and monasteries may be as large as a table top
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many religious homes in russia have icons hanging on the wall in the krasny ugol the red or beautiful corner
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is a rich history and elaborate religious symbolism associated with icons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in russian churches the nave is typically separated from the sanctuary by an iconostasis russian ikonostas a wall of icons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the use and making of icons entered kievan rus which later expanded to become the russian empire following its conversion to orthodox christianity in 988 ad as a general rule these icons strictly followed models and formulas hallowed by usage some of which had originated in constantinople
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as time passed the russians notably andrei rublev and dionisius widened the vocabulary of types and styles far beyond anything found elsewhere
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the personal improvisatory and creative traditions of western european religious art are largely lacking in russia before the 17th century when simon ushakov's painting became strongly influenced by religious paintings and engravings from both protestant and catholic europe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the mid 17th century changes in liturgy and practice instituted by patriarch nikon resulted in a split in the russian orthodox church
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the traditionalists the persecuted old ritualists or old believers continued the traditional stylization of icons while the state church modified its practice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from that time icons began to be painted not only in the traditional stylized and nonrealistic mode but also in a mixture of russian stylization and western european realism and in a western european manner very much like that of catholic religious art of the time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :main article romanian icons in romania icons painted as reversed images on glass and set in frames were common in the 19th century and are still made
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the transylvanian countryside the expensive icons on panels imported from moldavia wallachia and mt athos were gradually replaced by small locally produced icons on glass which were much less expensive and thus accessible to the transylvanian peasants romanian icons on glass dancu juliana and dumitru dancu wayne state university press 1982
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the egyptian coptic church and the ethiopian church also have distinctive living icon painting traditions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the abundant use and veneration historically accorded images in the roman catholic church was a point of contention for protestant reformers who varied in their attitudes toward images
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the consequent religious struggles many statues were removed from churches and there was also destruction of images in some cases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though followers of zwingli and calvin were more severe in their rejection lutherans tended to be moderate with many of their parishes having displays of statues and crucifixes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a joint lutheran orthodox statement in helsinki reaffirmed the ecumenical council decisions on the nature of christ and the veneration of images the seventh ecumenical council the second council of nicaea in 787 which rejected iconoclasm and restored the veneration of icons in the churches was not part of the tradition received by the reformation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lutherans however rejected the iconoclasm of the 16th century and affirmed the distinction between adoration due to the triune god alone and all other forms of veneration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: through historical research this council has become better known
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nevertheless it does not have the same significance for lutherans as it does for the orthodox
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: yet lutherans and orthodox are in agreement that the second council of nicaea confirms the christological teaching of the earlier councils and in setting forth the role of images icons in the lives of the faithful reaffirms the reality of the incarnation of the eternal word of god when it states the more frequently christ mary the mother of god and the saints are seen the more are those who see them drawn to remember and long for those who serve as models and to pay these icons the tribute of salutation and respectful veneration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: certainly this is not the full adoration in accordance with our faith which is properly paid only to the divine nature but it resembles that given to the figure of the honored and life giving cross and also to the holy books of the gospels and to other sacred objects definition of the second council of nicaea
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: today attitudes can vary even from church to church within a given denomination whether catholic or protestant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: protestants generally use religious art for teaching and for inspiration but such images are not venerated as in orthodoxy and many protestant church sanctuaries contain no imagery at all
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the second vatican council declared in the 1960s that the use of statues and pictures in churches should be moderate most statuary was removed from many catholic churches
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eastern orthodoxy however continues to give such strong importance to the use and veneration of icons that they are often seen as the chief symbol of orthodoxy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: catholicism has a long tradition of valuing the arts and patronized a significant number of famous artists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: present day imagery within roman catholicism varies in style from traditional to modern and is often affected by trends in the art world in general
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: icons are often illuminated with a candle or jar of oil with a wick
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beeswax for candles and olive oil for oil lamps are preferred because they burn very cleanly although other materials are sometimes used the illumination of religious images with lamps or candles is an ancient practice pre dating christianity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: historically and even today among conservative eastern orthodox there are reports of miraculous icons that exude a fragrant healing oil
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when these reports are verified by orthodox clergy they are still explained as miracles performed by god through the prayers of the saint rather than being magical properties of the painted wood itself
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: icons are used particularly in eastern orthodox coptic orthodox oriental orthodox and eastern rite catholic churches
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the eastern orthodorx view of the origen of icuns is quite different from that of some secular scholars and from some in contemporary roman catholic circles the orthodox church maintains and teaches that the sacred image has existed from the beginning of christianity leonid ouspensky theology of the icon st vladimir's seminary press 1978
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: accounts that some non orthodox writers consider legends are within eastern orthodoxy accepted as history because they are a part of church tradition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus accounts such as that of the miraculous image not made by hands and the weeping and moving mother of god of the sign of novgorod are accepted as fact church tradition tells us for example of the existence of an icon of the savior during his lifetime the icon made without hands and of icons of the most holy theotokos [mary] immediately after hum these truths we hold st tikhon's seminary press 1986
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eastern orthodox further believe that a clear understanding of the importance of icons was part of the church from its very beginning and has never changed although explanations of their importance may have developed over time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is due to the fact that iconography is rooted in the theology of the incarnation christ being the eikon of god which didn't change though its subsequent clarification within the church occurred over the period of the first seven ecumenical councils
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also icons served as tools of edification for the faithful during most of the history of christendom when most couldn't read nor write.okai
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eastern orthodox find the first instance of an image or icon in the bible when god made man in his own image septuagint greek eikona recorded in genesis 1:26-27
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in exodus god commanded that the israelites not make any graven image but soon afterwards he commanded that they make graven images of cherubim and other like things both as statues and woven on tapestries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later solomon included still more such imagery when he built the first temple
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eastern orthodox believe these qualify as icons in that they were visible images depicting heavenly beings and in the case of the cherubim used to indirectly indicate god's presence above the ark.in numbers it is written that god told moses to make a bronze serpent and hold it up so that anyone looking at the snake would be healed of their snakebites
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in john 3 jesus refers to the same serpent saying that he must be lifted up in the same way that the serpent was
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: john of damascus also regarded the brazen serpent as an icon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further jesus christ himself is called the image of the invisible god in colossians 1:15 and is therefore in one sense an icon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as people are also made in god's images people are also considered to be living icons and are therefore censed along with painted icons during orthodox prayer services
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to john of damascus anyone who tries to destroy icons is the enemy of christ the holy mother of god and the saints and is the defender of the devil and his demons this is because the theology behind icons is closely tied to the incarnational theology of the humanity and divinity of jesus so that attacks on icons typically have the effect of undermining or attacking the incarnation of jesus himself as elucidated in the ecumenical councils
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the eastern orthodox teaching regarding veneration of icons is that the praise and veneration shown to the icon passes over to the archetype basil of caesarea,on the holy spirit 18:45 the honor paid to the image passes to the prototype
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus to kiss an icon of christ in the eastern orthodox view is to show love towards christ jesus himself not mere wood and paint making up the physical substance of the icon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: worship of the icon as somehow entirely separate from its prototype is expressly forbidden by the seventh ecumenical council standard teaching in the eastern orthodox and roman catholic churches alike conforms to this principle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the catholic church accepts the same councils and the canons therein which codified the teaching of icon veneration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the latin church of the west which after 1054 was to become separate as the roman catholic church accepted the decrees of the iconodule seventh ecumenical council regarding images
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is some minor difference however in the catholic attitude to images from that of the orthodox
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: following gregory the great catholics emphasize the role of images as the biblia pauperum the bible of the poor from which those who could not read could nonetheless learn
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this view of images as educational is shared by most protestants
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: catholics also however accept in principle the eastern orthodox veneration of images believing that whenever approached images of the cross saints etc are to be reverenced
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though using both flat wooden panel and stretched canvas paintings catholics traditionally have also favored images in the form of three dimensional statuary whereas in the east statuary is much less widely employed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the greek word eikon means an image or likeness of any kind
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: anything that represents something else is an eikon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nothing is implied about sanctity or its absence or veneration or its absence by the word itself
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the septuagint is the greek translation of the hebrew scriptures used by the early christians and eastern orthodox consider it the only authoritative text of those scriptures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in it the word eikon is used for everything from man being made in the divine image to the molten idol placed by manasses in the temple
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the word eikon is found in daniel 2:31323435 daniel 3:12,35,71112141518 hosea 13:2 be aware that septuagint numberings and names and the english bible numberings and names are not uniformly identical
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the new testament the term is used for everything from jesus as the image of the invisible god colossians 1:15 to the image of caesar on a roman coin () to the image of the beast in the apocalypse revelation 14:19
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: popular modern house construction techniques include light frame construction in areas with access to supplies of wood and adobe or sometimes rammed earth construction in arid regions with scarce wood resources

lines.value: humans often build houses for domestic or wild animals often resembling smaller versions of human domiciles

lines.value: familiar animal houses built by humans include bird houses and dog houses kennels while domiciles for agricultural animals are more often called barns

lines.value: as a verb to house pronounced howz is to provide a routine locale for an object a person or an organization

lines.value: historic or artistic artifacts for example are said to be housed in museums

lines.value: a business may be housed in a storefront or a family may be housed in an apartment or a house

lines.value: a collection of domiciles either for persons for organizations for animals or for objects is often called housing

lines.value: an individual person or a single object might also find housing in an appropriate domicile

lines.value: communities often establish standards either by formal process or by custom for adequate housing

lines.value: <!pondasina mah nyaeta lapis ganda fosfolipid sedengkeun membran sagemblengna sok digambarkeun salaku mosaik cair fluid mosaic - a two dimensional fluid of freely diffusing lipids dotted or embedded with proteins which may function as channels or transporters across the membrane or as receptors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the model was first proposed by sj singer 1971 as a lipid protein model and extended to include the fluid character in a publication with gl nicolson in science 1972
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of these proteins simply adhere to the membrane extrinsic or peripheral proteins whereas others might be said to reside within it or to span it intrinsic proteins - more at integral membrane protein
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: glycoproteins have carbohydrates attached to their extracellular domains
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cells may vary the variety and the relative amounts of different lipids to maintain the fluidity of their membranes despite changes in temperature
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cholesterol molecules in case of eukaryotes or hopanoids in case of prokaryotes in the bilayer assist in regulating fluidity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: phospholipid molecules in the cell membrane are fluid in the sense of free to diffuse and exhibit rapid lateral diffusion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lipid rafts and caveolae are examples of cholesterol enriched microdomains in the cell membrane
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many proteins are not free to diffuse
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cytoskeleton undergirds the cell membrane and provides anchoring points for integral membrane proteins
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: anchoring restricts them to a particular cell face or surface - for example the apical surface of epithelial cells that line the vertebrate gut - and limits how far they may diffuse within the bilayer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rather than presenting always a formless and fluid contour the plasma membrane surface of cells may show structure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: returning to the example of epithelial cells in the gut the apical surfaces of many such cells are dense with involutions all similar in size
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the finger like projections called microvilli increase cell surface area and facilitate the absorption of molecules from the outside
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: synapses are another example of highly structured membrane
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: new material is incorporated into the membrane or deleted from it by a variety of mechanicsms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: i fusion of intracellular vesicles with the membrane not only excretes the contents of the vesicle but also incorporates the vesicle membrane's components into the cell membrane
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the membrane may form blebs that pinch off to become vesicles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ii if a membrane is continuous with a tubular structure made of membrane material then material from the tube can be drawn into the membrane continuously
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: iii although the concentration of membrane components in the aqueous phase is low stable membrane components have low solubility in water exchange of molecules with this small reservoir is possible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in all cases the mechanical tension in the membrane has an effect on the rate of exchange
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some cells usually having a smooth shape the membrane tension and area are interrelated by elastic and dynamical mechanical properties and the time dependent interrelation is sometimes called homeostasis area regulation or tension regulation

lines.value: over 570000 homes were destroyed leaving an estimated 1.9 million homeless

lines.value: the damage is estimated to have exceeded one billion us dollars at contemporary values

lines.value: the panic and confusion created by the earthquake led to numerous false rumours spreading both inside and outside of the affected regions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various japanese newspaper articles carried confused stories such as the total annihilation of tokyo the entire kanto region sinking into the sea destruction of izu islands due to volcanic eruptions the japanese cabinet getting wiped out or monster tsunamis reaching as far inland as mount akagi at the northernmost corner of the kanto plain almost halfway across the width of the country the interior ministry declared martial law and ordered each section police chief to put the maintenance of order and security as a priority
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of the messages was that there are some koreans who are taking advantage of this disaster committing arson as part of robberies within tokyo
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of them possess bombs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tokyo is under martial law and each area of police force should be extremely vigilant about korean activities some newspapers reported this message
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this started the deadliest rumour of all that koreans are rioting committing looting and arson and most importantly poisoning wells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the numerous fires and cloudy well water a little known effect of a big quake all seemed to confirm the rumours in the eyes of the fear stricken survivors living in the rubble
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: vigilante groups set up roadblocks in cities towns and villages across the region
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because people with korean accents pronounced g or j in the beginning of words differently 15円 50銭 ju-go-en go ju sen and がぎぐげご gagigugego were used as shibboleths
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: anyone who failed to pronounce them properly was deemed korean
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some were told to leave but many were beaten or killed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: moreover anyone mistakenly identified as korean such as chinese okinawans and japanese speakers of some regional dialects suffered the same fate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in response to this the japanese army and the police conducted operations to protect koreans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more than 2000 koreans were taken in for protection from the mobs across the region although recent studies have shown that there have been incidences where army and police personnel are known to have condoned or even colluded in the vigilante killings in some areas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the chief of police of tsurumi responding to the rumour of koreans poisoning wells publicly drank the well water to disprove this rumour
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some towns even police stations into which koreans had escaped were attacked by mobs whereas in other neighbourhoods residents took steps to protect them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the army distributed flyers denying the rumour and warning civilians against attacking koreans but in many cases vigilante activity only ceased as a result of army operations against it.the total death toll from these disturbances is uncertain according to the investigation by the interior ministry confirmed victims of vigilante justice were 231 koreans killed and 43 injured 3 chinese killed 59 japanese including okinawans killed and 43 injured
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: actual estimates range from 6000 to 10000 although politically independent studies put the figure to just over 2500
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 362 japanese civilians were eventually charged for murder attempted murder manslaughter and assault though most got off with nominal sentences and even those who were sent to jail were later released in a general pardon commemorating the marriage of prince akihito
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contrast the actual number of koreans who were charged for crimes during this period were 2 for murder 3 for arson 6 for robbery and 3 for rape
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all of those charged with the killings were civilians despite the fact that some military and police units are now known to have taken part in the crimes leading to accusations of a cover up
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on top of this violence socialists like hirasawa keishichi anarchists like osugi sakae and ito noe and chinese communal leader ou kiten were abducted and killed by elements of the police because of the unfounded fear that they would use this opportunity to overthrow the japanese government
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the importance of accurate information following natural disasters has been emphasised in japan ever since
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: earthquake preparation literature in modern japan almost always direct citizens to carry a portable radio and use it to listen to reliable information and do not be misled by rumours in the event of a big quake
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the earthquake goto shinpei organized a reconstruction plan of tokyo with modern networks of roads trains and public services
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: parks were placed all over tokyo to work as refuge spots and public buildings were constructed with stricter standards than private buildings to accommodate refugees
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the outbreak of world war ii and the subsequent destruction severely limited resources
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1960 september 1 was designated as disaster prevention day to commemorate the earthquake and remind people of the importance of preparation as september and october are the middle of the typhoon season
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: schools public and private organizations host disaster drills
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tokyo is located near a fault line beneath the izu peninsula which on average causes a major earthquake about once every 70 years

lines.value: there are low key memorial facilities in a small park in sumida ward tokyo at the site of the open space in which 30000 people were killed by a single firestorm

lines.value: the park houses a buddhist style memorial hall museum a memorial bell donated by taiwanese buddhists a memorial to the victims of world war ii tokyo air raids and a memorial to the korean victims of the vigilante killings
