lines.value: great britain refers to the largest of the british isles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the word great simply means larger no connection with greatness in other senses is intended in contrast to brittany a historical term for a peninsula in modern france that largely corresponds with the present day french province of bretagne
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that region was settled by many british immigrants during the period of anglo saxon migration into britain and named little britain by them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the french term bretagne now refers to the french little britain not to the british great britain which in french is called grande bretagne
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the second largest island in the archipelago is ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that ireland is a part of the geographical british isles in no way implies that all of the island is politically british
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although the channel islands are associated with the united kingdom politically they are clearly an outcrop of the nearby french geology and historically they are the last remaining parts of the former duchy of normandy still under the crown of the united kingdom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: united kingdom is short for the united kingdom of great britain and northern ireland which makes it self explanatory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: great britain is also widely but incorrectly used as a synonym for the uk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: both great britain and the united kingdom are often shortened to britain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the united kingdom is a sovereign state
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its four constituent countries whilst having equal rights to elect members of parliament on nominally the same terms are sometimes considered to be of different status
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this view may be supported by the existence of devolved governments with different levels of power in scotland and wales see asymmetrical federalism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: due to historical precedent england scotland and wales are countries and nations in their own right although none of these is sovereign today
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: wales is also a principality of the united kingdom prince of wales is a title usually given to the heir apparent to the british throne
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: northern ireland is sometimes described by united kingdom citizens as a province of the united kingdom which derives from the irish province of ulster which northern ireland is part of
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this epithet is also applied because it originally was part of the uk as part of the country of ireland rather than as a constituent country or nation in its own right
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: northern ireland also had until 1972 a far greater degree of self government than the other constituent parts of the uk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contrast to the british unionist usage irish nationalists consider all of ulster to be the province of ulster and organise their sporting and cultural institutions accordingly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the four constituent parts of the uk are also known to some as home nations or the four nations sporting contests between them are known as home internationals for example in football see the british home championship
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the governing body for soccer in northern ireland is called the irish football association having been in existence since some 40 years before partition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its counterpart in the republic plus derry city is the football association of ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the northern national team retained the name ireland for some 50 years after partition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is only since around 1970 that the two teams have been consistently referred to as northern ireland and republic of ireland respectively
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however in rugby union the four home nations are england ireland the whole island i.e the republic of ireland plus northern ireland scotland and wales
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: culturally some consider the cornish to be distinct from the english but politically cornwall is considered by the uk government to have the same status as any other county in england
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however some have raised questions concerning the constitutional status of cornwall
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus great britain is both a geographical and a political entity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: geographically it is one island but politically it also contains the islands that belong to its constituent nations england wales and scotland most notably england's isle of wight wales anglesey and scotland's inner hebrides outer hebrides orkney islands and shetland islands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the abbreviation gb is sometimes officially used for the uk for example in the olympics where athletes from northern ireland may choose whether to represent the uk or the republic of ireland and as the vehicle registration plate country identification code however the internet code .gb although allocated to the uk is unused the uk uses .uk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: uk teams in the olympics have competed under several different names most recently in athens the athletes were presented at the opening ceremony under a banner which said simply great britain rather than the full great britain and northern ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since the good friday agreement and the subsequent implementation legislation sporting organisation and several other organisations e.g tourism and irish gaelic and ulster scots language boards on the island of ireland has increasingly been cross border
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: citizens of the uk are called british or britons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term brits may also be used sometimes pejoratively for example by supporters of scottish independence when referring to supporters of the union
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some rather dated slang names for britons are tommy for british soldiers pom anglo and limey
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: anglo properly refers only to england but it is sometimes incorrectly used as a broader reference as an element in compound adjectives for example anglo french relations may be used in newspaper articles when referring to relations between the political entities france and the united kingdom the correct term in this case is british french relations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: anglo saxon may be used when referring to the whole english speaking world the correctly named as it refers to the english language not a british language anglosphere although ethnically very few of the world's one billion english speakers are of anglo saxon origin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: interestingly while the rest of the world refers to the english derived from angles speakers of the celtic languages refer to them as saxons sassannach in scottish gaelic saesneg in welsh
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ireland is the name since 1937 of the independent state which covers the island of ireland apart from northern ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since 1949 the description republic of ireland has been widely used but the official name in the irish constitution is ireland or in the irish language eire
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is also the geographical term for the entire island
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the republic of ireland gained full recognised independence from the united kingdom in 1921
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: northern ireland is sovereign british territory and a majority of the population of northern ireland consider themselves british
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditionally ireland is divided into four provinces leinster connacht munster and ulster
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the republic of ireland takes up 83% of the island while northern ireland takes up six of the nine counties of ulster
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on the island of ireland as everywhere the naming of places often raises political issues
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the usage of ireland as the official name of the state in the constitution of the republic of ireland causes offence to some unionists in northern ireland as it implies that the republic of ireland still has a territorial claim to the whole island the terminology of republic of ireland or eire is much preferred by northern unionists when referring to that political state
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similarly some nationalists in northern ireland also prefer to reserve to usage of ireland to refer to the whole island
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the republic of ireland is often referred to by irish republicans by the term the twenty six counties with the connotation that the state constituted as such forms only a portion of the ideal political unit which would consist of all of the thirty two counties into which the island is divided
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from 1922 to 1937 the state comprising those 26 counties was officially known by the term the irish free state
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many people object to these latter two terms as they are seen to imply that the republic of ireland is not a fully independent country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: conversely some republicans and others refer to northern ireland as the six counties in reference to northern ireland's six counties a name that avoids the disputed link with great britain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some even call it the occupied six counties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some nationalists use the terms the north of ireland and the north instead of northern ireland these are terms also used by the irish national broadcaster rte
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many people especially some unionists sometimes refer to northern ireland as ulster this is inaccurate as the irish province of ulster traditionally includes an additional three counties which are in the republic of ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term ulster and the province are sometimes preferred by unionists sometimes because it can suggest an origin of the polity of northern ireland that pre dates 1922 referring back to the act of union 1800 the glorious revolution of 1689 the plantation of ulster in 1610 the ancient migrations between ulster and scotland and even to biblical tradition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: so it is understandable that certain local place names should still be in dispute see derry/londonderry name dispute
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since 1978 the term british islands as opposed to british isles has been used by the uk's governments and assemblies to define the united kingdom together with the isle of man and the channel islands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: under the interpretation act 1978 of the united kingdom the term british islands refers to the united kingdom of great britain and northern ireland together with the crown dependencies the bailiwicks of jersey and of guernsey which in turn includes the smaller islands of alderney herm and sark in the channel islands and the isle of man
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the earliest known names for the islands come from the massaliote periplus of the 6th century bc fragments of which survived in the writings of avienus around ad 400
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ireland was referred to as ierne insula sacra the sacred island as the greeks interpreted it inhabited by the race of hiberni gens hiernorum and britain as insula albionum island of the albions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: earlier sources preserve fragments of the travel writings of the ancient greek pytheas around 320 bc and describe the british isles including ireland as the ai bpettaviai the brittanic isles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the peoples of these islands of prettanike were called the ppettavoi priteni or pretani
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these names derived from a celtic language term which is likely to have reached pytheas from the gauls who may have used it as their term for the inhabitants of the islands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the romans called the inhabitants of gaul modern france galli or celtae
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the latter term came from the greek name keatoi for a central european people and 17th century antiquarians who found language connections developed the idea of a race of celts inhabiting the area but this term was not used by the greeks or romans for the inhabitants of britain or ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: priteni is the source of the welsh language term prydain britain and has the same source as the goidelic term cruithne
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the latter referred to the early brythonic speaking inhabitants of ireland the scottish highlands and the north of scotland who are known as the cruithne in scottish gaelic and who the romans called picts or caledonians
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: caesar's invasions of britain brought descriptions of the peoples of what he called britannia pars interior inland britain in 55 bc throughout book 4 of his geography strabo is consistent in spelling the island britain transliterated as prettanikee he uses the terms prettans or brettans loosely to refer to the islands as a group a common generalisation used by classical geographers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example in geography 2.1.18 ...oi votiwtatoi twv bpnttavwv bopniotnpoi toutov nioiv ...the most southern of the brettans are further north than this)
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was writing around ad 10 although the earliest surviving copy of his work dates from the 6th century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pliny the elder writing around ad 70 uses a latin version of the same terminology in section 4.102 of his naturalis historia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he writes of great britain albion ipsi nomen fuit cum britanniae vocarentur omnes de quibus mox paulo dicemus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: albion was its own name when all [the islands] were called the britannias i will speak of them in a moment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the following section 4.103 pliny enumerates the islands he considers to make up the britannias listing great britain ireland and many smaller islands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in his geography written in the mid 2nd century and probably describing the position around ad 100 ptolemy includes both britain and ireland - he calls it hibernia - in the island group he calls britannia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he entitles book ii chapter 1 of as hibernia island of britannia and chapter 2 as albion island of britannia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the name albion for great britain fell from favour and the island was described in greek as ppettavia or bpettavia in latin britannia an inhabitant as bpettavoz britannus with the adjective bpettavikoz brittanicus equating to british
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the roman conquest of britain the name britannia was used for the province of roman britain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the emperor claudius was honoured with the agnomen britannicus as if he were the conqueror and coins were struck from ad 46 inscribed de britan de britann de britanni or de britannis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the visit of hadrian in ad 121 coins introduced a female figure with the label britannia as a personification or goddess of the place
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these and later roman coins introduced the seated figure of britannia which would be reintroduced in the 17th century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the later years of roman rule britons who left latin inscriptions both at home and elsewhere in the empire often described themselves as brittanus or britto and where describing their citizenship gave it as cives of a british tribe or of a patria homeland of britannia not roma
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from the 4th century many britons migrated from roman britain across the english channel and founded brittany
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while latin remained the language of learning from the early medieval period records begin to appear in native languages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the earliest indigenous source to use a collective term for the archipelago is the life of saint columba a hagiography recording the missionary activities of the sixth century irish monk saint columba among the peoples of modern scotland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was written in the late seventh century by adomnan of iona an irish monk living on the inner hebridean island
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the collective term for the archipelago used within this work is oceani insulae meaning islands of the ocean book 2 46 in the sharpe edition = book 2 47 in reeves edition it is used sparingly and no priteni derived collective reference is made
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another early native source to use a collective term is the historia ecclesiastica gentis anglorum of bede written in the early eighth century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the collective term for the archipelago used within this work is insularum meaning islands book 1 8 and it too is used sparingly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he stated that britain studies and confesses one and the same knowledge of the highest truth in the tongues of five nations namely the angles the britons the scots the picts and the latins distinguishing between the brythonic languages of the ancient britons or old welsh speakers and other language groups
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early celtic saxon and viking kingdoms such as rheged strathclyde and wessex amalgamated leading to the formation of scotland england and wales
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in norman ireland local lords gained considerable autonomy from the lordship of ireland until it became the kingdom of ireland under direct english rule
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: continental mapmakers gerardus mercator 1512 balthasar moretus 1624 giovanni magini 1596 abraham ortelius 1570 and sebastian munster 1550 produced maps bearing the term british isles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ortelius makes clear his understanding that england scotland and ireland were politically nominally at least separate in 1570 by the full title of his map angliae scotiae et hiberniae sive britannicar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: insularum descriptio which translates as a description of england scotland and ireland or the british isles additionally many maps from this period show wales and cornwall as separate nations most notably those of mercator
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the diagram on the right gives an indication of the further evolution of kingdoms and states
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1603 the scottish king james vi inherited the english throne as james i of england
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he styled himself as james i of great britain although both states retained their sovereignty and independent parliaments the parliament of scotland and the parliament of england
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 1707 act of union united england and scotland in the kingdom of great britain under the parliament of great britain then in 1800 ireland was brought under british government control by the act of union creating the united kingdom of great britain and ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: irish unrest culminated in the irish war of independence and the 1922 separation of the irish free state which later became the republic of ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the mostly protestant northeast continued to be part of what was now the united kingdom of great britain and northern ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: british overseas territories such as bermuda gibraltar hong kong the falkland islands and the british antarctic territory have or have had various relationships with the uk
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the commonwealth of nations formerly the british commonwealth is a loose confederation of nations roughly corresponding to the former british empire mostly for economic co operation formalised in 1931
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has no connection with the commonwealth of england and the protectorate which were short lived republics replacing the previous kingdoms during the interregnum 1649 1660
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the adjectives used to describe the contents and attributes of the various constituent parts of the british isles also cause confusion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: british is generally used to refer to the united kingdom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however in a specifically physical geographical sense british is used to refer to the island of great britain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the cumbersome adjective great british is very rarely used to refer to great britain other than to contrive a pun on the word great as in great british food
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: irish in a political sense is used to refer to the republic of ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: northern ireland as a constituent part of the united kingdom would be included within the umbrella of the political term british though many unionists in northern ireland would also consider themselves irish in a geographical sense
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in order to be more specific northern irish is therefore in common usage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term ulster can also be used as an adjective e.g royal ulster constabulary but this is more likely to be used by unionists and has political connotations in the same fashion as its use as a proper noun because only six of the traditional nine counties of ulster namely antrim armagh down fermanagh londonderry and tyrone are included in northern ireland with the remaining three counties cavan donegal and monaghan forming part of the republic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: likewise nationalists might describe say a lake in northern ireland as irish
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however some nationalists might attribute what they see as less attractive aspects of northern ireland to britain or even to england e.g the northern ireland squad is an english football team
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the northern in northern ireland is not completely accurate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a large portion of northern ireland lies to the south of county donegal which is in the republic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the northern tip of the island malin head is on donegal's inishowen peninsula
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: scottish english and welsh are self explanatory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term english is however commonly used to mean british by many anglophones both within and without the archipelago
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is considerable sensitivity about some of the terms particularly in relation to ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term british isles itself can be considered irritating or offensive by those who find that the association of the term british with the united kingdom leads to a mistaken presumption that the republic of ireland is still in some way under british rule or think that it implies that the uk has continuing territorial claims to that country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: no branch of the irish government including the department of foreign affairs and the irish embassy in london uses the term though it is on occasion used in a geographical sense in irish parliamentary debates
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in northern ireland nationalists reject the term and use these islands as an alternative whereas unionists when countering nationalist insistence on the territorial integrity of the island of ireland change the geographical frame of reference to that of the whole archipelago of what they call the british isles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there have been several suggestions for replacements for the term british isles but no single one has won any wide acceptance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term ireland is also a matter of sensitivity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is the official name of the republic of ireland as well as being a geographical term for the whole island
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in northern ireland irishness is a highly contested identity with fundamentally different perceptions between unionists who perceive themselves as being both british and irish and nationalists who consider both communities to be part of the irish nation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the isle of man and the two bailiwicks of the channel islands are crown dependencies that is non sovereign nations self governing but whose sovereignty is held by the british crown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they control their own politics but not their defence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are not part of the united kingdom nor part of the european union
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the celtic languages in the region - cornish irish scottish gaelic welsh and manx- each have names for the various countries and subdivisions of the british isles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of the above are note in irish there are actually several terms for northern ireland an tuaisceart meaning the north is usually used but a more recent term for official use is tuaisceart eireann
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ulaidh the irish word for ulster is also sometimes used though the traditional region of ulster also includes 3 counties which are not included in the political region of northern ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ironically the most northern point in ireland is down south that is ruled from dublin not london
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the english word welsh is from a common germanic root meaning foreigner cognate with wallonia and wallachia and also cognate with the word used in mediaeval german to refer to the french and italians
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the english names albion and albany are related to alba and used poetically for either england or scotland or the whole island of great britain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: english erin is a poetic name for ireland derived from eire or rather from its dative form eirinn
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the island of rockall is a disputed territory in the atlantic ocean
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is a small uninhabited island lying some 301.4 km 187.3 miles west of st kilda outer hebrides and 424 km 229.1 miles north west of ireland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is claimed by the united kingdom as part of the isle of harris whilst its surrounding continental shelf but not the island itself is claimed by the republic of ireland iceland and denmark through the faroe islands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its remote position however means that it is open to question whether or not geographically it belongs to the british isles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in any event the united nations convention on the law of the sea states rocks which cannot sustain human habitation or economic life of their own shall have no exclusive economic zone or continental shelf
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: blighty is a slang word for britain derived from the hindustani word bilayati foreign
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: depending on the user it is meant either affectionately or archly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was often used by british soldiers abroad in the first world war to refer to home
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term europe may be used in one of several different contexts by british people either to refer to the whole of the european continent to refer to only to mainland europe sometimes called continental europe or simply the continent by some people in the archipelago - as in the apocryphal newspaper headlining fog shrouds channel continent cut off europe and the adjective european may also be used in reference to the european union particularly in a derogative context such as the new regulations handed out by europe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after calibration the amount of absorption can be related to the concentrations of various metal ions

lines.value: the method can be automated and is widely used to measure concentrations of ions such as sodium and calcium in blood

lines.value: ( atomic absorption spectroscopy ) spektroskopi emisi uses the range of electromagnetic spectra in which a substance radiates
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it requires the substance to be vaporised at high temperatures by placing it in a spark gap
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: x ray spectroscopy and x ray crystallography when x rays of sufficient frequency energy interact with a substance inner shell electrons in the atom are excited to outer empty orbitals or they may be removed completely ionizing the atom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the inner shell hole will then be filled by electrons from outer orbitals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the energy available in this de excitation process is emitted as radiation fluorescence or will remove other less bound electrons from the atom auger effect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the absorption or emission frequencies energies are characteristic of the specific atom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition for a specific atom small frequency energy variations occur which are characteristic of the chemical bonding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with a suitable apparatus these characteristic x ray frequencies or auger electron energies can be measured
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: x ray absorption and emission spectroscopy is e.g used in chemistry and material sciences to determine elemental composition and chemical bonding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: x ray crystallography is a process in which x rays are shone onto crystals at a certain angle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the wavelength of the x rays is known and so the distance apart of the crystal planes can be calculated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: combining all information enables crystal structure to be detected

lines.value: in order to obtain a fine line spectrum the atoms must be in a gas phase

lines.value: this means that the substance has to be vaporised

lines.value: spectrum is studied in absorption or emission

lines.value: pananggalan radiometrik radiometric dating nyaeta hiji tehnik nu dipake pikeun nangtukeun umur bahan dumasar kana pangaweruh laju uray isotop alami jeung kandunganana kiwari
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aya sababaraha metode nu akurasina beaya jeung skala waktuna beda-beda
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all ordinary matter is made up of combinations of chemical elements each with its own atomic number indicating the number of protons in the atomic nucleus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: additionally elements may exist in different isotopes with each isotope of an element differing only in the number of neutrons in the nucleus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a particular isotope of a particular element is called a nuclide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some nuclides are inherently unstable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that is at some random point in time an atom of such a nuclide will be transformed into a different nuclide by the process known as radioactive decay
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this transformation is accomplished by the emission of particles such as electrons known as beta decay or alpha particles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while the moment in time at which a particular nucleus decays is random a collection of atoms of a radioactive nuclide decays exponentially at a rate described by a parameter known as the half life usually given in units of years when discussing dating techniques
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after one half life has elapsed one half of the atoms of the substance in question will have decayed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many radioactive substances decay from one nuclide into a final stable decay product or daughter through a series of steps known as a decay chain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this case the half life is usually given is for the entire chain rather than just one step in the chain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nuclides useful for radiometric dating have half lives ranging from a few thousand to a few billion years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the half life of a nuclide depends solely on its nuclear properties it is not affected by temperature chemical environment magnetic and electric fields or any other external factors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the half life of any nuclide is also believed to be constant through time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although decay can be accelerated by radioactive bombardment such bombardment tends to leave evidence of its occurrence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: therefore in any material containing a radioactive nuclide the proportion of the original nuclide to its decay product(s changes in a predictable way as the original nuclide decays
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this predictability allows the relative abundances of related nuclides to be used as a clock that measures the time from the incorporation of the original nuclide(s into a material to the present
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the processes that form specific materials are often conveniently selective as to what elements they incorporate during their formation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the ideal case the material will incorporate a parent nuclide and reject the daughter nuclide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this case the only daughter nuclides to be found through examination of a sample must have created since the sample was formed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when a material incorporates both the parent and daughter nuclides at the time of formation it may be necessary to assume that the initial proportions of a radioactive substance and its daughter are known
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the daughter product should not be a small molecule gas that can leak out of the material and it must itself have a long enough half life that it will be present in significant amounts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition the initial element and the decay product should not be produced or depleted in significant amounts by other reactions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the procedures used to isolate and analyze the reaction products must be straightforward and reliable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if a material that selectively rejects the daughter nuclide is heated any daughter nuclides that have been accumulated over time will be lost through diffusion setting the isotopic clock to zero
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the temperature at which this happens is known as the blocking temperature and is specific to a particular material
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contrast to most radiometric dating techniques isochron dating using the rubidium strontium decay sequence does not require knowledge of the initial proportions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: radiometric dating can be performed on samples as small as a billionth of a gram using a mass spectrometer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the mass spectrometer was invented in the 1940s and began to be used in radiometric dating in the 1950s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the mass spectrometer operates by generating a beam of ionized atoms from the sample under test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the ions then travel through a magnetic field which diverts them into different sampling sensors known as faraday cups depending on their mass and level of ionization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on impact in the cups the ions set up a very weak current that can be measured to determine the rate of impacts and the relative concentrations of different atoms in the beams
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the uranium lead radiometric dating scheme is one of the oldest available as well as one of the most highly respected
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it has been refined to the point that the error in dates of rocks about three billion years old is no more than two million years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: uranium lead dating is best performed on the mineral zircon zrsio 4 ), though it can be used on other materials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: zircon incorporates uranium atoms into its crystalline structure as substitutes for zirconium but strongly rejects lead
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it has a very high blocking temperature and is very chemically inert
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of its great advantages is that any sample provides two clocks one based on uranium 235's decay to lead 207 with a half life of about 4.5 billion years and one based on uranium 238's decay to lead 206 with a half life of about 700 million years providing a built in crosscheck that allows accurate determination of the age of the sample even if some of the lead has been lost
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: two other radiometric techniques are used for long term dating
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: potassium argon dating involves the beta decay of potassium 40 to argon 40
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: potassium 40 has a half life of 1.3 billion years and so this method is applicable to the oldest rocks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: radioactive potassium 40 is common in micas feldspars and hornblendes though the blocking temperature is fairly low in these materials about 125c
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rubidium strontium dating is based on the beta decay of rubidium 87 to strontium 87 with a half life of 50 billion years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this scheme is used to date old igneous and metamorphic rocks and has also been used to date lunar samples
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: blocking temperatures are so high that they are not a concern
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rubidium strontium dating is not as precise as the uranium lead method with errors of 30 to 50 million years for a 3-billion-year-old sample
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--there are a number of other dating techniques that have short ranges and are so used for historical or archaelogical studies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one of the best known is the carbon 14 c14 radiometric technique
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: carbon 14 is a radioactive isotope of carbon 12 with a half life of 5730 years very short compared with the above
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in other radiometric dating methods the heavy parent isotopes were synthesized in the explosions of massive stars that scattered materials through the galaxy to be formed into planets and other stars
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the parent isotopes have been decaying since that time and so any parent isotope with a short half life should be extinct by now
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: carbon 14 is an exception
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is continuously created through collisions of neutrons generated by cosmic rays with nitrogen in the upper atmosphere
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the carbon 14 ends up as a trace component in atmospheric carbon dioxide co2
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an organism acquires carbon from carbon dioxide during its lifetime
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: plants acquire it through respiration and photosynthesis and animals acquire it from consumption of plants and other animals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when the organism dies the carbon 14 begins to decay and the proportion of carbon 14 left when the remains of the organism are examined provides an indication of the date of its death
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: carbon 14 radiometric dating has a range of about 50000 years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the rate of creation of carbon 14 appears to be roughly constant as cross checks of carbon 14 dating with other dating methods show it gives consistent results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however local eruptions of volcanoes or other events that give off large amounts of carbon dioxide can reduce local concentrations of carbon 14 and give inaccurate dates
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the releases of carbon dioxide into the biosphere as a consequence of industrialization have also depressed the proportion of carbon 14 by a few percent conversely the amount of carbon 14 was increased by above ground nuclear bomb tests that were conducted into the early 1960s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another relatively short range dating technique is based on the decay of uranium 238 into thorium 230 a process with a half life of 80000 years it is accompanied by a sister process in which uranium 235 decays into protactinium 231 which has a half life of 34300 years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while uranium is water soluble thorium and protactinium are not and so they are selectively precipitated into ocean floor sediments from which their ratios are measured
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the scheme has a range of several hundred thousand years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: archaeologists use tree ring dating dendrochronology to determine the age of old pieces of wood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: trees grow rings on a yearly basis with the spacing of rings being wider in good growth years than in bad growth years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these spacings can be used to help pin down the age of old wood samples and also give some hints to climate change
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the technique is only useful to about 4000 years in the past however because it requires overlapping tree ring series
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although determining geologic time by measuring the rate of deposition of sediments is not reliable over the large scale it is still useful for certain scenarios such as the deposition of layers of sediment on the bottom of a stable lake
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the approach is now known as varve analysis the term varve means a layer or layers of sediment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another technique used by archaelogists is to inspect the depth of penetration of water vapor into chipped obsidian volcanic glass artifacts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the water vapor creates a hydration rind in the obsidian and so this approach is known as hydration dating or obsidian dating and is useful for determining dates as far back as 200000 years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: natural sources of radiation in the environment knock loose electrons in say a piece of pottery and these electron accumulate in defects in the material's crystal lattice structure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when the sample is heated at a certain temperature it will glow from the emission of electrons released from the defects and this glow can be used to estimate the age of the sample to a threshold of a few hundred thousand years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: finally fission track dating involves inspection of a polished slice of a material to determine the density of track markings left in it by radioactive decay of uranium 238 impurities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the uranium content has to be understood but that can be determined by placing a plastic film over the polished slice of the material and then bombarding it with slow neutrons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this causes induced fission of u 235 as opposed to spontaneous fission of u 238
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the fission tracks produced by this process are recorded by a thin plastic film placed against the surface of the sample
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the uranium content of the material can then be calculated so long as the neutron dose is known
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this scheme has a maximum range of about a million years and works best with micas tektites glass fragments from volcanic eruptions and meteorites
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the dates may be inaccurate if the sample was heated to high temperatures in the past as blocking temperatures are generally low or if the sample was exposed on the surface of the earth where it was bombarded with cosmic rays
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!the idea of abiogenic petroleum origin was championed in the western world by thomas gold based on thoughts from russia mainly on studies of nikolai kudryavtsev
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the idea proposes that large amounts of carbon exist naturally in the planet some in the form of hydrocarbons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hydrocarbons are less dense than aqueous pore fluids and migrate upward through deep fracture networks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thermophilic rock dwelling microbial life forms are in part responsible for the biomarkers found in petroleum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however their role in the formation alteration or contamination of the various hydrocarbon deposits is not yet understood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thermodynamic calculations and experimental studies confirm that n alkanes common petroleum components do not spontaneously evolve from methane at pressures typically found in sedimentary basins and so the theory of an abiogenic origin of hydrocarbons suggests deep generation below 200 km see results ).
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as with any petroleum the idea goes these hydrocarbons would migrate upwards with methane sometimes bearing helium and nitrogen and heavy metals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: diamondoids are common in oil and gas and its nature probably is related to natural diamonds that come from earth's mantle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the proponents of abiogenic petroleum claim that reserves are never exhausted because they are filled from below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further evidence such as the existence of hydrocarbons on planetary bodies e.g methane on titan ) where life has not been found support this theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: experiments in 2004 by henry scott of the university of indiana of south bend and associates showed that methane could be created from carbon and water at high temperatures and pressures but scott states that this not the source of commercial petroleum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also the implications of this theory are what have been used to find most of the recent reserves world wide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: traditional biotic theory only predicts oil in certain rock at a certain depth but the abiotic theory allows for much more
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: reserves in much of canada iran kazakhstan the coast of vietnam and virtually all the oil in russia were found either at depths or in source rock that are incompatible with traditional techniques
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1985 in switzerland thomas gold led an experimental drill for oil straight into pure granite where 12 tonnes about 100 barrels were extracted over five years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--generally the first stage in the extraction of crude oil is to drill a well into the underground reservoir
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: historically in the usa some oil fields existed where the oil rose naturally to the surface but most of these fields have long since been depleted except for certain remote locations in alaska
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: often many wells called multilateral wells will be drilled into the same reservoir to ensure that the extraction rate will be economically viable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also some wells secondary wells may be used to pump water steam acids or various gas mixtures into the reservoir to raise or maintain the reservoir pressure and so maintain an economic extraction rate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the underground pressure in the oil reservoir is sufficient then the oil will be forced to the surface under this pressure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gaseous fuels or natural gas are usually present which also supplies needed underground pressure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this situation it is sufficient to place a complex arrangement of valves the christmas tree on the well head to connect the well to a pipeline network for storage and processing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is called primary oil recovery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: usually only about 20% of the oil in a reservoir can be extracted this way
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: over the lifetime of the well the pressure will fall and at some point there will be insufficient underground pressure to force the oil to the surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if economical and it often is the remaining oil in the well is extracted using secondary oil recovery methods see energy balance and net energy gain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: secondary oil recovery uses various techniques to aid in recovering oil from depleted or low pressure reservoirs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sometimes pumps such as beam pumps and electrical submersible pumps esps are used to bring the oil to the surface
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other secondary recovery techniques increase the reservoir's pressure by water injection natural gas reinjection and gas lift which injects air carbon dioxide or some other gas into the reservoir
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: together primary and secondary recovery allow 25% to 35% of the reservoir's oil to be recovered
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tertiary oil recovery reduces the oil's viscosity to increase oil production
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tertiary recovery is started when secondary oil recovery techniques are no longer enough to sustain production but only when the oil can still be extracted profitably
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this depends on the cost of the extraction method and the current
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when prices are high previously unprofitable wells are brought back into production and when they are low production is curtailed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thermally enhanced oil recovery methods teor are tertiary recovery techniques that heat the oil and make it easier to extract
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: steam injection is the most common form of teor and is often done with a cogeneration plant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this type of cogeneration plant a gas turbine is used to generate electricity and the waste heat is used to produce steam which is then injected into the reservoir
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this form of recovery is used extensively to increase oil production in the san joaquin valley which has very heavy oil yet accounts for 10% of the united states oil production
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in situ burning is another form of teor but instead of steam some of the oil is burned to heat the surrounding oil
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: occasionally detergents are also used to decrease oil viscosity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tertiary recovery allows another 5% to 15% of the reservoir's oil to be recovered
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as oil prices continue to escalate other alternatives to producing oil have been gaining importance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most viable of these is the coal to oil process known as the fischer tropsch process that aims to convert coal into crude oil
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was a concept pioneered in nazi germany when imports of petroleum were restricted due to war and germany found a method to extract oil from coal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was known as ersatz substitute in german and accounted for nearly half the total oil used in wwii by germany
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the process was used only as a last resort as naturally occurring oil was much cheaper
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as crude oil prices increase the cost of coal to oil conversion becomes comparatively cheaper
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the method involves converting high ash coal into synthetic oil in a multistage process
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ideally a ton of coal produces nearly 200 liters 1.25 bbl of crude with by products ranging from tar to rare chemicals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: currently two companies have commercialised their fischer tropsch technology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shell in bintulu malaysia uses natural gas as a feedstock and produces primarily low sulfur diesel fuels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sasol in south africa uses coal as a feedstock and produces a variety of synthetic petroleum products
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the process is today used in south africa to produce most of the country's diesel fuel from coal by the company sasol
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the process was used in south africa to meet its energy needs during its isolation under apartheid
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this process has received renewed attention in the quest to produce low sulfur diesel fuel in order to minimize the environmental impact from the use of diesel engines
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more recently explored is thermal depolymerization tdp
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in theory tdp can convert any organic waste into petroleum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--the first oil wells were drilled in china in the 4th century or earlier
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they had depth of up to 800 feet and were drilled using bits attached to bamboo poles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the oil was burned to evaporate brine and produce salt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the 10th century extensive bamboo pipelines connected oil wells with salt springs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ancient persian tablets indicate the medicinal and lighting uses of petroleum in the upper echelons of their society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 8th century the streets of the newly constructed baghdad were paved with tar derived from easily accessible petroleum from natural fields in the region
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 9th century oil fields were exploited in baku azerbaijan to produce naphtha
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these fields were described by the geographer masudi in the 10th century and by marco polo in the 13th century who described the output of those wells as hundreds of shiploads
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also timeline of islamic science and technology the modern history of oil began in 1853 with the discovery of the process of oil distillation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: crude oil was distilled into kerosene by ignacy lukasiewicz a polish scientist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first rock oil petr-oleum mine was created in bobrka near krosno in southern poland in the following year and the first refinery actually a distillery was built in ulaszowice also by lukasiewicz
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these discoveries rapidly spread around the world and meerzoeff built the first russian refinery in the mature oil fields at baku in 1861
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at that time baku produced about 90% of the world's oil
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the battle of stalingrad was fought over baku now the capital of the azerbaijan republic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first commercial oil well drilled in north america was in oil springs ontario canada in 1858 dug by james miller williams
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the american petroleum industry began with edwin drake's discovery of oil in 1859 near titusville pennsylvania
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the industry grew slowly in the 1800s driven by the demand for kerosene and oil lamps
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it became a major national concern in the early part of the 20th century the introduction of the internal combustion engine provided a demand that has largely sustained the industry to this day
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early local finds like those in pennsylvania and ontario were quickly exhausted leading to oil booms in texas oklahoma and california
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by 1910 significant oil fields had been discovered in canada specifically in the province of alberta the dutch east indies 1885 in sumatra persia 1908 in masjed soleiman peru venezuela and mexico and were being developed at an industrial level
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even until the mid-(1950s coal was still the world's foremost fuel but oil quickly took over
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: following the 1973 energy crisis and the 1979 energy crisis there was significant media coverage of oil supply levels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this brought to light the concern that oil is a limited resource that will eventually run out at least as an economically viable energy source
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the time the most common and popular predictions were always quite dire and when they did not come true many dismissed all such discussion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the future of petroleum as a fuel remains somewhat controversial
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: usa today news 2004 reports that there are 40 years of petroleum left in the ground
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some would argue that because the total amount of petroleum is finite the dire predictions of the 1970s have merely been postponed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: others argue that technology will continue to allow for the production of cheap hydrocarbons and that the earth has vast sources of unconventional petroleum reserves in the form of tar sands bitumen fields and oil shale that will allow for petroleum use to continue for an extremely long period in the future with both the canadian tar sands and united states shale oil deposits representing potential reserves matching existing liquid petroleum deposits worldwide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: today about 90% of vehicular fuel needs are met by oil
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: petroleum also makes up 40% of total energy consumption in the united states but is responsible for only 2% of electricity generation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: petroleum's worth as a portable dense energy source powering the vast majority of vehicles and as the base of many industrial chemicals makes it one of the world's most important commodities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: access to it was a major factor in several military conflicts including world war ii and the persian gulf war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: about 80% of the world's readily accessible reserves are located in the middle east with 62.5% coming from the arab 5 saudi arabia 12.5% uae iraq qatar and kuwait
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the usa has less than 3%
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--the presence of oil has significant social and environmental impacts from accidents and routine activities such as seismic exploration drilling and generation of polluting wastes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: oil extraction is costly and sometimes environmentally damaging although dr john hunt from woods hole pointed out in a 1981 paper that over 70% of the reserves in the world are associated with visible macroseepages and many oil fields are found due to natural leaks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: offshore exploration and extraction of oil disturbs the surrounding marine environment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: extraction may involve dredging which stirs up the seabed killing the sea plants that marine creatures need to survive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: crude oil and refined fuel spills from tanker ship accidents have damaged fragile ecosystems in alaska the galapagos islands spain and many other places
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: burning oil releases carbon dioxide into the atmosphere which contributes to global warming
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: per energy unit oil produces less co2 than coal but more than natural gas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however oil's unique role as a transportation fuel makes reducing its co 2 emissions a particularly thorny problem amelioration strategies such as carbon sequestering are generally geared for large power plants not individual tailpipes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: renewable energy source alternatives do exist although the degree to which they can replace petroleum and the possible environmental damage they may cause are uncertain and controversial
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sun wind geothermal and other renewable electricity sources cannot directly replace high energy density liquid petroleum for transportation use instead automobiles and other equipment must be altered to allow using electricity in batteries or hydrogen via fuel cells or internal combustion which can be produced from renewable sources
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other options include using biomass origin liquid fuels ethanol biodiesel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: any combination of solutions to replace petroleum as a liquid transportation fuel will be a very large undertaking
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the hubbert peak theory also known as peak oil is a theory concerning the long term rate of production of conventional oil and other fossil fuels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it assumes that oil reserves are not replenishable i.e that abiogenic replenishment is negligible and predicts that future world oil production must inevitably reach a peak and then decline as these reserves are exhausted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: controversy surrounds the theory as predictions for when the global peak will actually take place are highly dependent on the past production and discovery data used in the calculation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: proponents of peak oil theory also refer as an example of their theory that when any given oil well produces oil in similar volumes to the amount of water used to obtain the oil it tends to produce less oil afterwards leading to the relatively quick exhaustion and or commercial unviablility of the well in question
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the issue can be considered from the point of view of individual regions or of the world as a whole
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: originally m king hubbert noticed that the discoveries in the united states had peaked in the early 1930s and concluded that production would then peak in the early 1970s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his prediction turned out to be correct and after the us peaked in 1971 and thus lost its excess production capacity opec was finally able to manipulate oil prices which led to the oil crisis in 1973
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since then most other countries have also peaked britain's north sea for example in late 1990s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: china has confirmed that two of its largest producing regions are in decline and mexico's national oil company pemex has announced that cantarell field one of the world's largest offshore fields is expected to peak in 2006 and then decline 14% per annum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for various reasons perhaps most importantly the lack of transparency in accounting of global oil reserves it is difficult to predict the oil peak in any given region
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: based on available production data proponents have previously and incorrectly predicted the peak for the world to be in years 1989 1995 or 1995-2000
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however these predictions date from before the recession of the early 1980s and the consequent reduction in global consumption the effect of which was to delay the date of any peak by several years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a new prediction by goldman sachs picks 2007 for oil and some time later for natural gas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: just as the 1971 us peak in oil production was only clearly recognized after the fact a peak in world production will be difficult to discern until production clearly drops off
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one signal is that 2005 saw a dramatic fall in announced new oil projects coming to production from 2008 onwards
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since it takes on average four to six years for a new project to start producing oil in order to avoid the peak these new projects would have to not only make up for the depletion of current fields but increase total production annually to meet increasing demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 2005 also saw substantial increases in oil prices due to temporary circumstances which then failed to be controlled by increasing production
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the inability to increase production in the short term indicating a general lack of spare capacity and the corresponding uncontrolled price fluctuations can be interpreted as a sign that peak oil has occurred or is presently in the process of occurring
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--references to the oil price are usually either references to the spot price of either wti/light crude as traded on new york mercantile exchange nymex for delivery in cushing oklahoma or the price of brent as traded on the international petroleum exchange ipe for delivery at sullom voe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the price of a barrel of oil is highly dependent on both its grade which is determined by factors such as its specific gravity or api and its sulphur content and location
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the vast majority of oil will not be traded on an exchange but on a over the counter basis typically with reference to a marker crude oil grade that is typically quoted via pricing agencies such as argus media ltd and platts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example in europe a particular grade of oil say fulmar might be sold at a price of brent plus us$0.25/barrel".or as an intra company transaction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ipe claim that 65% of traded oil is priced off their brent benchmarks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other important benchmarks include dubai tapis and the opec basket
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the energy information administration eia uses the imported refiner acquisition cost the weighted average cost of all oil imported into the us as their world oil price
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is often claimed that opec sets the oil price and the true cost of a barrel of oil is around $2 which is equivalent to the cost of extraction of a barrel in the middle east
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these estimates of costs ignore the cost of finding and developing oil reserves
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: furthermore the important cost as far as price is concerned is not the price of the cheapest barrel but the cost of producing the marginal barrel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by limiting production opec has caused more expensive areas of production such as the north sea to be developed before the middle east has been exhausted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: opec's power is also often overstated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: investing in spare capacity is expensive and the low oil price environment in the late 90s led to cutbacks in investment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this has meant during the oil price rally seen between 2003-2005 opec's spare capacity has not been sufficient to stabilise prices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: oil demand is highly dependent on global macroeconomic conditions so this is also an important determinant of price
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some economists claim that high oil prices have a large negative impact on the global growth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this means that the relationship between the oil price and global growth is not particularly stable although a high oil price is often thought of as being a late cycle phenomenon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a recent low point was reached in january 1999 after increased oil production from iraq coincided with the asian financial crisis which reduced demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the prices then rapidly increased more than doubling by september 2000 then fell until the end of 2001 before steadily increasing reaching us $40 to us $50 per barrel by september 2004
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in october 2004 light crude futures contracts on the nymex for november delivery exceeded us $53 per barrel and for december delivery exceeded us $55 per barrel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: crude oil prices surged to a record high above $60 a barrel in june 2005 sustaining a rally built on strong demand for gasoline and diesel and on concerns about refiners ability to keep up
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this trend continued into early august 2005 as nymex crude oil futures contracts surged past the $65 mark as consumers kept up the demand for gasoline despite its high price
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see oil price increases of 2004 and 2005 the new york mercantile exchange nymex trades crude oil including futures contracts and provides the basis of us crude oil pricing via wti west texas intermediate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other exchanges also trade crude oil futures eg the international petroleum exchange ipe in london trades contracts in brent crude
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even individuals can now trade crude oil through online trading sites margin account or their banks through structured products indexed on the commodities markets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also history and analysis of crude oil prices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese
