lines.value: the following are noteworthy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pangakuan diplomatik nyaeta kawijakan politik hiji nagara keur ngaku kana ayana nagara atawa pamarentahan nagara sejen dumasar kana hukum jeung nembongkeun hasil kaputusan ti pamarentahan eta nagara tur pangakuan sacara hukum internasional
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pangakuan ieu bisa sacara de facto atawa de jure tur biasana diembarkeun ku pamarentah
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recognition of a government implies recognition of the state it governs but not vice versa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recognition of states de facto rather than de jure is rare and questions center around recognition of governments
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: de jure recognition is of course stronger while de facto recognition is more tentative and more connected with effective control of the recognized state over its territory as when the united kingdom recognized the soviet union de facto in 1921 but de jure only in 1924
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another example is the state of israel in 1948 whose government was immediately recognized de facto by the united states and later britain and one upped 3 days later by soviet de jure recognition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: renewing recognition of a government is not necessary when it changes in a normal constitutional way but is in the case of a coup d'etat or revolution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recognition of the new government by other states can be important for its long term survival
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for instance the taliban government of afghanistan which lasted only from 1996 to 2001 was recognized by only three countries while far more had recognized the government of ousted president burhanuddin rabbani
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recognition can be implied by other acts like the visit of the head of state or the signing of a bilateral treaty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if implicit recognition is possible a state may feel the need to explicitly proclaim that its acts do not constitute diplomatic recognition as when the united states commenced its dialogue with the palestinian liberation organization in 1988
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the doctrine of non recognition of illegal or immoral factual situations e.g territorial gains achieved by the use of force is called the stimson doctrine and has become more important since the second world war especially in the united nations as a method of ensuring compliance with international law for instance in the case of rhodesia in 1965
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: withdrawal of recognition is an even more severe act of disapproval of another state than the breaking of diplomatic relations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another example is the united states non recognition of the wwii annexation of the baltic states by the soviet union
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it continued to recognize the independence of these three states until surprisingly with the collapse of communism in the soviet union these states once more came into being in fact rather than just on paper
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other things which can be recognized include belligerent rights of a party in a conflict the occupation or annexation of territory or maritime flags
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sir ronald aylmer fisher frs 17 february 1890 - 29 july 1962 ahli statistik evolusi biologi jeung genetika inggris
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: richard dawkins nyebutna the greatest of darwin's successors jeung ahli sejarah statistik anders hald nyebutkeun fisher was a genius who almost single handedly created the foundations for modern statistical science
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher was born in east finchley in london to george and katie fisher
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his father was a successful businessman who dealt in fine arts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his boyhood was a happy one being doted on by his three older sisters an older brother and his mother who died when fisher was 14
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his father lost his business in several ill considered transactions only 18 months later
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although fisher had very poor eyesight he was a precocious student winning the neeld medal a competitive essay in mathematics at harrow school at the age of 16
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because of his poor eyesight he was tutored in mathematics without the aid of paper and pen which developed his ability to visualize problems in geometrical terms as opposed to using algebraic manipulations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was legendary in being able to produce mathematical results without setting down the intermediate steps
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he developed a strong interest in biology and especially evolution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he obtained a needed scholarship to the university of cambridge in 1909 as scholar at gonville and caius college
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he had a very happy time there forming many friendships and became enthralled with the heady intellectual atmospherics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1911 he became heavily involved in the formation of the cambridge university eugenics society with such luminaries as john maynard keynes r c punnett and horace darwin charles darwin's son
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the group was quite active and held monthly meetings often featuring addresses by leaders of mainstream eugenics organizations such as the eugenics education society of london founded by francis galton in 1909
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by the time fisher graduated with a degree in mathematics in 1913 it had over 150 members
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from the time of graduation when he left cambridge for a mundane job in london it would be six years before he found a post that could use his abilities to advantage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: major leonard darwin another of charles darwin's sons and an unconventional and vivacious friend he called gudruna were almost his only contacts with his cambridge circle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they sustained him through this difficult period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when the war came he tried several times to enlist but was rejected because of his eyesight
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for his war work he took up teaching physics and mathematics at a series of public schools including bradfield college in berkshire
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was miserable and did poorly at it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a bright spot in his life was that gudruna matched him to her sister eileen guinness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he fell madly in love and they married when she was only 17 in 1917
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the sisters help he set up a subsistence farming operation on the bradfield estate where they had a large garden and raised animals learning to make do on very little
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they lived through the war without ever using their food coupons
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during this period fisher started writing book reviews for the eugenic review and gradually increased his interest in genetical and statistical work
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he volunteered to undertake all such reviews for the journal and was hired to a part time position by major darwin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he published several articles on biometry during this period including the ground breaking the correlation between relatives on the supposition of mendelian inheritance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this paper laid the foundation for what came to be known as biometrical genetics and introduced the very important methodology of the analysis of variance which was a considerable advance over the correlation methods used previously
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the paper showed very convincingly that the inheritance of traits measurable by real values the values of continuous variables is consistent with mendelian principles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the end of the war he went looking for a new job and was offered one at the famed galton laboratory by karl pearson
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because he saw the developing rivalry with pearson as a professional obstacle however he accepted instead a temporary job as a statistician with a small agricultural station in the country in 1919
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1919 fisher started work at rothamsted experimental station located at harpenden in hertfordshire england
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: here he started a major study of the extensive collections of data recorded over many years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this resulted in a series of reports under the general title studies in crop variation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was in his prime and he began a period of amazing productivity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: over the next seven years he pioneered the principles of the design of experiments and elaborated his studies of analysis of variance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he furthered his studies of the statistics of small samples
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: perhaps even more important he began his systematic approach of the analysis of real data as the springboard for the development of new statistical methods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he began to pay particular attention to the labor involved in the necessary computations and developed ingenious methods that were as practical as they were founded in rigor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1925 this work culminated in the publication of his first book statistical methods for research workers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this went into many editions and translations in later years and became a standard reference work for scientists in many disciplines
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1935 this was followed by the design of experiments which also became a standard
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher invented the techniques of maximum likelihood and analysis of variance and originated the concepts of sufficiency ancillarity fisher's linear discriminator and fisher information
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his 1924 article on a distribution yielding the error functions of several well known statistics presented karl pearson's chi squared and student's t in the same framework as the normal distribution and his own analysis of variance distribution z more commonly used today in the form of the f distribution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these contributions easily made him a major figure in 20th century statistics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in defending the use of the z distribution when the data were not gaussian fisher introduced the randomization test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to quote from the biographical article by yates and mather referenced below fisher introduced the randomizationtest comparing the value of t or z actually obtained with the distribution ofthe t or z values when all possible random arrangements were imposed on theexperimental data but fisher wrote that randomization tests were in no sense put forward to supersede the common and expeditious tests based on the gaussian theory of errors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher thus effectively began the field of non parametric statistics even though he didn't believe it was necessary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his work on the theory of population genetics also made him one of the three great figures of that field together with sewall wright and j b s haldane and as such was one of the founders of the neo darwinian modern evolutionary synthesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher introduced the concept of fisher information in 1925 many years before shannon's notion of entropy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher information has been the subject of renewed interest in the last few years both due to the growth of bayesian inference in artificial intelligence and due to b roy frieden's book physics from fisher information which attempts to derive the laws of physics from a fisherian starting point
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher was an ardent promoter of eugenics which also stimulated and guided much of his work in genetics of man
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his book the genetical theory of natural selection was started in 1928 and published in 1930
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it contained a summary of what was already known to the literature
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he developed ideas on sexual selection mimicry and the evolution of dominance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he famously showed that chance of a mutation increasing the fitness of an organism decreases with the magnitude of the mutation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he also proved that larger populations carry more variation so that they have a larger chance of survival
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he set forth the foundations of what was to become known as population genetics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: about a third of the book concerned the applications of these ideas to man and presented what data there was available at the time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he presented a theory that attributed the decline and fall of civilizations to its arrival of a state where the fertility of the upper classes is forced down
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: using the census data of 1911 for britain he showed that there was an inverse relationship between fertility and social class
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was partly due he believed to the rise in social status of families who were not capable of producing many children but who rose because of the financial advantage of having a small number of children
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: therefore he proposed the abolishment of the economic advantage of small families by instituting subsidies he called them allowances to families with larger numbers of children with the allowances proportional to the earnings of the father
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he himself had two sons and six daughters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to yates and mather his large family in particular reared in conditionsof great financial stringency was a personal expression of his genetic andevolutionary convictions between 1929 and 1934 the eugenics society also campaigned hard for a law permitting sterilization on eugenic grounds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they believed that it should be entirely voluntary and a right not a punishment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they published a draft of a proposed bill and it was submitted to parliament
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although it was defeated by a 2:1 ratio this was viewed as progress and the campaign continued
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher played a major role in this movement and served in several official committees to promote it.in 1934 fisher moved to increase the power of scientists within the eugenics society but was ultimately thwarted by members with an environmentalist point of view and he along with many other scientists resigned
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as an adult fisher was noted for his loyalty to his friends
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: once he had formed a favorable opinion of any man he was loyal to a fault
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a similar sense of loyalty bound him to his culture
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was a patriot a member of the church of england politically conservative and a scientific rationalist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: much sought after as a brilliant conversationalist and dinner companion he very early on developed a reputation for carelessness in his dress and sometimes his manners
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in later years he was the archetype of the absent minded professor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: having been brought up in the church of england he knew the scriptures well but was not dogmatic in his religious beliefs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in a 1955 broadcast on science and christianity he said the custom of making abstract dogmatic assertions is not certainly,derived from the teaching of jesus but has been a widespread weaknessamong religious teachers in subsequent centuries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: i do not think that theword for the christian virtue of faith should be prostituted to mean thecredulous acceptance of all such piously intended assertions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: much self deceptionin the young believer is needed to convince himself that he knowsthat of which in reality he knows himself to be ignorant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that surely ishypocrisy against which we have been most conspicuously warned
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was fisher who referred to the growth rate r used in equations such as the logistic function as the malthusian parameter as a criticism of the writings of thomas robert malthus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher referred to ...a relic of creationist philosophy in observing the fecundity of nature and deducing as darwin did that this therefore drove natural selection
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he received the recognition of his peers in 1929 when he was inducted into the royal society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his fame grew and he began to travel more and lecture to wider circles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1931 he spent six weeks at the statistical laboratory at iowa state college in ames iowa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he gave three lectures a week on his work and met many of the active american statisticians including george w snedecor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he returned again for another visit in 1936
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1933 he left rothamsted to become a professor of eugenics at university college london
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1937 he visited the indian statistical institute in calcutta which at the time consisted of one part time employee professor p c mahalanobis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he revisited there often in later years encouraging its development
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was the guest of honor at its 25th anniversary in 1957 when it had grown to 2000 employees
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1939 when war broke out the university tried to dissolve the eugenics department and ordered all of the animals destroyed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher fought back but he was exiled back to rothamsted with a much reduced staff and resources
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was unable to find any suitable war work and though he kept very busy with various small projects he became discouraged of any real progress
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his marriage disintegrated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his oldest son a pilot was killed in the war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1943 he was offered the balfour chair of genetics at cambridge his alma mater
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the war this department was also pretty much destroyed but the university promised him that he would be charged with rebuilding it after the war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he accepted the offer but the promises were largely unfilled and the department grew very slowly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a notable exception was the recruitment in 1948 of the italian researcher cavalli sforza who established a one man unit of bacterial genetics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his reappointment was denied by the university in the summer of 1950 much to fisher's dismay
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he now realized he could expect little in the way of support but he continued his work on mouse chromosome mapping and other projects
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they culminated in the publication in 1949 of the idiosyncratic the theory of inbreeding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1947 he co founded with cyril darlington the journal heredity an international journal of genetics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he received many awards for his work and was created a knight bachelor by queen elizabeth ii in 1952
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher was opposed to the conclusions of richard doll that smoking caused lung cancer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to quote yates and mather again it has been suggested that the fact that fisher was employed as consultant by the tobacco firmsin this controversy casts doubt on the value of his arguments
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is to misjudge the man
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was notabove accepting financial reward for his labours but the reason for his interest was undoubtedly hisdislike and mistrust of puritanical tendencies of all kinds and perhaps also the personal solacehe had always found in tobacco after retiring from cambridge in 1957 he spent some time as a senior research fellow at the csiro in adelaide australia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he died of colon cancer in 1962
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fisher's important contributions to both genetics and statistics are emphasized by the remark of lj savage i occasionally meet geneticists who ask me whether it is true that the great geneticist ra fisher was also an important statistician annals of statistics 1976
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are available on the university of adelaide website
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: full publication details are available on the university of adelaide website
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: arithmetic mean nyaeta standar average biasa dipake keur nyebut mean
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is used for many purposes and may be abused by using it to describe skewed distributions with highly misleading results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a classic example is average income
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the arithmetic mean may be used to imply that most people's incomes are higher than is in fact the case
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when presented with an average one may be led to believe that most people's incomes are near this number
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this average arithmetic mean income is higher than most people's incomes because high income outliers skew the result higher in contrast the median income resists such skew
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however this average says nothing about the number of people near the median income nor does it say anything about the modal income that most people are near
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nevertheless because one might carelessly relate average and most people one might incorrectly assume that most people's incomes would be higher nearer this inflated average than they are
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: consider the scores {1 2 2 2 3 9}

lines.value: the arithmetic mean is 3.17 but five out of six scores are below this

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: watesan nu pakait dina survey nyaeta kasalahan variabel acak dina panalungtikan sarta bias teu-acak atawa akibat langsung nu disababkeun ku ayana hal nu teu pakait ku variabel mandiri
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: akurasi nyaeta tingkat kadeukeutan sedengkeun presisi nyaeta tingkat kamampuh dijieun deui
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: analogi dipake di dieu keur nerangkeun beda antara akurasi jeung presisi nyaeta babandingan target
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this analogy repeated measurements are compared to arrows that are fired at a target
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: accuracy describes the closeness of arrows to the bullseye at the target center
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: arrows that strike closer to the bullseye are considered more accurate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the closer a system's measurements to the accepted value the more accurate the system is considered to be.to continue the analogy if a large number of arrows are fired precision would be the size of the arrow cluster
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when only one arrow is fired precision is the size of the cluster one would expect if this were repeated many times under the same conditions when all arrows are grouped tightly together the cluster is considered precise since they all struck close to the same spot if not necessarily near the bullseye
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the measurements are precise though not necessarily accurate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further example if a measuring rod is supposed to be ten yards long but is only 9 yards 35 inches measurements can be precise but inaccurate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the measuring rod will give consistently similar results but the results will be consistently wrong
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however it is not possible to reliably achieve accuracy in individual measurements without precision - if the arrows are not grouped close to one another they cannot all be close to the bullseye
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: their average position might be an accurate estimation of the bullseye but the individual arrows are inaccurate see also circular error probable for application of precision to the science of ballistics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as described in the sigda newsletter [vol 20
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: number 1 june 1990] a common mistake in evaluation of accurate models is to compare a logic simulation model to a transistor circuit simulation model
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is a comparison of differences in precision not accuracy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: precision is measured with respect to detail and accuracy is measured with respect to reality
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another reference for this topic is logic level modelling by john m acken encyclopedia of computer science and technology vol 36 1997 page 281-306
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ideally a measurement device is both accurate and precise with measurements all close to and tightly clustered around the known value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the accuracy and precision of a measurement process is usually established by repeatedly measuring some traceable reference standard
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such standards are defined in the international system of units and maintained by national standards organizations such as the national institute of standards and technology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: precision is usually characterised in terms of the standard deviation of the measurements sometimes incorrectly called the measurement process's standard error
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the interval defined by the standard deviation is the 68.3% one sigma confidence interval of the measurements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if enough measurements have been made to accurately estimate the standard deviation of the process and if the measurement process produces normally distributed errors then it is likely that 68.3% of the time the true value of the measured property will lie within one standard deviation 95.4% of the time it will lie within two standard deviations and 99.7% of the time it will lie within three standard deviations of the measured value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this also applies when measurements are repeated and averaged
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in that case the term standard error is properly applied the precision of the average is equal to the known standard deviation of the process divided by the square root of the number of measurements averaged
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further the central limit theorem shows that the probability distribution of the averaged measurements will be closer to a normal distribution than that of individual measurements
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with regard to accuracy we can distinguish a reading of 8000 m with trailing zeroes and no decimal point is ambiguous the trailing zeroes may or may not be intended as significant figures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to avoid this ambiguity the number could be represented in scientific notation 8.0 x 10³ m indicates that the first zero is significant hence a margin of 50 m while 8.000 x 10³ m indicates that all three zeroes are significant giving a margin of 0.5 m similarly it is possible to use a multiple of the basic measurement unit 8.0 km is equivalent to 8.0 x 10³ m
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in fact it indicates a margin of 0.05 km 50 m
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however reliance on this convention can lead to false precision errors when accepting data from sources that do not obey it.looking at this in another way a value of 8 would mean that the measurement has been made with a precision of 1 the measuring instrument was able to measure only up to 1's place whereas a value of 8.0 though mathematically equal to 8 would mean that the value at the first decimal place was measured and was found to be zero
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the measuring instrument was able to measure the first decimal place the second value is more precise
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: neither of the measured values may be accurate the actual value could be 9.5 but measured inaccurately as 8 in both instances
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus accuracy can be said to be the correctness of a measurement while precision could be identified as the ability to resolve smaller differences
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: precision is sometimes stratified into something to think about in the nfl a place kicker makes 9 of 10 field goals and another makes 6 of 10
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even if the 6 that the second kicker made were straight down the middle and the first kicker just made his in he is still less accurate and less precise than the first kicker
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this differs from the darts example because either you make it or you do not there are not different levels of points that can be scored
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: accuracy is also used as a statistical measure of how well a binary classification test correctly identifies or excludes a condition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that is the accuracy is the proportion of true results both true positives and true negatives in the population
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is a parameter of the test
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in psychometrics the terms accuracy and precision are interchangeably used with validity and reliability respectively
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: validity of a measurement instrument or psychological test is established through experiment or correlation with behavior
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: reliability is established with a variety of statistical technique classically cronbach's alpha
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina catetan hirupna gandhi ngajelaskeu kajadian ieu salaku kagagalan dina lobi ka baraya nu leuwih kolot
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina kaayaan ieu nyaeta taun 1893 ditarima keur kontrak panjang di parusahaan india keur dikirim ka natal afrika kidul
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!at this point in his life gandhi was a mild mannered diffident and politically indifferent individual
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he had read his first newspaper at the age of 18 and was prone to stage fright while speaking in court
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: south africa changed him dramatically as he faced the discrimination that was commonly directed at blacks and indians in that country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one day in court in the city of durban the magistrate asked him to remove his turban
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi refused to do so and stormed out of the courtroom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in another incident he was thrown off a train at pietermaritzburg after refusing to move from the first class coach to a third class compartment while holding a valid first class ticket
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later travelling further on by stagecoach he was beaten by a driver for refusing to travel on the footboard to make room for a european passenger
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he suffered other hardships on the journey as well including being barred from many hotels on account of his race
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these incidents have been acknowledged by several biographers as a turning point in his life that would serve as the catalyst for his activism later in life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was through witnessing first hand the racism prejudice and injustice against indians in south africa that gandhi started to question his people's status and his own place in society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the end of his contract gandhi prepared to return to india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however at a farewell party in his honour in durban he happened to glance at a newspaper and learned that a bill was being considered by the natal legislative assembly to deny the right to vote to indians
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when he brought this up with his hosts they lamented that they did not have the expertise necessary to oppose the bill and implored gandhi to stay and help them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he circulated several petitions to both the natal legislature and the british government in opposition to the bill
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though unable to halt the bill's passage his campaign was successful in drawing attention to the grievances of indians in south africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: supporters convinced him to remain in durban to continue fighting against the injustices levied against indians in south africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he founded the natal indian congress in 1894 with himself as the secretary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: through this organization he moulded the indian community of south africa into a homogeneous political force publishing documents detailing indian grievances and evidence of british discrimination in south africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi returned briefly to india in 1896 to bring his wife and children to live with him in south africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when he returned in january 1897 a white mob attacked and tried to lynch him
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in an early indication of the personal values that would shape his later campaigns he refused to press charges on any member of the mob stating it was one of his principles not to seek redress for a personal wrong in a court of law
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the onset of the south african war gandhi argued that indians must support the war effort in order to legitimize their claims to full citizenship organizing a volunteer ambulance corps of 300 free indians and 800 indentured labourers called the indian ambulance corps one of the few medical units to serve wounded black south africans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he himself was a stretcher bearer at the battle of spion kop and was decorated
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the conclusion of the war however the situation for the indians did not improve but continued to deteriorate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1906 the transvaal government promulgated a new act compelling registration of the colony's indian population
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at a mass protest meeting held in johannesburg that september gandhi adopted his methodology of satyagraha devotion to the truth or non violent protest for the first time calling on his fellow indians to defy the new law and suffer the punishments for doing so rather than resist through violent means
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this plan was adopted leading to a seven year struggle in which thousands of indians were jailed including gandhi himself on many occasions flogged or even shot for striking refusing to register burning their registration cards or engaging in other forms of non violent resistance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while the government was successful in repressing the indian protesters the public outcry stemming from the harsh methods employed by the south african government in the face of peaceful indian protesters finally forced south african general jan christiaan smuts to negotiate a compromise with gandhi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in may 1915 gandhi founded an ashram on the outskirts of ahmedabad and called it satyagrah ashram also known as sabarmati ashram
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there lodged twenty five men and women who took vows of truth celibacy ahimsa nonpossession control of the palate and service of the indian people
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as he had done in the south african war gandhi urged support of the british in world war i and was active in encouraging indians to join the army
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his rationale opposed by many others was that if he desired the full citizenship freedoms and rights in the empire it would be wrong not to help in its defence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he spoke at the conventions of the indian national congress but was primarily introduced to indian issues politics and the indian people by gopal krishna gokhale at the time one of the most respected leaders of the congress party
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi's first major achievements came in 1918 with the champaran agitation and kheda satyagraha although in the latter he was involved at par with sardar vallabhai patel who acted as his right hand and leader of the rebels
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in champaran a district in the state of bihar he organized civil resistance on the part of tens of thousands of landless farmers and serfs and poor farmers with small lands who were forced to grow indigo and other cash crops instead of the food crops necessary for their survival
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: suppressed by the militias of the landlords mostly british they were given measly compensation leaving them mired in extreme poverty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the villages were kept extremely dirty and unhygienic and alcoholism untouchability and purdah were rampant
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: now in the throes of a devastating famine the british levied an oppressive tax which they insisted on increasing in rate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the situation was desperate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in kheda in gujarat the problem was the same
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi established an ashram there organizing scores of his veteran supporters and fresh volunteers from the region
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he organized a detailed study and survey of the villages accounting the atrocities and terrible episodes of suffering including the general state of degenerate living
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: building on the confidence of villagers he began leading the clean up of villages building of schools and hospitals and encouraging the village leadership to undo and condemn many social evils as accounted above
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but his main assault came as he was arrested by police on the charge of creating unrest and was ordered to leave the province
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hundreds of thousands of people protested and rallied outside the jail police stations and courts demanding his release which the court unwillingly granted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi led organized protests and strikes against the landlords who with the guidance of the british government signed an agreement granting more compensation and control over farming for the poor farmers of the region and cancellation of revenue hikes and collection until the famine ended
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was during this agitation that gandhi was addressed by the people as bapu father and mahatma great soul
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in kheda patel represented the farmers in negotiations with the british who suspended revenue collection and granted relief
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all prisoners were released
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi's resulting fame spread all over the nation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in punjab the jallianwala bagh massacre of civilians by british troops caused deep trauma to the nation and increased public anger and acts of violence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi criticized both the actions of the british and the retaliatory violence of indians
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he authored the resolution offering condolences to british civilian victims and condemning the riots which after initial opposition in the party was accepted after gandhi made an emotional speech pushing forth his principle that all violence was evil and could not be justified
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but it was after the massacre and violence that gandhi's mind focused upon obtaining complete self government and control of all indian government institutions maturing soon into swaraj or complete individual spiritual political independence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi was invested with executive authority on behalf of the indian national congress in december 1921
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: under gandhi's leadership the congress was reorganized with a new constitution with the goal of swaraj
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: membership in the party was opened to anyone prepared to pay a token fee
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a hierarchy of committees was set up to improve discipline transforming the party from an elite organization to one of mass national appeal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi expanded his non violence platform to include the swadeshi policy - the boycott of foreign made goods especially british goods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: linked to this was his advocacy that khadi homespun cloth be worn by all indians instead of british made textiles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi exhorted indian men and women rich or poor to spend time each day spinning khadi in support of the independence movement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was a strategy to inculcate discipline and dedication to weed out the unwilling and ambitious and include women in the movement at a time when many thought that such activities were not respectable for women
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition to boycotting british products gandhi urged the people to boycott british educational institutions and law courts to resign from government employment and to forsake british titles and honours
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: non cooperation enjoyed wide spread appeal and success increasing excitement and participation from all strata of indian society yet just as the movement reached its apex it ended abruptly as a result of a violent clash in the town of chauri chaura uttar pradesh in february 1922
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: fearing that the movement was about to take a turn towards violence and convinced that this would be the undoing of all his work gandhi called off the campaign of mass civil disobedience
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi was arrested on march 10 1922 tried for sedition and sentenced to six years
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: beginning on march 18 1922 he only served about two years of the sentence being released in february 1924 after an operation for appendicitis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: without gandhi's uniting personality the indian national congress began to splinter during his years in prison splitting into two factions one led by chitta ranjan das and motilal nehru favouring party participation in the legislatures and the other led by chakravarti rajagopalachari and sardar vallabhbhai patel opposing this move
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: furthermore cooperation among hindus and muslims which had been strong at the height of the nonviolence campaign was breaking down
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi attempted to bridge these differences through many means including a three week fast in the autumn of 1924 but with limited success
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi stayed out of the limelight for most of the 1920s preferring to resolve the wedge between the swaraj party and the indian national congress and expanding initiatives against untouchability alcoholism ignorance and poverty
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he returned to the fore in 1928
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the year before the british government appointed a new constitutional reform commission under sir john simon numbering not a single indian in its ranks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the result was a boycott of the commission by indian political parties
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi pushed through a resolution at the calcutta congress in december 1928 calling on the british government to grant india dominion status or face a new campaign of non violence with complete independence for the country as its goal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi had moderated the views of younger men like subhas chandra bose and jawaharlal nehru who sought a demand for immediate independence but also modified his own call to a one year wait instead of two
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the british did not respond
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on december 31 1929 the flag of india was unfurled in lahore
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: january 26 1930 was celebrated by the indian national congress meeting in lahore as india's independence day
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this day was commemorated by almost every other indian organization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: making good on his word in march 1930 he launched a new satyagraha against the tax on salt highlighted by the famous salt march to dandi from march 21 to april 6 1930 marching 400 kilometres 248 miles from ahmedabad to dandi gujarat to make his own salt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thousands of indians joined him on this march to the sea
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this campaign was one of his most successful resulting in the imprisonment of over 60000 people
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the government represented by lord edward irwin decided to negotiate with gandhi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gandhi irwin pact was signed in march 1931
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in it the british government agreed to set all political prisoners free in return for the suspension of the civil disobedience movement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: furthermore gandhi was invited to attend the round table conference in london as the sole representative of the indian national congress
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the conference was a disappointment to gandhi and the nationalists as it focused on the indian princes and indian minorities rather than the transfer of power
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: furthermore lord irwin's successor lord willingdon embarked on a new campaign of repression against the nationalists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi was again arrested and the government attempted to destroy his influence by completely isolating him from his followers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this tactic was not successful
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1932 through the campaigning of the dalit leader b r ambedkar the government granted untouchables separate electorates under the new constitution
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in protest gandhi embarked on a six day fast in september 1932 successfully forcing the government to adopt a more equitable arrangement via negotiations mediated by the dalit cricketer turned political leader palwankar baloo
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this began a new campaign by gandhi to improve the lives of the untouchables whom he named harijans the children of god
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on may 8 1933 gandhi began a 21-day fast of self purification to help the harijan movement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the summer of 1934 three unsuccessful attempts were made on his life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when the congress party chose to contest elections and accept power under the federation scheme gandhi decided to resign from party membership
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he did not at all disagree with the party's move but felt that if he resigned his popularity with indians would cease to stifle the party's membership that actually varied from communists socialists trade unionists students religious conservatives to those with pro business convictions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi also did not want to prove a target for raj propaganda by leading a party that had temporarily accepted political accommodation with the raj
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi returned to the head in 1936 with the nehru presidency and the lucknow session of the congress
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although gandhi desired a total focus on the task of winning independence and not speculation about india's future he did not restrain the congress from adopting socialism as its goal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi had a clash with subhas bose who had been elected to the presidency in 1938
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi's main issues with bose were his lack of commitment to democracy and lack of faith in non violence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bose won his second term despite gandhi's criticism but left the congress when the all india leaders resigned en masse in protest of his abandonment of principles introduced by gandhi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: world war ii broke out in 1939 when nazi germany invaded poland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: initially gandhi had favored offering non violent moral support to the british effort but other congress leaders were offended by the unilateral inclusion of india into the war without consultation of the people's representatives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all congressmen elected to office resigned en masse
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after lengthy deliberations gandhi declared that india could not be party to a war ostensibly being fought for democratic freedom while that freedom was denied in india herself
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as the war progressed gandhi increased his demands for independence drafting a resolution calling for the british to quit india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was gandhi's and the congress party's most definitive revolt aimed at securing the british exit from indian shores
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi was criticized by some congressmen and other indian political groups both pro british and anti british
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some felt that opposing britain in its life death struggle was immoral and others felt that gandhi wasn't doing enough
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: quit india became the most forceful movement in the history of the struggle with mass arrests and violence on an unprecedented scale
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thousands of freedom fighters were killed or injured in police firing and hundreds of thousands were arrested
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi and his supporters made it clear they would not support the war effort unless india was granted immediate independence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he even clarified that this time the movement would not be stopped if individual acts of violence were committed saying that the ordered anarchy around him was worse than real anarchy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he called on all congressmen and indians to maintain discipline in ahimsa and karo ya maro do or die in the cause of ultimate freedom
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi and the entire congress working committee were arrested in bombay by the british on august 9 1942
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi was held for two years in the aga khan palace in pune
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was here that gandhi suffered two terrible blows in his personal life - his wife kasturba died just a few months after mahadev desai his 42-year old secretary died of a heart attack
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was released before the end of the war because of his failing health and necessary surgery the raj did not want him to die in prison and enrage the entire nation beyond control
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although the ruthless suppression of the movement by british forces brought relative order to india by the end of 1943 quit india succeeded in its objective
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the end of the war the british gave clear indications that power would be transferred to indian hands and gandhi called off the struggle and the congress leadership and around 100000 political prisoners were released
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in february 1944 kasturbai gandhi died in prison and six weeks later gandhi suffered a severe malaria attack
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during this time gandhi's health continually deteriorated to the point that the government on may 6 1944 decided to release him
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi advised the congress to reject the proposals the british cabinet mission offered in 1946 as he was deeply suspicious of the grouping proposed for muslim majority states - gandhi viewed this as a precursor to partition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however this became one of the few times the congress broke from gandhi's advice not his leadership though as nehru and patel knew that if the congress did not approve the plan the control of government would pass to the muslim league
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: between 1946 and 1947 over 5000 people were killed in violence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi was vehemently opposed to any plan that partitioned india into two separate countries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many muslims in india lived side by side with hindus and sikhs and were in favour of a united india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but muhammad ali jinnah the leader of the muslim league commanded widespread support in west punjab sindh nwfp and east bengal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the partition plan was approved by the congress leadership as the only way to prevent a wide scale hindu muslim civil war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: congress leaders knew that gandhi would viscerally oppose partition and it was impossible for the congress to go ahead without his agreement for gandhi's support in the party and throughout india was strong
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi's closest colleagues had accepted partition as the best way out and sardar patel endeavoured to convince gandhi that it was the only way to avoid civil war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a devastated gandhi gave his assent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on the day of the transfer of power gandhi did not celebrate independence with the rest of india but was alone in calcutta mourning the partition and working to end the violence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after india's independence gandhi focused on hindu muslim peace and unity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he conducted extensive dialogue with muslim and hindu community leaders working to cool passions in northern india as well as in bengal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite the indo pakistani war of 1947 he was troubled when the government decided to deny pakistan the rs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 55 crores due as per agreements made by the partition council
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: leaders like sardar patel feared that pakistan would use the money to bankroll the war against india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi was also devastated when demands resurged for all muslims to be deported to pakistan and when muslim and hindu leaders expressed frustration and an inability to come to terms with one another
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he launched his last fast unto death in delhi asking that all communal violence be ended once and for all and that the payment of rs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 55 crores be made to pakistan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi feared that instability and insecurity in pakistan would increase their anger against india and violence would spread across the borders
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he further feared that hindus and muslims would renew their enmity and precipitate into an open civil war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after emotional debates with his life long colleagues gandhi refused to budge and the government rescinded its policy and made the payment to pakistan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hindu muslim and sikh community leaders including the rss and hindu mahasabha assured him that they would renounce violence and call for peace
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi thus broke his fast by sipping orange juice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on january 30 1948 on his way to a prayer meeting gandhi was shot dead in birla house new delhi by nathuram godse
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: godse was a hindu radical with links to the extremist hindu mahasabha who held gandhi responsible for weakening india by insisting upon a payment to pakistan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: godse and his co conspirator narayan apte were later tried and convicted and on 15 november 1949 were executed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a prominent revolutionary and hindu revivalist the president of the mahasabha vinayak damodar savarkar was accused of being the architect of the plot but was acquitted due to lack of evidence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi's memorial or samadhi at raj ghat new delhi bears the epigraph devanagiri हे
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: राम or he ram which may be translated as oh god
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are widely believed to be gandhi's last words after he was shot though the veracity of this statement has been disputed by many
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: jawaharlal nehru addressed the nation through radio ::"friends and comrades the light has gone out of our lives and there is darkness everywhere and i do not quite know what to tell you or how to say it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: our beloved leader bapu as we called him the father of the nation is no more
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: perhaps i am wrong to say that nevertheless we will not see him again as we have seen him for these many years we will not run to him for advice or seek solace from him and that is a terrible blow not only for me but for millions and millions in this country
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi dedicated his life to the wider purpose of discovering truth or satya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he tried to achieve this by learning from his own mistakes and conducting experiments on himself
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he named his autobiography the story of my experiments with truth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi said that the most important battle to fight was in overcoming his own demons fears and insecurities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi summarized his beliefs first when he said god is truth but as typical of gandhi he evolved later to correct himself and state that truth is god the first statement seemed insufficient to gandhi as the mistake could be made that gandhi was using truth as a description of god rather than the summative definition of the entire essence of god
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: satya truth in gandhi's philosophy is god
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it shares all the characteristics of the hindu concept of god or brahman
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the concept of nonviolence ahinsa and nonresistance has a long history in indian religious thought and has had many revivals in hindu buddhist jain and christian contexts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi explains his philosophy and way of life in his autobiography the story of my experiments with truth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was quoted as saying :"i would like you to lay down the arms you have as being useless for saving you or humanity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: you will invite herr hitler and signor mussolini to take what they want of the countries you call your possessions if these gentlemen choose to occupy your homes you will vacate them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if they do not give you free passage out you will allow yourselves man woman and child to be slaughtered but you will refuse to owe allegiance to them even in 1946 by which time gandhi had learned of the holocaust he said to biographer louis fisher :"the jews should have offered themselves to the butcher's knife
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they should have thrown themselves into the sea from cliffs however gandhi was aware that this level of nonviolence required incredible faith and courage which he realized not everyone possessed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he therefore advised that everyone need not keep to nonviolence especially if it was used as a cover for cowardice
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a young child gandhi experimented in meat eating
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was due partially to his inherent curiosity as well as his rather persuasive peer and friend sheikh mehtab
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the idea of vegetarianism is deeply engrained in hindu and jain traditions in india and in his native land of gujarat many hindus were vegetarian
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gandhi family was no exception
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: before leaving for his studies in london gandhi made a promise to his mother putlibai and his uncle becharji swami that he would abstain from eating meat taking alcohol and engaging in promiscuity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he held fast to his promise and gained more than a diet he gained a basis for his life long philosophies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as gandhi grew into adulthood he became a strict vegetarian
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he wrote articles on the subject some of which were published in the london vegetarian society's publication the vegetarian gandhi became inspired by many great minds during this period and befriended a chairman of the london vegetarian society dr josiah oldfield
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: having also read and admired the work of henry stephens salt the young mohandas met and often corresponded with the vegetarian campaigner
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi spent much time advocating vegetarianism during and after his time in london
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to gandhi a vegetarian diet would not only satisfy the requirements of the body it would also serve an economic purpose as meat was and still is generally more expensive than grains legumes and fruits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: also many indians of the time struggled with low income thus vegetarianism was seen not only as a spiritual practice but also a practical one
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he abstained from eating for long periods using fasting as a political weapon he refused to eat until his death or his demands were met
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was noted in his autobiography that vegetarianism was the beginning of his deep commitment to brahmacharya without total control of the palate his success in bramacharya would have been likely to falter
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi gave up sexual intercourse at the age of 36 becoming totally celibate while still married
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this decision was deeply influenced by the philosophy of brahmacharya spiritual and practical purity largely associated with celibacy and asceticism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi saw brahmacharya as a means of going close to god and as a primary foundation for self realization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in his autobiography he tells of his battle against lustful urges and fits of jealousy with his childhood bride kasturba
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he felt it his personal obligation to remain celibate so that he could learn to love rather than lust
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for gandhi brahmacharya meant control of the senses in thought word and deed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi earnestly believed that a person involved in social service should lead a simple life which he thought could lead to brahmacharya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his simplicity began by renouncing the western lifestyle he was leading in south africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he called it reducing himself to zero which entailed giving up unnecessary expenditure embracing a simple lifestyle and washing his own clothes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on one occasion he returned the gifts bestowed to him from the natals for his diligent service to the community
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi spent one day of each week in silence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he believed that abstaining from speaking brought him inner peace
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this influence was drawn from the hindu principles of mouna silence and shanti peace
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on such days he communicated with others by writing on paper
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for three and a half years from the age of 37 gandhi refused to read newspapers claiming that the tumultuous state of world affairs caused him more confusion than his own inner unrest
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: returning to india from south africa where he had enjoyed a successful legal practice he gave up wearing western style clothing which he associated with wealth and success
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he dressed to be accepted by the poorest person in india advocating the use of homespun cloth khadi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi and his followers adopted the practice of weaving their own clothes from thread they themselves spun and encouraged others to do so
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while indian workers were often idle due to unemployment they had often bought their clothing from industrial manufacturers owned by british interests
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was gandhi's view that if indians made their own clothes it would deal an economic blow to the british establishment in india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: consequently the spinning wheel was later incorporated into the flag of the indian national congress
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he would wear a dhoti all his life to show simplicity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi was born a hindu and practiced hinduism all his life deriving most of his principles from hinduism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a common hindu he believed all religions to be equal and rejected all efforts to convert him to a different faith
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he was an avid theologian and read extensively about all major religions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he had the following to say about hinduism :"hinduism as i know it entirely satisfies my soul fills my whole being when doubts haunt me when disappointments stare me in the face and when i see not one ray of light on the horizon i turn to the bhagavad gita and find a verse to comfort me and i immediately begin to smile in the midst of overwhelming sorrow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: my life has been full of tragedies and if they have not left any visible and indelible effect on me i owe it to the teachings of the bhagavad gita gandhi believed that at the core of every religion was truth and love compassion nonviolence and the golden rule
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he also questioned hypocrisy malpractices and dogma in all religions and was a tireless social reformer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of his comments on various religions are :"yes i am
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: i am also a christian a muslim a buddhist and a jew in spite of their deep reverence to each other gandhi and rabindranath tagore got involved in protracted debates more than once
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these debates exemplify the philosophical differences between the two most famous indians at the time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on january 15 1934 an earthquake hit bihar and caused extensive damage and loss of life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi maintained this was because of the sin committed by upper caste hindus by not letting untouchables in their temples gandhi was committed to the cause of improving the fate of untouchables referring to them as harijans people of krishna
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tagore vehemently opposed gandhi's stance maintaining that an earthquake can only be caused by natural forces not moral reasons however repugnant the practice of untouchability may be
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: throughout his life and after his death gandhi has evoked serious criticism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: b r ambedkar the dalit political leader condemned gandhi's terming the untouchable community as harijans which he found condescending
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ambedkar and his allies also felt gandhi was undermining dalit political rights
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: muhammad ali jinnah and contemporary pakistanis often condemn gandhi for undermining muslim political rights
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: vinayak damodar savarkar condemned gandhi for appeasing muslims politically - savarkar and his allies blamed gandhi for thus facilitating the creation of pakistan and increasing the influence of the muslim community in politics beyond proportion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: savarkar himself was implicated in the trial following gandhi's murder as he was the mentor of the assassin nathuram godse and an important hindu mahasabha leader
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contemporary times historians like ayesha jalal blame gandhi and the congress for being unwilling to share power with muslims and thus hastening partition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hindu political activists like pravin togadia and narendra modi have been known to criticize gandhi's leadership and actions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi has also been criticized by various historians and commentators for his attitudes regarding hitler and nazism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi apparently believed that hitler's hatred could be transformed by the application of non violent resistance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi has come under fire in particular for statements to the effect that the jews would win god's love if they willingly went to their deaths as martyrs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some criticism of gandhi has been challenged in a number of articles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi has also been criticized by anti communists for referring to vladimir lenin as a titan in spirit and for generally supporting the cause of the soviet union
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi never received the nobel peace prize though he was nominated for it five times between 1937 and 1948
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: decades later however the nobel committee publicly declared its regret for the omission and admitted to deeply divided nationalistic opinion denying the award to gandhi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the prize was not awarded in 1948 the year of gandhi's death on the grounds that there was no suitable living candidate that year and when the dalai lama was awarded the prize in 1989 the chairman of the committee said that this was in part a tribute to the memory of mahatma gandhi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after gandhi's death albert einstein said of gandhi generations to come will scarcely believe that such a one as this walked the earth in flesh and blood he also once said i believe that gandhi's views were the most enlightened of all the political men in our time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: we should strive to do things in his spirit not to use violence in fighting for our cause but by non participation in anything you believe is evil time magazine named gandhi as the runner up to albert einstein as person of the century at the end of 1999 and named the dalai lama lech walesa dr martin luther king jr cesar chavez aung san suu kyi benigno aquino jr desmond tutu and nelson mandela as children of gandhi and his spiritual heirs to the tradition of non violence
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the government of india awards the annual mahatma gandhi peace prize to distinguished social workers world leaders and citizens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nelson mandela the leader of south africa's struggle to eradicate racial discrimination and segregation is a prominent non indian recipient of this honour
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1996 the government of india introduced the mahatma gandhi series of currency notes in rupees 5 10 20 50 100 500 and 1000 denomination
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the word mahatma while often mistaken for gandhi's given name in the west is taken from the sanskrit words maha meaning great and atma meaning soul
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the title mahatma was first accorded to gandhi on january 21 1915 by his pioneer supporter nautamlal bhagavanji mehta at the kamribai school in jetpur gujarat india in the erstwhile princely state of kathiawad
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in his autobiography gandhi nevertheless explains that he never felt worthy of the honour
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to the manpatra the name mahatma was given in response to gandhi's admirable sacrifice in manifesting justice and truth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the best known artistic depiction of his life is the film gandhi 1982 directed by richard attenborough and starring ben kingsley himself of gujarati parentage from his father's side in the title role
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the film has since been criticised by some post colonial scholars who argue that it depicts gandhi as single handedly bringing india to independence and ignores other prominent figures both elite and subaltern in the anti colonial struggle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the making of the mahatma directed by shyam benegal and starring rajat kapur is a film about gandhi's 21 years of life in south africa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi's character is played by anu kapoor in the film sardar 1993 about the life of sardar vallabhbhai patel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 1998 film hey ram made by kamal hasan portrays a would be assassin of gandhi and the dilemma faced by the would be assassins in the turmoil of post partition india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi's character is played by veteran actor naseeruddin shah
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are several works explorative of different aspects of gandhi's life and his controversial actions the play mahatma vs gandhi explores his troubled relationship with his eldest son harilal gandhi and me nathuram godse boltoy marathi i am nathuram godse speaking explores the rationale and circumstances in which gandhi's murder was plotted and carried out
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the opera satyagraha , composed by philip glass in 1980 with a libretto by himself and constance de jong is based on the life of gandhi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mahatma gandhi has been featured in the video game series civilization as a civilization leader of the indian civilization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he has appeared through the first three civilization games as a lone civilization leader but in civilization iv gandhi is a civilization leader alongside asoka the famous indian emperor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a gun toting gandhi is shown briefly in a parody trailer for gandhi ii in the comedy movie uhf in which he is described as no more mr passive resistance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gandhi is referred to in an episode of the sitcom seinfeld the old man as having an affair with one of the minor characters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the short lived mtv cartoon clone high featured the clone of gandhi as one of the main characters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the united kingdom there are several prominent statues of gandhi most notably in tavistock square london near university college london where he studied law
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: january 30 is commemorated in the united kingdom as national gandhi remembrance day
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the united states there are statues of gandhi outside the ferry building in san francisco union square park in new york city the martin luther king jr national historic site in atlanta the heritage park in skokie north suburb of chicago the hermann park in houston and near the indian embassy in the dupont circle neighbourhood of washington dc
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the city of pietermaritzburg south africa where gandhi was ejected in 1893 from a first class train now hosts a commemorative statue
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the government of india donated a statue to the city of winnipeg manitoba canada to signify their support for the future canadian museum for human rights
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are wax statues of gandhi at the madame tussaud's wax museums in new york and london and other cities around the world including moscow paris amsterdam barcelona lisbon canberra santiago de chile mexico city and trinidad and tobago's two cities port of spain and san fernando
lines.name: Sundanese
