lines.value: geus diterima sacara umum linguistik nyata ilmu pengunaan bahasa manusia sarta linguist nyata jalma nu kalibet dina widang ulikan ieu
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ulikan linguistik bisa dipikirkan sapanjang tilu hal utama nu tungtungna boleh dijelaskan saperti berikut linguistic inquiry is pursued by a wide variety of specialists who may not all be in harmonious agreement as russ rymer flamboyantly puts it linguistics is arguably the most hotly contested property in the academic realm
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is soaked with the blood of poets theologians philosophers philologists psychologists biologists and neurologists along with whatever blood can be got out of grammarians 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: theoretical linguistics is often divided into a number of separate areas to be studied more or less independently
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following divisions are currently widely acknowledged
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whereas the core of theoretical linguistics is concerned with studying languages at a particular point in time usually the present diachronic linguistics examines how language changes through time sometimes over centuries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: historical linguistics enjoys both a rich history the study of linguistics grew out of historical linguistics and a strong theoretical foundation for the study of language change
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in american universities the non historic perspective seems to have the upper hand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many introductory linguistics classes for example cover historical linguistics only cursorily
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the shift in focus to a non historic perspective started with saussure and became predominant with noam chomsky
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: explicitly historical perspectives include historical comparative linguistics and etymology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whereas theoretical linguistics is concerned with finding and describing generalities both within languages and among all languages as a group applied linguistics takes the results of those findings and applies them to other areas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: usually applied linguistics refers to the use of linguistic research in language teaching but linguistics is used in other areas as well
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: speech synthesis and speech recognition for example use linguistic knowledge to provide voice interfaces to computers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: contextual linguistics is that realm where linguistics interacts with other academic disciplines
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whereas core theoretical linguistics studies languages for their own sake the inder disciplinary areas of linguistic consider how language interacts with the rest of the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but that rather depends upon their world view
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sociolinguistics anthropological linguistics and linguistic anthropology are where the social sciences that consider societies as whole and linguistics interact
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: critical discourse analysis is where rhetoric and philosophy interact with linguistics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: psycholinguistics and neurolinguistics is the where the medical sciences meets linguistics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other cross disciplinary areas of linguistics include language acquisition evolutionary linguistics stratificational linguistics and cognitive science
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: linguists also differ in how broad a group of language users they study
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some analyze a given speaker's language or language development in great detail
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some study language pertaining to a whole speech community such as the language of all those who speak black english vernacular
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: others try to find linguistic universals that apply at some abstract level to all users of human language everywhere
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this latter project has been most famously advocated by noam chomsky and it interests many people in psycholinguistics and cognitive science
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is thought that universals in human language may reveal important insight into universals about the human mind
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most work currently done under the name linguistics is purely descriptive the linguists seek to clarify the nature of language without passing value judgments or trying to chart future language directions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nonetheless there are many professionals and amateurs who also prescribe rules of language holding a particular standard out for all to follow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whereas prescriptivists might want to stamp out what they perceive as incorrect usage descriptivists seek to find the root of such usage they might describe it simply as idiosyncratic or they may discover a regularity that the prescriptivists don't like because it is perhaps too new or from a dialect they don't approve of
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most contemporary linguists work under the assumption that spoken language is more fundamental and thus more important to study than writing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: reasons for this standpoint include furthermore the study of writing systems themselves falls under the aegis of linguistics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: phonetics phonology syntax semantics pragmatics etymology lexicology lexicography theoretical linguistics historical comparative linguistics and descriptive linguistics linguistic typology computational linguistics corpus linguistics semiotics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: applied linguistics historical linguistics orthography writing systems comparative linguistics cryptanalysis decipherment sociolinguistics critical discourse analysis psycholinguistics language acquisition evolutionary linguistics anthropological linguistics stratificational linguistics text linguistics cognitive science neurolinguistics and in computational linguistics there is natural language understanding speech recognition speaker recognition authentication speech synthesis and more generally speech processing
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early scholars of linguistics include jakob grimm who devised the principle of consonantal shifts in pronunciation known as grimm's law in 1822 karl verner who discovered verner's law august schleicher who created the stammbaumtheorie and johannes schmidt who developed the wellentheorie wave model in 1872
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ferdinand de saussure was the founder of modern structural linguistics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: noam chomsky's formal model of language transformational generative grammar developed under the influence of his teacher zellig harris who was in turn strongly influenced by leonard bloomfield has been the dominant one from the 1960s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other important linguists and schools include michael halliday whose systemic functional grammar is pursued widely in the uk canada australia china and jepang dell hymes who developed a pragmatic approach called the ethnography of speaking george lakoff len talmy and ronald langacker who were pioneers in cognitive linguistics charles fillmore and adele goldberg who are associated with construction grammar and linguists developing several varieties of what they call functional grammar including talmy givon and robert van valin jr
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: linguistics and linguist may not always be meant to apply as broadly as above
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in some contexts the best definitions may be what is studied in a typical university's department of linguistics and one who is a professor in such a department linguistics in this narrow sense usually does not refer to learning to speak foreign languages except insofar as this helps to craft formal models of language it does not include literary analysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: only sometimes does it include study of things such as metaphor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it probably does not apply to those engaged in such prescriptive efforts as found in strunk and white's the elements of style linguists usually seek to study what people do not what they should do
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one could probably argue for a long while about who is and who is not a linguist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dolly 5 juli 1996 - 14 pebruari 2003 mangrupa mamalia munggaran nu dihasilkeun tina kloning sel sawawa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: diklon di roslin institute di scotlandia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the name dolly came from a suggestion by jesse haase who helped with her birth in honour of dolly parton because it was a mammary cell [1] that was cloned
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the technique that was made famous by her birth is somatic cell nuclear transfer in which the nucleus of a non reproductive cell is placed in a de nucleated embryonic cell which then develops into a fetus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when dolly was cloned in 1996 from a cell taken from a six year old ewe she became the centre of much controversy that still exists today
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on 9 april 2003 her stuffed remains were placed at edinburgh's royal museum part of the national museums of scotland
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: while the promise of cloning extinct species has been a long standing justification for the development of cloning there are many other applications such as cloning animals eg cattle and horses which appears to offer a much faster and more efficient way of propagating desirable genes as chosen by humans than traditional breeding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another application which has recently become feasible is the cloning of pets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the company genetic savings and clone was established to provide such a service using chromatid transfer which is arguably more effective than nuclear transfer with little nicky being the first pet cloned by the company after the death of the original cat
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the procedure is still very expensive and has little demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however demand could be generated from unexpected quarters such as hollywood movies studios which could seek to store genetic samples of animal actors for the purpose of creating a clone to replace the original animal in a sequel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he then spent part of 1879 and 1880 studying medieval and 16th-century german literature at the universities of berlin and heidelberg &ndash in fact he became sufficiently knowledgeable in this field that he was offered a post in the german department at cambridge university
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his next career move was to lincoln's inn where he read law until 1881 although he never practised
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after this he returned to mathematics deputising for the mathematics professor at king's college london in 1881 and for the professor at university college london in 1883
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1884 he was appointed to the goldshmid chair of applied mathematics and mechanics at university college london
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 1891 saw him also appointed to the professorship of geometry at gresham college here he met wfr weldon a zoologist who had some interesting problems requiring quantitative solutions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the collaboration in biometry and evolutionary theory was a fruitful one and lasted until weldon died in 1906
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: weldon introduced pearson to francis galton who was interested in aspects of evolution such as heredity and eugenics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: galton died in 1911 and left the residue of his estate to the university of london for a chair in eugenics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson was the first holder of this chair in accordance with galton's wishes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he formed the department of applied statistics with financial support from the drapers company into which he incorporated the biometric and galton laboratories
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he remained with the department until his retirement in 1933 and continued to work until his death in 1936
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson married maria sharpe in 1890 and between them they had 2 daughters and a son
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the son egon sharpe pearson succeeded him as head of the applied statistics department at university college
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aside from his professional life pearson was active as a prominent freethinker and socialist
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he gave lectures on such issues as the woman's question this was the era of the suffragette movement in the uk and upon karl marx
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his commitment to socialism and its ideals led him to refuse the offer of being created an obe officer of the order of the british empire in 1920 and also to refuse a knighthood in 1935
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson's views on eugenics however would be considered deeply racist today
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to a bbc report on the history of genetics pearson was a fanatic &ndash a cold calculating measurer of man who claimed to be a socialist but loathed the working class pearson openly advocated war against inferior races and saw this as a logical implication of his scientific work on human measurement my view &ndash and i think it may be called the scientific view of a nation he wrote &ndash is that of an organized whole kept up to a high pitch of internal efficiency by insuring that its numbers are substantially recruited from the better stocks and kept up to a high pitch of external efficiency by contest chiefly by way of war with inferior races
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson achieved widespread recognition across a range of disciplines and his membership of and awards from various professional bodies reflects this
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson's work was all embracing in the wide application and development of mathematical statistics and encompassed the fields of biology epidemiology anthropometry medicine and social history
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1901 with weldon and galton he founded the journal biometrika whose object was the development of statistical theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he edited this journal till his death
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he also founded the journal annals of eugenics now annals of human genetics in 1925
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he published the drapers company research memoirs largely to provide a record of the output of the department of applied statistics not published elsewhere
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pearson's thinking underpins many of the classical statistical methods which are in common use today
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of his main contributions are
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term table is derived from a merger of french table and old english tabele related to old high german zabel and modern german tafel both of which are ultimately derived from the latin word tabula a board plank flat piece
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in late latin tabula took over the meaning previously reserved to mensa preserved in spanish mesa table
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in old english the word replaced bord for this meaning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tables come in a wide variety of shapes height and material depending on their origin style and intended use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all tables are composed of a flat surface and a base that may comprise of one or more legs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the surface may be virtually of any shape although rectangular square round a round table and oval tops are the most frequent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a table may be freestanding or meant to be placed against a wall a console table
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it might have more or less than four legs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a table with a single central foot is a pedestal table
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: long tables often have extra feet for support
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some tables have higher surfaces for standing at or sitting with a tall stool
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for some tables the top surface can be adjusted in size with a part that is foldable or can slide under the rest
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some tables are entirely foldable for easy transport e.g camping
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: small tables in trains and aircraft may be fixed or foldable although they are usually some sort of shelf rather than a table
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tables of various shape and size are used for specific uses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a table can be used temporarily for objects such as food and eating utensils during a meal cups for drinks a book especially a big one that one can not easily keep in one's hands a spread-out map writing paper during writing and anything that requires having several objects at hand including various hobbies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tables are frequently used to drop small items such as keychains or pens until further use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tables sometimes substitute for other pieces of furniture such as chairs and beds that require little more than a flat surface to accomplish their basic goal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: things may also be put more permanently on a table for example a tv computer objects for decoration such as vases or tablecloths etc table settings of food are laid out in a traditional arrangement
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: wooden tables are often used in hardcore wrestling matches
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are used for wrestlers to be slammed through and very rarely are they used as weapons after they are broken
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first tables were made and used by the egyptians and were little more than metal or stone platforms used to keep objects off the floor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they were not used for seating people
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: food was put on large plates deposed on a pedestal for eating
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the egyptians made use of various small tables and elevated playing boards
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the greeks and romans made more frequent use of tables notably for eating although greek tables were pushed under the beds after use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the greeks invented a piece of furniture very similar to the gueridon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tables were made of marble or wood and metal typically bronze or silver alloys
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later the larger rectangular tables were made of separate platforms and pillars
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the romans also introduced a large semicircular table to italy the mensa lunata
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: furniture during the middle ages is not as well known as that of earlier or later periods,and most sources show the types used by the nobility
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the eastern roman empire tables were made of metal or wood usually with four feet frequently linked by x shaped stretchers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tables for eating were large usually round or semicircular
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a combination of a small round table and a lectern seemed very popular as a writing table
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in western europe the invasions and intestine wars caused most of the knowledge inherited from the classical era to be lost
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as a result of the necessary movability most tables were simple trestle tables although small round tables made from joinery reappeared during the 15th century and onward
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the gothic era the chest became totally widespread and was often used as a table
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: refectory tables first appeared in the 16th century as an evolution of the trestle table
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lignin biosynthesis begins with the synthesis of monolignols
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the starting material is the amino acid phenylalanine
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first reactions in the biosynthesis are shared with the phenylpropanoid pathway and monolignols are considered to be a part of this group of compounds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are three types of monolignols coniferyl alcohol sinapyl alcohol and paracoumaryl alcohol
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: different plants use different monolignols
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example norway spruce lignin is almost entirely coniferyl alcohol while paracoumaryl alcohol is found almost exclusively in grasses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: monolignols are synthetised in the cytosol as glucosides
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the glucose is added to the monolignol to make them water soluble and to reduce their toxicity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the glucosides are transported through the cell membrane to the apoplast
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the glucose is then removed and the monolignols are polymerised into lignin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the polymerisation step is catalysed by oxidative enzymes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: both peroxidase and laccase enzymes are present in the plant cell walls and it is not known whether one or both of these groups participates in the polymerisation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the oxidative enzyme catalyses the formation of monolignol radicals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these radicals then undergo chemical coupling to form the lignin polymer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the details of this final step are being debated since it is not known how the abundance of various possible bond types between monolignols in controlled
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some theories favour pure chemical coupling while other state that dirigent proteins control this step
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pyrolysis of lignin eg during combustion yields a range of products of which the most characteristic ones are methoxy phenols
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: of those the most important are guaiacol and syringol and their derivates their presence can be used to trace a smoke source to a wood fire
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in cooking lignin in the form of hardwood is an important source of these two chemicals which impart the characteristic aroma and taste to smoked foods.-->
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: *lignin wikipedia edisi basa inggris 3 agustus 2006

lines.value: we changed from gatherers to hunter gatherers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the experience of the ice age it is probable that humans wanted to create some feeling of security by controlling what plants were growing and which animals were available
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this led to agriculture which has continually improved and altered the way in which food is obtained
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a selection of different complementary foods eaten together comprises a meal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: people often choose to eat meals together with other family members or friends and this is seen as an important social occasion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: food eaten in smaller quantities between meals is regarded as snack food
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the number of meals in a day their size composition when and how they are prepared and eaten vary greatly around the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is greatly dependent on the local climate ecology economy cultural traditions and industrialisation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: meals also plays an important role in the celebration of many key cultural and religious festivals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in societies where the availability of food has risen above subsistence levels and beyond staple foods food is also sold pre prepared for immediate consumption in restaurants and other similar retail premises
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in industrial societies meals often contain a higher proportion of food of animal origin
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :see also appetite buddhist cuisine eucharist fast food fasting gault millau restaurant guide halaal i tal kashrut michelin restaurant guide muslim dietary laws potluck totemism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: food is traditionally obtained through farming ranching and fishing with hunting foraging and other methods of subsistence locally important for some populations but minor for others
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the modern era in developed nations food supply is increasingly dependent upon agriculture industrial farming aquaculture and fish farming techniques which aim to maximise the amount of food produced whilst minimising the cost
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these include a reliance on mechanised tools which have been developed from the threshing machine seed drill through to the tractor and combine harvester etc these have been combined with the use of pesticides to promote high crop yields and combat those insects or mammals which reduce yield
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more recently there has been a growing trend towards more sustainable agricultural practices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this approach which is partly fuelled by consumer demand encourages biodiversity local self reliance and organic farming methods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: major influences on food production are international policy e.g the world trade organization and common agricultural policy national government policy or law and war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: food for livestock is fodder and traditionally comprises hay or grain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :see also mariculture horticulture agribusiness gardening
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: whilst some food can be eaten without preparation many foods undergo some form of preparation for reasons of safety palatability or flavour
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the simplest level this may involve washing cutting trimming or adding other foods or ingredients such as spices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it may also involve mixing heating or cooling pressure cooking fermentation or combination with other food
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most food preparation takes place in a kitchen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the preparation of animal based food will usually involve slaughter evisceration hanging portioning and rendering
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :see also barbecue eating utensils frankfurt kitchen hangi oven microwave oven refrigeration,
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: human knowledge of cooking and preparation methods is often taught by parents to their children largely based on the cuisine within their cultural traditions

lines.value: since the development of mass produced printing this has been supplemented by written recipes

lines.value: early examples of influential recipe books include de re coquinaria le repertoire de la cuisine larousse gastronomique and mrs beeton's book of household management
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :see also wikipedia cookbook

lines.value: food manufacturing or food processing arose during the industrialisation era in the 19th century
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this development took advantage of new mass markets and emerging new technology such as milling food preservation packaging and labelling and transportation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it brought the advantages of pre prepared time saving food to the bulk of ordinary people who did not employ domestic servants
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at the start of the 21st century a two tier structure has arisen with a few international food processing giants controlling a wide range of well known food brands with a populous number of small local or national food processing companies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: :'see also best before canning coloring food quality cook chill additives flavoring enzymes genetically modified food packaging and labelling pasteurization preservation shelf life ultra high temperature processing

lines.value: food is now traded on a global basis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the variety and availability of food is no longer restricted by the diversity of locally grown food or the limitations of the local growing season
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: between 1961 and 1999 there has been a 400% increase in worldwide food exports
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some countries are now economically dependant on food exports which in some cases account for over 80% of all exports
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1994 trade liberalisation began when over 100 countries became signatories to the uruguay round of the general agreement on tariffs and trade which included an agreement to reduce subsidies paid to farmers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is underpinned by the wto enforcement of agricultural subsidy tariffs import quotas and settlement of trade disputes that cannot be bilaterally resolved
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: where trade barriers are raised on the disputed grounds of public health and safety the wto refer the dispute to the codex alimentarius commission which was founded in 1962 by the united nations food and agriculture organization and the world health organization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the sale of surplus food traditionally took place once a week when farmers took their wares on market day into the local village market place
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: here food was sold to grocers for sale in their local shops for purchase by local people
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with the onset of industrialisation and the development of the food processing industry a wider range of food could be sold and distributed in distant locations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: typically early grocery shops would be counter based shops in which purchasers told the shop keeper what they wanted so that the shop keeper could get it for them
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 20th century supermarkets were born
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: supermarkets brought with them a self service approach to shopping using shopping carts or trollies in british english and were able to offer quality food at lower cost through economies of scale and reduced staffing costs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was sometimes known as pile it high in the latter part of the 20th century this has been further revolutionised by the development of vast warehouse sized out of town supermarkets selling an extraordinarily wide range of food from around the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: alike with food processors food retailing is a two tier market in which a small number of very large companies control a large proportion of supermarkets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the supermarket giants wield great purchasing power over farmers and processors and strong influence over consumers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nevertheless in 2000 only 19% of all us consumer expenditure spent on food went to farmers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: recent technological innovations such as point of sale technology barcodes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this allows ordering of goods and food to be driven by actual sales

lines.value: in the middle ages all royal courts had food tasters

lines.value: the sale of rancid contaminated or adulterated food was commonplace until introduction of hygiene and vermin controls in the 19th century

lines.value: discovery of techniques for killing bacteria using heat and other microbiological by scientists such as louis pasteur contributed to the modern standards that we enjoy today

lines.value: this was further underpinned by the work of justus von liebig whose work led to the development of modern food storage and food preservation methods

lines.value: understanding of the causes of food borne illnesses and more systematic techniques for their elimination has led to the development of commercial systems such as haccp which can if properly implemented identify and can eliminate all possible risks

lines.value: dietary habits play a significant role in the health and mortality of all humans
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the nutrient content of diets in industrialised countries contain more animal fat sugar energy alcohol and less dietary fiber carbohydrates and antidioxidants
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: contemporary changes to work family and exercise patterns together with concerns about the effect of nutrition and obesity on human health and mortality are all having an effect on traditional eating habits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: physicians and alternative medicine practitioners may recommend changes to diet as part of their recommendations for treatment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more recently dietary habits have been influenced by the concerns that some people have about the chronic impact on health that arise through the consumption of genetically modified food or beef infected with bovine spongiform encephalopathy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further concerns about the impact of indudtrial farming on animal welfare human health and the environment are also having an effect on contemporary human dietary habits

lines.value: this has led to the emergence of a counterculture with a preference for organic and local food

lines.value: ekonomi nyaeta elmu sosial nu ngulik ngageroh masalah produksi distribusi jeung konsumsi barang jeung jasa nu didadasaran ayana pipilih atawa tutukeuran di antara alternatip alternatip nu sipatna kompetitip nu eces dina kuantitas nu kaukur saperti asupan input harga jeung hasil kaluaran output
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: widang ekonomi ngawengku sababaraha teori nu kamungkinan gede teu bisa diharmoniskeun nu tumali jeung sistem produksi jeung distribusi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ngan dina aturan umumna mah para ahli ekonomi ngaheuyeuk nalungtik perilaku jalma jeung kamakmuran nu jadi tumali antara alat sumber ekonomi nu sipatna dibutuhkeun sacara sosial jeung nu sipatna langka jeung bisa jadi alternatip guna kagunaanana
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: lionel robbins 1935
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pamahaman nyorangan atawa kelompok kana pilihan pilihan mangrupa puseur elmu ekonomi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ku sifat ayana kalangkaan milih hiji alternatif tangtuna ngabalukarkeun pangaruh ka alternatif sejena di mana ahli ekonomi pasti milih ka alternatif panghadena jeung tangtuna eta nempatkeun alternatif sejen jadi opportunity cost
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: contona bae mun diajar hiji kaahlian ngabalukarkeun jadi teu boga waktu diajar kaahlian sejena
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tah dina alam pasar mah nu ayeuna jadi tiori paling gede pangaruhna eta kalangkaan teh paling umum diitung dihubungkeun jadi hiji harga economists believe that incentives and desires together play an important role in shaping decision making
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: concepts from the utilitarian school of philosophy are used as analytical concepts within economics though economists appreciate that society may not adopt utilitarian objectives
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one example of this is the idea of a utility function which is assumed to be the means by which individual economic actors decide what makes them happy and what decisions they make in pursuit of that happiness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the subject is said to be positive when it attempts to explain the consequences of different choices given a set of assumptions and normative when it prescribes a certain route of action
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: aspects receiving particular attention in economics are resource allocation production distribution or trade and competition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the word economy comes from the greek oikos for house and nomos for laws or norms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: originally the term oikonomikos was used for different contexts the house a town a city the polis in greek
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this last use originated the term political economy while the term economics was coined around 1870 and popularized by alfred marshall
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: note that the word economist predated economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after this change the term political economy has been used to denote the classical economy of the 19th century with adam smith david ricardo and karl marx as its main thinkers in recent years the term has also been used to describe the study of production systems which are not viewed through the lens of price but through descriptions of the network of relationships and requirements involved in a particular economy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are also those who use the terms economics and political economy as interchangeable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ekonomi biasana dibagi jadi dua cabang utama economics can also be divided into numerious subdisciplines that do not always fit neatly into the macro micro categorization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of these subdisciplines include international economics labour economics welfare economics resource economics environmental economics managerial economics financial economics urban economics and spatial economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are also methodologies used by economists whose underlying theories are important
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there has been an increasing trend for ideas and methods from economics to be applied in wider contexts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since economics analysis focuses on decision making it can be applied with varying degrees of success to any field where people are faced with alternatives &ndash education marriage health etc public choice theory studies how economic analysis can apply to those fields traditionally considered outside of economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the areas of investigation in economics therefore overlap with other social sciences including political science and sociology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see political economy for the study of economics in the context of political science
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most prevalent political economy is loosely called capitalism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mainstream economics does not assume a priori that markets are preferable to other forms of social organization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in fact much analysis is devoted to cases where so called market failures lead to resource allocation that is suboptimal by some standard
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in such cases economists may attempt to find policies that will avoid waste directly by government control indirectly by regulation that induces market participants to act in a manner consistent with optimal welfare or by creating missing markets to enable efficient trading where none had previously existed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is studied in the field of collective action
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mainstream economics centers around the relationship between supply and demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: supply can be said to be the amount of a given commodity available at a give price and demand can be said to be the amount of a commodity that would be purchased at a given price
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mainstream economic theory centers on creating a series of supply and demand relationships describing them as equations and then adjusting for factors which produce stickiness between supply and demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: analysis is then done to see what trade offs are made in the market which is the negotiation between sellers and buyers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: analysis is done as to what point the ability of sellers to sell becomes less useful than other opportunities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is related to marginal costs or the price to produce the last unit that can be sold profitably versus the chance of using the same effort to engage in some other activity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite the extreme controversy surrounding larger economic issues there is significant agreement among mainstream economists on the fundamentals of the subject especially as reflected in microeconomics as opposed to macroeconomics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in particular the nature of money supply and whether price reflects available information are areas of dispute
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see below for further discussion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: much contemporary theory assumes that economic agents act rationally to optimize well being given available information
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this may sometimes be an acceptable approximation for instance if a given individual's irrationality is canceled out in the aggregate and tends to produce tractable results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however this framework homo economicus has for decades been understood as a handy approximation e.g see herbert simon's model for bounded rationality which was awarded a nobel prize in 1978
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more recently irrational behavior and imperfect information have increasingly been the subject of formal modelling often referred to as behavioral economics for which daniel kahneman won a nobel prize in 2002
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an example is the growing field of behavioral finance which combines previous theory with cognitive psychology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: economics relies on rigorous styles of argument more than other social sciences
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is at least the purported ideal of professionals in the field
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: economic methodology has several interacting parts formal modelling has been adopted to some extent by all branches of economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is not the identical to what is often referred to as mathematical economics this includes but is not limited to an attempt to set microeconomics in particular general equilibrium on solid mathematical foundation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some reject mathematical economics the austrian school of economics believes that anything beyond simple logic is often unnecessary and inappropriate for economic analysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in fact the entire empirical deductive framework sketched in this section may be rejected outright by this school
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however we believe the framework sketched here represents accurately the current predominant view of economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <div style="float:right margin left:10px margin right:10px width:163px text align:center"> modern economic thought is usually considered to have begun with adam smith in the late 18th century although earlier thinkers such as the spanish scholastics and the physiocrats made important contributions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for an overview of precursors to smith as well as an overview of schools that have developed later see history of economic thought
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern mainstream economics can be said to begin with mills focusing of what was then called political economy on wealth which he defined exclusively in relation to the exchange value of objects or what would now be called price
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: classical economics as the economic work of the period is called forms the foundation of micro economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the central idea promoted by smith was that the competition between various suppliers and buyers would produce the best possible distribution of goods and services because it would encourage individuals to specialize and improve their capital so as to produce more value with the same labor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as with its contemporaneous idea of evolution it rests on the belief that large systems can be self regulating by the activity of their parts without specific direction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: smith's formulation is called the invisible hand and is still the centerpiece of market economics and capitalism in particular
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 19th century karl marx synthesized a variety of schools of thought involving the social distribution of resources including the work of adam smith as well as socialism and egalitarianism and used the systematic approach to logic taken from philosopher hegel to produce das kapital
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his work was the most widely adhered to critique of market economics during much of the 19th and 20th centuries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the marxist paradigm of economics is not generally held in high regard by market economists though some concepts from his work are occasionally used in mainstream contexts particularly in labor economics and in political economy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term marxian is in some contexts used to describe work which accepts concepts from his work but does not necessarily subscribe to the political thrust of marxist thought
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the early 20th century economics became increasingly statistical and the study of econometrics became increasingly important
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: statistical treatment of price unemployment money supply and other variables as well as the compiling of these statistics became more and more central to economic writing and disputes within the field of economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: macroeconomics diverged from microeconomics with keynes in the 1920s and was codified in the 1930s by keynes and others particularly john hicks
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it grew in popularity as a reaction to the great depression
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: keynes had been an influential exponent of the importance of central banking and government involvement in economic affairs as well as a critic of the political economy of the post world war i period
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: his general theory encapsulated both criticisms of classical theory that had been levelled by thorstein veblen and others as well a method for economic management of aggregate demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for an overview of a number of competing schools see macroeconomics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many economists use a combination of neoclassical microeconomics and keynesian macroeconomics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this combination sometimes known as the neoclassical synthesis was dominant in western teaching and public policy in the years following world war ii and up to the late 1970s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the neoclassical school was challenged by monetarism formulated in the late 1940's and early 1950's by milton friedman and associated with the university of chicago
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in principle economics can be applied to any type of economic organization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the majority of economic theory centers around systems where goods are exchanged in the market where buyers and sellers seek to maximize their results by trading
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the dominant form of market economics focuses on societies where property is owned by individuals money has a rational basis and profit comes from utilizing labor and capital to produce goods to be sold in the market or capitalism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however economic theory is also applied to markets where the control of capital is in the hands of the state or society which include socialism and mercantilism and to societies where the allocation of resources is not through the market but through political mechanisms generally referred to as command economies which includes communism and other forms of totalitarianism
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many economists assert that it is impossible to avoid the invisible hand of the market and hence all societies can be modelled through market dynamics though this viewpoint has vehement opponents across the political spectrum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the development of economics as a field of study is closely related to the rise of capital as the primary determining factor of production and trading hence its most detailed and precise work has dealt with the institutions belonging to market societies and most specifically to capitalist and socialist societies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to what extent economics must be adjusted to be applied to earlier forms of social organization has been the source of discussion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: generally mainstream economists mostly feel that the basic framework of economics is relevant and flexible enough to be applied to virtually any form of society
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: marxist economics asserts that history is divided into eras which are determined by which two classes which are struggling to control the means of production that is slaves and masters peasants and royalty wage workers and capitalists and that mainstream economics only applies to those societies which are objectively industrial that is to say societies which are capable of industrial production based on their own knowledge and resources
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see marxism particularly the hegelian roots of marxism in the late 20th century three of the areas of study which are producing change in economic thinking are risk based rather than price based models imperfect economic actors and treating economics as a biological science based on evolutionary norms rather than abstract exchange
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the study of risk has been influential which viewed variations in price over time as more important than actual price
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this particularly applies to financial economics where risk return tradeoffs are the crucial decisions to be made
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most important area of growth has been in the study of information and decision
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: examples of this school include the work of joseph stiglitz
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: problems of asymmetric information and moral hazard both based around information economics profoundly affect modern economic dilemmas like executive stock options insurance markets and third world debt relief
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: finally there are a series of economic ideas rooted in the conception of economics as a branch of biology including the idea that energy relationships rather than price relationships determine economic structure and the use of fractal geometry to create economic models
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see energy economics in its infancy is the application of non linear dynamics to economic theory as well as the application of evolutionary psychology
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: so far the most visible work has been in the area of applying fractals to market analysis particularly arbitrage
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see complexity in economics another infant branch of economics is neuroeconomics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this combines neuroscience economics and psychology to study how we make choices
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because scarcity and decision are central to economic theory the question of what is the basic trade off in economics is of central importance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in every economic theory there is a basic exchange of two or more ultimately scarce commodities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for adam smith it was defined as the trading of time or convenience for money
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example a person could live near town and pay more for rent or his domicile or live farther away and pay less paying the difference out of his convenience
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this view that the primary trade off involved in economics is between time and money has several challengers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: each of these bases its view of scarcity on a different fundamental trade off
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a small number of economists prefer to define economics as the study of how and why people trade this definition implies relative scarcity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in economic theory the price level is determined by the marginal cost and marginal utility
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: marginalism became increasingly important in economic theory in the late 19th century and is a tool which is used to analyze how economic systems will react
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the marginal cost of a commodity is the cost to produce the last unit of it the marginal utility is the happiness gained from buying the last unit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: economic theory uses marginalism to describe the diminishing returns from consumption the 10th candy bar doesn't taste as good as the first and so brings less marginal utility
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: marginal cost of production divides costs into fixed costs which must be paid regardless of how many of a commodity are produced and variable costs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the marginal cost is the variable cost of the last unit plus the percentage of fixed costs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: marginalism states that when the profit from the next unit will be zero that unit will not be produced
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: information theory has been applied to economics since the work of ronald coase in the 1930's
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however with herbert simon and john von neumann in the 1950's it gathered a more specific formalism as part of game theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this emphasises that the decision making process itself is costly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: marxist economics generally denies the trade off of time for money
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the marxist view concentrated control over the means of production is the basis for the allocation of resources among classes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: scarcity of any particular physical resource is subsidiary to the central question of power relationships embedded in the means of production
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the question of the environment is viewed in the traditional economic framework as being related to the externalization of costs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that is market economics assumes that a good which is underpriced is overconsumed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: externalization of cost in this view will be corrected by pricing the overconsumed resources which are being used for example the work of lester thurow and also see pigovian taxes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: not all economics study accepts this paradigm and instead there is a seven decade old tradition of viewing economic relationships as being based on the scarcity of energy rather than price as the central feature of economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it could be argued that beneath an economic theory is a theory of value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: value can be defined as the underlying activity which economics describes and measures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is what is really happening
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: adam smith defined labor as the underlying source of value and the labor theory of value underlies the work of karl marx david ricardo and many other classical economists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the labor theory of value argues that a good or service is worth the labor that it takes to produce and the abundance or scarcity of labor determines the price of a commodity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the labor theory of value and the closely related cost of production theory of value dominates the work of most classical economists but they are far from the only accepted basis for value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example neoclassical economists and austrian school economists prefer the marginal theory of value
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: market theory argues that there is no value separate from price that the market incorporates all available information into price and that so long as markets are open that price and value are one and the same
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this theory rests on the idea of the rational economic actor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this was orginally asserted by mill
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another set of theories rest on the idea that there is a basic external scarcity and that value represents the relationship to that basic scarcity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: theories based on economics being limited by energy or based on a gold standard are of this type
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: all of these value theories are used in current economic work
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: price is the measurable quantities involved in an exchange
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: price theory therefore charts the movement of measurable quantities over time and the relationship between price and other measurable variables
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in adam smith's wealth of nations this was the trade off between price and convenience
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a great deal of economic theory is based around prices and the theory of supply and demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: supply and demand assume that the factors affecting the agents who supply a particular commodity can be separated from those who wish to sell it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sellers have a quantity they would wish to sell at every given price and a price for any quantity they wish to sell buyers have a quantity they will demand at any given price and a price that they will pay to if they have to buy a particular quantity
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the market clears at the point where all the supply and demand at a given price balance
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that is the amount of a commodity available at a given price equals the amount that buyers are willing to purchase at that price
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is assumed that there is a process that will result in the market reaching this point but exactly what the process is in a real situation is an ongoing subject of research
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: markets which do not clear will react in some way either by a change in price or in the amount produced or in the amount demanded
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: graphically the situation can be represented by two curves one showing the price quantity combinations buyers will pay for or the demand curve one showing the combinations sellers will sell for or the supply curve
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the market clears where the two are in equilibrium that is where the curves intersect
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in a general equilibrium model all markets in all goods clear simultaneously and the price can be described entirely in terms of tradeoffs with other goods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for a century the say's law was believed in economic theory which said that markets as a whole would always clear
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in many practical economic models some form of price stickiness is incorporated to model the observed fact that in many markets prices do not move fluidly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: economic policy often revolves around arguments as to what is causing economic friction or price stickiness and which is therefore preventing the supply and demand from reaching equilibrium
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another area of economic controversy is on whether price measures value correctly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in mainstream market economics where there are significant scarcities not factored into price there is said to be an externalization of cost
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: market economics predicts that scarce goods which are underpriced are over consumed see social cost
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this leads into public goods theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is some degree of tension between economics and ethics another of the most basic social sciences which tends to avoid quantification and emphasize balances of rights
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern economics deals with this tension explicitly &ndash according to some thinkers a theory of economics is also or implies also a theory of moral reasoning
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one way economists deal with this is to qualify discussions of economic choice by noting that all else being equal referring to moral or social factors that are supposedly held equivalent for all choices that one might make
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for exploration of this issue see the moral purchasing article
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another premise is that economics fits within a finite ecosystem where there are at least some abundant resources &ndash for instance when fueling a fire one is usually concerned with finding the wood and not so much with finding the air to burn it with
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: economics explicitly does not deal with free abundant inputs &ndash one criticism is that it often conflicts with ecology's view of what affects what
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: human beings are according to ecologists merely one species participating in a vast energy system on this planet &ndash economy is a subset of ecology that deals with just one species habits and wants
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see nature's services for the economic view of ecology and green economics for the view wherein economics is a subset of ecology a third premise is that economics suggests market forms and other means of distribution of scarce goods that do not just affect desires and wants but also needs and habits
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: much of so called economic choice is involuntary certainly given the conditioning that people have to expect certain quality of life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this leads to one of the most hotly debated areas in economic policy namely the effect and efficacy of welfare policies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is viewed as a failure to respect economics reasoning by libertarians who argue that redistribution of wealth is morally and economically wrong
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: and viewed as a failure of economics to respect society by socialists who argue that disparities of wealth should not have been allowed in the first place
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this led to both 19th century labour economics and 20th century welfare economics before being subsumed into human development theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the debates above are all quite old
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term economics was coined in around 1870 and popularised by influential neoclassical economists such as alfred marshall
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: prior to this the subject had been known as political economy and referred to the economy of polities &ndash competing states
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the older term is still often used instead of economics especially by radical economists such as marxists who strongly question assumptions of mainstream technical and quantitative economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: use of this term often signals an a basic disagreement with the terminology or paradigm of market economics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: political economy explicitly brings political considerations into economic analysis and therefore tends to be more normative
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some mainstream universities such as the university of toronto and many in the united kingdom have a political economy department rather than an economics department
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nalika pitaieun didorong kana torowongan rektum mondokan sarta gelombang peristaltis ngadorong tai kaluar rektum
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sphincter luar jeung jero anus salajengna metot otot ngaluarkeun taina
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina matematika aljabar o atawa widang o x pikeun saset s hartina anggota subset s nu katutup ku set operasi operasi nu bisa diitung aljabar o utamana dipake pikeun nangtukeun ukuran s ieu konsep penting dina analisis matematika jeung teori probabilitas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sacara formal x kaasup aljabar o mun jeung ukur mun jika dan hanya jika if and only if miboga pasipatan di handap ieu an ordered pair s x where s is a set and x is a o-algebra over s is called a measurable space
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mun s mangrupa set naon bae then the family consisting only of the empty set and s is a o-algebra over s the so called trivial o-algebra
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another o-algebra over s is given by the full power set of s if {x a } is a family of o-algebras over s then the intersection of all x a is also a o-algebra over s if u is an arbitrary family of subsets of s then we can form a special o-algebra from u called the o-algebra generated by u we denote it by o(u and define it as follows
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: first note that there is a o-algebra over s that contains u namely the power set of s let φ be the family of all o-algebras over s that contain u that is a o-algebra x over s is in φ if and only if u is a subset of x then we define o(u to be the intersection of all o-algebras in φ
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: o(u is then the smallest o-algebra over s that contains u this leads to the most important example the borel algebra over any topological space is the o-algebra generated by the open sets or equivalently by the closed sets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: note that this o-algebra is not in general the whole power set
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for a non trivial example see the vitali set
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on the euclidean space r n another o-algebra is of importance that of all lebesgue measurable sets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this o-algebra contains more sets than the borel algebra on r n and is preferred in integration theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also measurable function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sistim internasional lambangna si sarua jeung tina asal hartina dina basa prancis systeme international d'unites nyaeta sistim unit nu pangumumna dipake
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: iwal di as jeung inggris sistim ieu dipake dina kahirupan sapopoe utamana dagang di sakuliah dunya oge dina widang ilmiah
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: si was selected as a specific subset of the existing metre kilogram second systems of units mks rather than the older centimetre gram second system of units cgs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various new units were added with the introduction of the si and at later times
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: si is sometimes referred to as the metric system especially in the united states which has not widely adopted it although it has been used more commonly in recent years and the uk where conversion is incomplete
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: metric system is a broader term which includes si however not all metric units of measurement are accepted as si units
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are seven base units and several derived units together with a set of prefixes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: non si units can be converted to si units or vice versa according to the conversion of units
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the units of the si are decided by a series of international conferences organised by the standards organization bureau international des poids et mesures international bureau of weights and measures
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the si was first given its name in 1960 and last added to in 1971
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the true origins of the si or metric system date back to approximately 1640
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it was invented by french scientists and was given a huge boost in popularity by the french revolution of 1789
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the metric system tried to choose units which were non arbitrary merging well with the revolution's official ideology of pure reason
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the layout of the metric system may have been based on the idealistic world view of ancient greeks who theorized that there were four basic elements earth water fire and air
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most important unit is that of length one metre was intended to be equal to 1/10000000thof the distance from the pole to the equator along the meridian through paris
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is approximately 10% longer than one yard
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later on a platinum rod with a rigid x shaped cross section was produced to serve as the easy-to-check standard for one metre's length
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however due to the difficulty of actually measuring the length of a meridian quadrant in the 18th century the first platinum prototype was short by 0.2 millimetres
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: then a multiple of a specific radiation wavelength was introduced to abstractly define the unchanged length of the metre unit and finally the metre was defined as the distance travelled by light in a vacuum in a specific period of time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the unit of mass is the kilogram which was defined by a cube filled with distilled pure water at its densest +4° celsius and having sides equal to 1/10th of a metre
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this volume contains one kilogram of water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one kilogram is about 2.2 pounds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this cubic space was also known as one litre since slightly revised so volumes of different liquids could be compared
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later on a platinum iridium metal cylinder was manufactured to serve as the one kilogram weight standard and remained so ever since
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the unit of temperature became the centigrade or inverted celsius grade which means the mercury scale is divided into 100 equal length parts between the water ice mixture and the boiling point of pure distilled water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: boiling water thus becomes one hundred degrees celsius and freezing is zero degrees celsius
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is the metric unit of temperature in everyday use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a hundred years later scientists discovered absolute zero
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this prompted the establishment of a new temperature scale called the absolute scale or kelvin scale which relocates the zero place but still uses 100 kelvins between the freezing point and boiling point of water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the metric unit of time remained the second
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: one definition of day is 86400 seconds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the formal definition of the second has been changed several times for enhanced scientific requirements astronomic observations tuning fork clock quartz clock and then caesium atomic clock but wristwatch users remain relatively unaffected
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the swift worldwide adoption of the metric system as a tool of economy and everday commerce was based mainly on the lack of customary systems in many countries to adequately describe some concepts or as a result of an attempt to standardize the many regional variations in the customary system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: international politics also factored into the choice as many countries made the industrial shift when britain still had empire status and had various feelings related to its position in the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: scientifically it provides ease when dealing with very large and small quantities because it lines up so well with our numeral system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: cultural differences can be represented in the local everyday uses of metric units
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example bread is sold in one half one or two kilogram sizes in many countries but you buy them by multiples of one hundred grams in the former ussr
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: non scientific people should not be put off by the fine tuning that has happened to the metric base units over the past two hundred years as experts regularly tried to refine the metric system to fit the best scientific researcher e.g mkg to cgs to si system changes or the invention of kelvin scale
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these changes seldom affect the everyday use of metric units
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the presence of these adjustments has been one reason advocates of the us customary units have used against metrication
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: si is built on seven si base units the kilogram metre second ampere kelvin mole and candela
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are used to define various si derived units
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: si also defines a number of si prefixes to be used with the units these combine with any unit name to give subdivisions and multiples
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example the prefix kilo denotes a multiple of a thousand so the kilometre is 1 000 metres the kilogram 1 000 grams and so on
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: note that a millionth of a kilogram is a milligram not a microkilogram
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: di handap ieu unit unit dasar ti mana nu sejen diturunkeun they are dimensionally independent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the definitions stated below are widely accepted
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following si units are derived from the base units and are dimensionless
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: base units can be put together to derive units of measurement for other quantities
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some have been given names
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following units are not si units but are accepted for use with the international system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following si prefixes can be used to prefix any of the above units to produce a multiple or submultiple of the original unit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following si prefixes are no longer in use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: several nations notably the united states typically use the spellings meter and liter instead of metre and litre
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is in keeping with standard american english spelling for example americans also use center rather than centre using the latter on mostly office buildings see also american and british english differences
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition the official us spelling for the si prefix deca is deka
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the us government has approved these spellings for official use but the bipm only recognizes the british english spellings as official names for the units
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in scientific contexts only the symbols are used since these are universally the same the differences do not arise in practice in scientific use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the unit gram is also sometimes spelled gramme in english speaking countries other than the united states though that is an older spelling and use is declining
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: official
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese
