lines.value: <!eukaryotes also spelled eucaryotes are organisms with complex cells in which the genetic material is organized into membrane bound nuclei
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they include the animals plants and fungi which are mostly multicellular as well as the kingdom of the protists many of which are unicellular
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in contrast other organisms such as bacteria lack nuclei and other complex cell structures and are called prokaryotes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eukaryotes are thought to share a common origin and are often treated formally as a superkingdom empire or domain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the name comes from the greek eus or true and karyon or nut referring to the nucleus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eukaryotic cells are generally much larger than prokaryotes typically a thousand times by volume
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: usually they have a variety of internal membranes and structures called organelles and a cytoskeleton composed of microtubules and microfilaments which plays an important role in defining the cell's organization
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however some eukaryotes e.g diplomonads microsporidia do not contain organelles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eukaryotic dna is divided into several bundles called chromosomes which are separated by a microtubular spindle during nuclear division
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in addition to asexual cell division most eukaryotes have some process of sexual reproduction via cell fusion which is not found among prokaryotes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eukaryotic cells include a variety of membrane bound structures collectively referred to as the endomembrane system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: simple compartments called vesicles or vacuoles can form by budding off other membranes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many cells ingest food and other materials through a process of endocytosis where the outer membrane invaginates and then pinches off to form a vesicle
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is probable that most other membrane bound organelles are ultimately derived from such vesicles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the nucleus is surrounded by a double membrane with pores that allow material to move in and out
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: various tube and sheet like extensions of the nuclear membrane form what is called the endoplasmic reticulum or er which is involved in protein transport
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it includes rough sections where ribosomes are attached and the proteins they synthesize enter the interior space or lumen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: subsequently they generally enter vesicles which bud off from the smooth section
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in most eukaryotes the proteins may be further modified in stacks of flattened vesicles called golgi bodies or dictyosomes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: vesicles may be specialized for various purposes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for instance lysosomes contain enzymes that break down the contents of food vacuoles and peroxisomes are used to break down peroxide which is toxic otherwise
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many protozoa have contractile vacuoles which collect and expel excess water and extrusomes which expel material used to deflect predators or capture prey
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in multicellular organisms hormones are often produced in vesicles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in higher plants most of a cell's volume is taken up by a central vacuole or tonoplast which maintains its osmotic pressure
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mitochondria are organelles found in nearly all eukaryotes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are surrounded by double membranes the inner of which is folded into invaginations called cristae where aerobic respiration takes place
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they contain their own dna and are only formed by the fission of other mitochondria
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are now generally held to have developed from endosymbiotic prokaryotes probably proteobacteria
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the few protozoa that lack mitochondria have been found to contain mitochondrion derived organelles such as hydrogenosomes and mitosomes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: plants and various groups of algae also have plastids
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: again these have their own dna and developed from endosymbiotes in this case cyanobacteria
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they usually take the form of chloroplasts which like cyanobacteria contain chlorophyll and produce energy through photosynthesis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: others are involved in storing food
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although plastids likely had a single origin not all plastid containing groups are closely related
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: instead some eukaryotes have obtained them from others through secondary endosymbiosis or ingestion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: endosymbiotic origins have also been proposed for the nucleus and eukaryotic flagella but this is not generally accepted both from a lack of cytological evidence and difficulty in reconciling this with cellular reproduction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: many eukaryotes have slender motile projections usually called flagella when long and cilia when short that are variously involved in movement feeding and sensation
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these are entirely distinct from prokaryotic flagella
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are supported by a bundle of microtubules arising from a basal body also called a kinetosome or centriole characteristically arranged as nine doublets surrounding two singlets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: flagella also may have hairs or mastigonemes scales connecting membranes and internal rods
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: their interior is continuous with the cell's cytoplasm
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: centrioles are often present even in cells and groups that do not have flagella
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they generally occur in groups of one or two called kinetids that give rise to various microtubular roots
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these form a primary component of the cytoskeletal structure and are often assembled over the course of several cell divisions with one flagellum retained from the parent and the other derived from it
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: centrioles may also be associated in the formation of a spindle during nuclear division
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some protists have various other microtubule supported organelles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these include the radiolaria and heliozoa which produce axopodia used in flotation or to capture prey and the haptophytes which have a peculiar flagellum like organelle called the haptonema
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nuclear division is often coordinated with cell division
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this generally takes place by mitosis a process which allows each daughter nucleus to receive one copy of each chromosome
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in most eukaryotes there is also a process of sexual reproduction typically involving an alternation between haploid generations where only one copy of each chromosome is present and diploid generations where two are present occurring through nuclear fusion syngamy and meiosis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there is considerable variation in this pattern however
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the origin of the eukaryotic cell was a milestone in the evolution of life
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: although eukaryotes use the same genetic code and metabolic processes as prokaryotes their higher level of organizational complexity has permitted the development of truly multicellular organisms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: without eukaryotes the world would lack mammals birds fish invertebrates mushrooms plants and complex single celled organisms
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: eukaryotes are generally held to have originated around 2 billion years ago but this has been disputed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: early fossils such as acritarchs are difficult to interpret
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: forms that can be related to modern groups start appearing around 800 million years ago and most fossil lines are known by the end of the cambrian around 500 million years ago
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: genetic studies during the 1980s and 1990s left most eukaryotes in an unresolved crown group usually divided by the form of the cristae in their mitochondria
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the few amitochondriate groups branched first and so were considered basal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however newer studies contradict this and a new picture has been slow to develop
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: most eukaryotes may be assigned to several supergroups however some protists are not closely related to any of these lines and the relationships between the different supergroups remain almost entirely uncertain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in particular there is dispute about where the root of the evolutionary tree belongs and as a result what the earliest eukaryotes were like
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: * s l baldauf 2003
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the deep roots of eukaryotes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!getih manusa digolongkeun kana sababaraha tipe dumasar antigen jeung antibodina the precise reason why people develop antibodies against an antigen they have never been exposed to is unknown
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is believed that some bacterial antigens are similar enough to the a and b glycoproteins and that antibodies created against the bacteria will react to abo incompatible blood cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: apart from red blood cells the abo antigen is also expressed on the glycoprotein von willebrand factor vwf which participates in hemostasis control of bleeding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in fact blood type o predisposes very slightly to bleeding as vwf is degraded more rapidly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: abo antigens are also present in many other tissues such as liver kidneys and lungs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the a & b antigens are derived from a common precursor known as the h antigen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the h antigen is a glycosphingolipid sphingolipid with carbohydrates bonded to the ceramide moiety which is modified to produce the a and b antigens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in type o blood it remains unchanged and consists of a chain of galactose n acetylglucsamine galactose frucose attached to the ceramide
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: since it lacks n acetylneuraminic acid sialic acid it is referred to as a globoside not a ganglioside
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: type a has an extra n acetyl galactosamine bonded to the galactose near the end while type b has a third galactose bonded to that near end galactose
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: blood groups are inherited from both parents
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the abo blood type is controlled by a single gene with three alleles i i a , and i b
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gene encodes a glycosyltransferase an enzyme that modifies the carbohydrate content of the red blood cell antigens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gene is located on the long arm of the ninth chromosome 9q34
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: i a allele gives type a i b gives type b and i gives type o i a and i b are dominant over i so ii people have type o i a i a or i a i have a i b i b or i b i have type b i a i b people have both phenotypes because a and b express a special dominance relationship codominance preceding means that type a and b parents can have ab child
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus it is usually impossible for a type ab parent to have a type o child it is not however direct proof of illegitimacy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: evolutionary biologists theorize that the i a allele evolved earliest followed by o by the deletion of a single nucleotide shifting the reading frame and then i b
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this chronology accounts for the percentage of people worldwide with each blood type
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is consistent with the accepted patterns of early population movements and varying prevalent blood types in different parts of the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for instance b is very common in populations of asian descent but rare in ones of european descent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--another characteristic of blood is rhesus factor or rh factor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is named after the rhesus monkey in which the factor was first identified by karl landsteiner and alexander s wiener
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: someone either has or does not have the rh factor on the surface of their red blood cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is indicated as + or , and the two groups are described as rh positive rh+ or rh negative rh- respectively
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is often combined with the abo type
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: type o+ blood is most common though in some areas type a prevails and there are other areas in which as many as 80 percent of the people are type b matching the rhesus factor is very important as mismatching an rh positive donor to an rh negative recipient may cause the production in the recipient of an antibody to the rh(d antigen which could lead to subsequent hemolysis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is of particular importance in females of or below childbearing age where any subsequent pregnancy may be affected by the antibody produced
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for one off transfusions particularly in older males the use of rh(d positive blood in an rh(d negative individual who has no atypical red cell antibodies may be indicated if it is necessary to conserve rh(d negative stocks for more appropriate use
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the converse is not true rh+ patients do not react to rh blood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rh disease occurs when an rh negative mother who has already had an rh positive child or an accidental rh+ blood transfusion carries another rh positive child
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the first pregnancy the mother develops igg antibodies against rh+ red blood cells which can cross the placenta and hemolyse the red cells of the second child
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this reaction doesn't always occur and is less likely to occur if the child carries either the a or b antigen and the mother does not
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the past rh incompatibility could result in stillbirth or death of the mother
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rh incompatibility was until recently the most common cause of long term disability in the united states
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at first this was treated by transfusing the blood of infants who survived
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: at present it can be treated with certain anti rh(+ antisera the most common of which is rhogam anti-d
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it can be anticipated by determining the blood type of every child of a rhd mother if it is rh+ the mother is treated with anti d to prevent development of antibodies against rh+ red blood cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: abo blood type incompatibilities between the mother and child do not cause a similar problem because antibodies to the abo blood groups are of the igm type which do not cross the placenta
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: predicted frequency of rh factor blood types in populations based on occurrence of genotype for rh people there is a risk associated with travel to parts of the world where supplies of rh blood are rare particularly east asia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: correspondingly blood services in these areas may look to encourage westerners to donate blood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rh or the d antigen is inherited on one locus on the short arm of the first chromosome 1p36.2-p34 with two alleles of which rh+ is dominant and rh recessive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the gene codes for a polypeptide on the red cell membrane
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: rh individuals dd genotype do not produce this antigen and may be sensitized to rh+ blood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: two very similar epitopes cc and ee appear to be closely related to rh.frequency of rh alleles by population
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--blood types are not evenly distributed throughout the human population
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: o+ is the most common ab is the rarest
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are also variations in blood type distribution within human subpopulations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the figures given here are for people of european descent
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <br clear="all">
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--the rare individuals with bombay phenotype hh do not express substance h on their red blood cells and therefore do not bind a or b antigens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: instead they produce antibodies to h substance which is present on all red cells except those of hh genotype as well as to both a and b antigens and are therefore compatible only with other hh donors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: individuals with bombay phenotype blood groups can only be transfused with blood from other bombay phenotype individuals
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: given that this condition is very rare to begin with any person with this blood group who needs an urgent blood transfusion may be simply out of luck as it would be quite unlikely that any blood bank would have any in stock
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: those anticipating the need for blood transfusion e.g in scheduled surgery may bank blood for their own use i.e an autologous blood donation but this option is not available in cases of accidental injury
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: patients who test as type o may have the bombay phenotype if they have inherited two recessive alleles of the h gene their blood group is o h and their genotype is hh and so do not produce the h carbohydrate that is the precursor to the a and b antigens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it then no longer matters whether the a or b enzymes are present or not as no a or b antigen can be produced since the precursor antigen is not present
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite the designation o o h negative is not a sub group of any other group not even o negative or o positive
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: when this blood group was first encountered it was found not to be of either group a or b and so was thought to be of group o but on further testing it did not match even for o negative or o positive because of the absence of antigen h
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the h antigen is a precursor to the a and b antigens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for instance the b allele must be present to produce the b enzyme that modifies the h antigen to become the b antigen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is the same for the a allele
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however if only recessive alleles for the h antigen are inherited hh as in the case above the h antigen will not be produced
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: subsequently the a and b antigens also will not be produced
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the result is an o phenotype by default since a lack of a and b antigens is the o type
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the blood phenotype was first discovered in bombay now known as mumbai in india
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: <!--in order to provide maximum benefit from each blood donation and to extend shelf life blood banks fractionate whole blood into several products that may have varying degrees of compatibility depending upon the recipient's blood type
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the most common of these products are packed red blood cells rbc's plasma platelets and fresh frozen plasma ffp which is quick frozen to retain labile clotting factors v and vii and usually administered to patients who have a potentially fatal clotting problem caused by a condition such as as advanced liver disease overdose of anticoagulant or disseminated intravascular coagulation dic
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see cryoprecipitate
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the united states human blood products are considered drugs
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are tightly regulated by the food and drug administration fda and their use must be ordered by a licensed physician or surgeon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ideally a patient should receive type specific blood products to minimize the chance of a transfusion reaction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if time allows the risk will further be reduced by crossmatching blood in addition to typing both recipient and donor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: crossmatching involves mixing a sample of the recipient's blood with the donor blood and checking to see if the mixture agglutinates or forms clumps
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: blood bank technicians usually check for agglutination with a microscope and if it occurs the donor blood that was checked cannot be transfused
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a blood transfusion is a risky medical procedure and typing and crossmatching is standard except in emergencies
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because cross matching takes about 45 minutes but blood typing takes only 3 minutes cross matching is sometimes omitted in emergency cases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: persons with blood type o negative are often called universal donors and those with type ab positive blood are called universal recipients but this is misleading and only true for transfusions of packed red cells
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with respect to transfusions of plasma this situation is reversed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: o negative plasma can only be given to o negative recipients while patients of all blood types can receive ab positive plasma because it contains no anti a anti b or anti d antigens
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: platelets have no blood type and are freely transfused
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are usually lumped together in ten packs which are plastic pouches containing the platelets removed by apheresis from ten pints of blood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are administered to patients who cannot clot due to thrombocytopenia low platelet count
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the terms universal donor and universal recipient aren't very useful because they only consider the reaction of the patient's antibodies to received blood and not the antibodies present in that blood
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus although a transfusion of o blood to an a or b typed person is unlikely to cause an immune reaction from the recipient's antibodies the transfused blood may itself contain antibodies to the patient's a and b antigens this can cause an adverse reaction although the risk is far less than that of an o person receiving types a or b for this reason an exact abo type match is preferable where circumstances allow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: additionally the other red blood cell surface antigens that belong to blood groups outside of the abo convention might cause an adverse reaction
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this is further complicated by the fact that an rh negative patient can theoretically receive rh positive blood once unless the patient is female and she has been pregnant with an rh positive fetus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a second exposure to rh positive blood in an rh negative patient in one lifetime is usually fatal because the patient's blood will have developed antibodies to the rh factor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: catatan perjalanan snouck itu dimuat dalam bki nomor 101 tahun 1942 halaman 311-324 dengan judul aantekeningen over islam en volklore in west en midden java snouck hurgronyr sebetulnya telah mengenal hhm semenjak masih bermukim di mekah dan konon pernah ditolong oleh hhm ketika snouck akan dibunuh oleh orang orang arab
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: semenjak itulah hhm menjadi sahabat karibnya bahkan ketika dia pulang ke negerinya mereka masih tetap berhubungan sampai hhm meninggal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: selama tujuh tahun hhm menjadi pembantu snouck hurgronye dan pada tahun 1893 atas usul snouck pemerintah belanda mengangkat dia menjadi hoofd penghulu di aceh
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: menurut penuturan awak awak galih pakuan pada waktu itu setiap penghulu yang bertugas di aceh sering dibunuh orang karena dianggap tidak dapat berlaku adil di dalam menyelesaikan sesuatu masalah atau persengketaan diantara mereka
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pada masa itu seorang hoofd penghulu disamping menjadi seorang pemuka agama juga turut memberikan keputusan di dalam masalah hukum dan mereka biasa disebut kadi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: di aceh pada waktu itu bila seseorang dikalahkan dalam sesuatu perkara maka orang yang kalah akan bertanya berdasarkan hukum apa ayat berapa maka ia dianggap bersalah
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bila kadi tersebut tidak dapat memberikan jawaban yang memuaskan hatinya maka kadi itu dianggap berat sebelah tidak adil sehingga ada kalanya kadi itu dibunuh
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: menurut penilaian pemerintah belanda maka orang yang menjadi hoofd penghulu aceh haruslah orang yang cerdas pandai dalam ilmu hukum di samping menguasai ilmu agama secara menbdalam
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: berdasarkan pendapat snouck hurgronye maka orang yang tepat untuk jabatan tersebut adalah hajia hasan mustapa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hhm bersedia memikul tugas tersebut dengan mengajukan dua syarat a ia harus dipercayai sepenuhnya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: segala perkataan perbuatan dan tulisan tulisannya jangan diganggu
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: kesanggupan pemerintahan belanda memenuhi persyaratan pertama ini harus dinyatakan secara tertulis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: b bila ia telah berhasil dengan tugasnya di aceh dan bila nanti ada lowongan jabatan hoofd penghulu bandung dia minta agar ditempatkan di bandung
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: syarat pertama segera dikabulkan dengan keluarnya surat kepercayaan dari ratu wihelmina
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tahun 1893 hhm secara resmi diangkat menjadi hoofd penghulu di aceh paha tahun itu pula tepatnya tanggal 25 agustus 1893 teuku umar salah seorang pemimpin kaum hulubalng di dalam perang aceh menghadap gubernur deykerhof di kutaraja
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sebagai hoofd penghulu di aceh hhm telah menjalankan tugasnya dengan baik
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: masyarakat aceh pun merasa puas atas keputusan keputusan yang dia berikan dalam persengketaan persenketaan yang tombul
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hal ini disebabkan dia menguasai dan hapal betul akan hukum hukum islam yang menjadi dasar keputusan semua perkara
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dan sebagai tanda terima kasih rakyat aceh telah memberikan sebidang tanah kepada dia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: di atas tanah itu didirikanlah sebuah masjid olehnya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: jabatan hoofd penghulu aceh dipegang dalam waktu yang singkat yaitu dua tahun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pada tahun 1895 dia kembali ke tanah priangan untuk memangku jabatan hoofd penghulu bandung
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: jabatan hoofd penghulu bandung dilaluinya dalam waktu dua puluh tiga tahun dan pada tahun 1918 atas permintaan sendiri dia diberhentikan dengan hormat dan memperoleh hak pensiun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: pada waktu itu usianya kurang lebih 66 tahun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: menurut kern 1946 vi sebetulnya ketika masih bermukim di mekah dia telah mengajar ulama ulama yang berdatangan dari seluruh jawa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ia mengajar bahasa arab dan soal soal keagamaan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: oleh karena itu ia dikenal dan dihormati oleh ulama ulama diseluruh jawa dan menjadi tempat bertanya serta tempat meminta nasihat bagi penghulu penghulu priangan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sehubungan dengan jabatan kepenghuluannya sebuah pertanyaan timbul megapa hhm minta berhenti sebelum masa baktinya selesai
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: kern 1946 viii ix menyebutkan bahwa ketika dia menjabat hoofd penghulu bandung kerja sama dia dengan golongan kabupaten maupun dengan golongan kaum tidaklah begitu akrab
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: begitu juga ketika sebuah panitia yang bernama comite mendak hadji hasan moestapa panitia peringatan wafatnya haji hasan mustapa didirikan di bandung tak seorang pun dari golongan kaum yang menjadi anggotanya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: walaupun hhm disegani dan dikagumi keahliannya baik dalam bidang agama maupun dalam bidang bahasa dan adat istiadat sunda namun kelihatannya mereka mengambil jarak dan tidak terlau dekat dengannya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: diduga penyebabnya adalah karena sikap dan paham agama mereka
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: sebagai hoofd penghulu adalah pegawai pemerintah
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: walaupun demikian hhm bukanlah pegawai yang mau mentaati segala perintah dan kemauan atasannya begitu saja tanpa memperhitungkan pendapat dan kepribadiannya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hal ini dapat kita lihat antara lain dari pernyataan pernyataan yang diajukannya ketika ia akan diangkat menjadi hoofd penghulu di aceh dan dari penolakannya yang tegas terhadap ajakan pemerintah belanda yang menginginkan agar penganut agama islam diperkenankan pula mempelajari agama kristen lihat aji wiwitan istilah buku jilid ka 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: wangsaatmadja dalam bukunya yang berjudul singa bandung 1930:31 secara teperinci telah menguraikan sifat dan sikap hidup dia
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: antara lain disebutkannya bahwa dia adalah seorang yang memiliki sifat luar biasa
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: ketabahan dan kesabarannya dikagumi oleh semua yang mengenalnya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: selain itu ia memiliki firasat dan intuisi yang tajam hingga tidak jarang ia mengetahui apa yang diinginkan atau yang menjadi pikiran orang lain tanpa diutarakan dahulu kepadanya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dia pun dikenal sebagai orang yang teguh pada pendiriannya serta berani mengemukakan pendapat dan pendiriannya itu kepada siapa pun
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: bahkan berani pula ia menentang pendirian dan kehendak atasannya bila menurut pendapatnya tindakan atasannya itu tidak sesuai dengan hati nuraninya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hal ini dapat dilihat dari penolakannya yang tegas terhadap ajakan pemerintah belanda ketika itu yang menginginkan agar penganut agama islam di ijinkan pula untuk mempelajari agama kristen dan usahanya yang berhasil dalam mengusir rumah makan cina dari sekeliling masjid agung bandung karena menurut pendapatnya tidak pantas tempat orang islam bersembahyang dikeliling bau masakan babi
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tidak jarang pula buah fikiran dan perkataannya mengejutkan bupati beserta bawahannya sebab perkataannya itu merupakan sindiran halus yang bermakna dalam
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dia pun dikenal sebagai seorang putera yang sangat hormat dan berbakti kepada orang tuanya
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: disamping itu ia adalah orang yang sangat pemurah dan pengasih baik kepada sanak keluarganya sendiri maupun kepada orang lain bahkan kepada pembantu rumah tangganya

lines.value: sebagai ulama yang luas dan dalam ilmunya dengan tangan terbuka dan hati yang bersih dia selalu menerima semua orang yang bersungguh sungguh ingin belajar kepadanya

lines.value: namun demikian ia tidak pernah mau dianggap dan disebut guru oleh semua yang datang belajar kepadanya

lines.value: menurut pendapatnya agar mereka bertanggung jawab pada dirinya masing masing dan supaya bisa mengembangkan dirinya sendiri
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dari karya karyanya dapatlah dilihat bahwa dia adalah seorang pribadi yang amat tanggap perenung yang mendalam dan seorang yang berani mengemukakan pendapatnya sendiri

lines.value: hal ini dapat dilihat dari catatan catatan peristiwa yang sering dicantumkan dalam karya karyanya misalnya berlangsung kongres sarikat islam di bandung pada tahun 1916 meninggalnya seorang mufti besar yang berasal dari mesir dalam kerusuhan di luar kota mekah pada tahun 1924 sebab sebab berjangkitnya penyakit kuris yang sering melanda para jemaah haji dari indonesia dan banyak lagi

lines.value: sedangkan renuganrenungannya dapat di baca dalam dangding dangdingnya dan dalam syeh nur jaman dari anekdot anekdotnya yang telah dihimpun oleh wangsaatmadja dalam sira bandung 1930:47-73 dan dari kalimat kalimat yang sering diselipkan dalam bahasa bahasanya dia memiliki rasa humor yang halus cerdas dan tajam otaknya

lines.value: oleh karena itu dia dikagumi dan disegani baik oleh lawan apa lagi pengagumnya

lines.value: in the western world use of improved genetics better management of soil nutrients and improved weed control have greatly increased yields per unit area

lines.value: at the same time use of mechanization has decreased labor requirements releasing most of the populace from intense agricultural labor
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the developing world is behind by western measures of productivity because of unavailability of the education capital and technology base needed to sustain these advances and usually ecoregion with less optimal climates and soils
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: modern agriculture depends heavily on engineering and technology and on the biological and physical sciences
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: irrigation drainage conservation and sanitary engineering-each of which is important in successful farming are some of the fields requiring the specialized knowledge of agricultural engineers

lines.value: agricultural chemistry deals with other vital farming concerns such as the application of fertilizer insecticides see pest control and fungicides soil makeup analysis of agricultural products and nutritional needs of farm animals

lines.value: plant breeding and genetics contribute immeasurably to farm productivity

lines.value: genetics has also made a science of livestock breeding
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hydroponics a method of soilless gardening in which plants are grown in chemical nutrient solutions may help meet the need for greater food production as the world's population increases
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the packing processing and marketing of agricultural products are closely related activities also influenced by science
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: methods of quick freezing and dehydration have increased the markets for farm products see food processing and preservation meat packing industry
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mechanization the outstanding characteristic of late 19th and 20th-century agriculture has eased much of the backbreaking toil of the farmer
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: more significantly mechanization has enormously increased farm efficiency and productivity see agricultural machinery
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: animals including horses oxen llamas alpacas and dogs however are still used to cultivate fields harvest crops and transport farm products to markets in many parts of the world
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: airplanes and helicopters are used in agriculture for seeding spraying operations for insect and disease control transporting perishable products and fighting forest fires

lines.value: radio and television disseminate vital weather reports and other information such as market reports that concern farmers
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: computers have become an essential tool for farm management
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: animal husbandry means breeding and raising animals for meat or to harvest animal products like milk eggs or wool on a continual basis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in recent years some aspects of industrial intensive agriculture have been the subject of increasing discussion
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the widening sphere of influence held by large seed and chemical companies and meat packers has been a source of concern both within the farming community and for the general public
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the patent protection given to companies that develop new types of seed using genetic engineering has allowed seed to be licensed to farmers in much the same way that computer software is licensed to users

lines.value: this has changed the balance of power in favor of the seed companies allowing them to dictate terms and conditions previously unheard of

lines.value: some argue these companies are guilty of biopiracy

lines.value: soil conservation and nutrient management have been important concerns since the 1950s with the best farmers taking a stewardship role with the land they operate

lines.value: for example average yields of corn maize in the usa have increased from around 2.5 tons per hectare 40 bushels per acre in 1900 to about 9.4 t ha 150 bushels per acre in 2001 primarily due to improvements in genetics

lines.value: similarly worldwide average wheat yields have increased from less than 1 t ha in 1900 to more than 2.5 t ha in 1990

lines.value: german used to be the language of commerce and government in the habsburg empire which encompassed a large area of central and eastern europe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: until the mid nineteenth century it was essentially the language of townspeople throughout most of the empire
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it indicated that the speaker was a merchant an urbanite not their nationality
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some towns such as prague and budapest were gradually germanized in the years after their incorporation into the habsburg domain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: others such as bratislava pressburg were originally settled during the habsburg period and were primarily german at that time
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a few towns such as milano remained primarily non german
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however most towns such as prague budapest bratislava zagreb and ljubljana which later became national capitals were for the time primarily german although they were surrounded by country that spoke other languages
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: until about 1800 standard german was almost only a written language
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in this time people in urban northern germany who spoke dialects very different from standard german learnt it almost like a foreign language and tried to pronounce it as close to the spelling as possible
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later this spoken form spread southward

lines.value: demografi nyaeta elmu ngeunaan dinamika populasi manusa nu ngawengku panalungtikan ukuran struktur jeung sebaran populasi sarta kumaha parobahan populasi sajalan jeung nyerelekna waktu ku ayana nu babar maot migrasi jeung nambahna umur

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the earliest modern census was carried out in britain in 1801
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: see also demographic statistics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in many countries particularly in the third world reliable demographic data are still difficult to obtain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for example during the 1980s the population of nigeria was widely estimated to be around 110 million before it was established to be as little as 89 million without adjustment for undercounting in a census carried out in 1991
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: konsep-konsep nu penting dina demografi di antarana
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: among the earliest contributions to demography were the works of thomas malthus
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: malthus concluded that if unchecked populations would be subject to exponential growth
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: he feared that population growth would tend to outstrip growth in food production leading to ever increasing famine and poverty see malthusian catastrophe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: later more sophisticated and realistic models were presented by e.g gompertz and verhulst
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: contrary to malthus predictions natural population growth in most developed countries has diminished to close to zero without being held in check by famine or lack of resources as people in developed nations have shown a tendency to have fewer children
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the fall in population growth has occurred despite large rises in life expectancy in these countries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: similar trends are now becoming visible in ever more developing countries so that far from spiralling out of control world population growth is expected to slow markedly in the next century coming to an eventual standstill
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the change is likely to be accompanied by major shifts in the proportion of world population in particular regions
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this pattern of population growth with slow growth in preindustrial societies followed by fast growth as the society develops and industrialises followed by slow growth again as it becomes more affluent is known as the demographic transition
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the term demographics is often used erroneously for demography but refers rather to selected population characteristics as used in marketing or opinion research
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina analisis numeris quadrature rule mangrupa salah sahiji pendekatan definite integral tina function biasana dinyatakan salaku jumlah beurat tina nilai fungsi dina titik husus dijero domain integration
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: tempo numerical integration keur quadrature rules lianna dina n titikgaussian quadrature rule dingaranan ieu sanggeus carl friedrich gauss mangrupa quadrature rule constructed to yield an exact result for polynomials of degree 2n &minus 1 by a suitable choice of the n points x i and n weights w i
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the domain of integration for such a rule is conventionally taken as [-1 1] so the rule is stated as it can be shown see press et al or stoer and bulirsch that the evaluation points are just the roots of a polynomial belong to a class of orthogonal polynomials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for the integration problem stated above the associated polynomials are legendre polynomials
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some low order rules for solving the integration problem are listed below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an integral over [a b] must be changed into an integral over [-1 1] before applying the gaussian quadrature rule
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this change of interval can be done in the following way for some choices of a b and &omega
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for a = -1 b = 1 and ω(x = 1 the problem is the same as that considered above
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: other choices lead to other integration rules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some of these are tabulated below
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: equation numbers are given for abramowitz and stegun a&s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: hermite polynomials eq
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the error of a gaussian quadrature rule can be stated as follows theorem 3.6.24 in stoer and bulirsch
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for an integrand which has 2n continuous derivatives : th derivative and furthermore the actual error may be much less than a bound established by the derivative
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: another approach is to use two gaussian quadrature rules of different orders and to estimate the error as the difference between the two results
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for this purpose gauss kronrod rules can be useful
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the interval [a b] is subdivided the evaluation points of the new subintervals generally do not coincide with the previous evaluation points and thus the integrand must be evaluated at every point
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: gauss kronrod rules are gaussian quadrature rules that are modified to make some of the evaluation points coincide after subdivision
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the difference between the results before and after subdivision can be taken as an estimate of the error of approximation so such an approach can increase the accuracy achieved for a given number of function evaluations
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the algorithms in quadpack see below are based on gauss kronrod rules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: * quadpack part of slatec description source code
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: quadpack is a collection of algorithms in fortran for numerical integration based on gauss kronrod rules
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: slatec at netlib is a large public domain library for numerical computing

lines.value: kecap kernel mibanda sababaraha harti dina matematik kadang pakait jeung hal sejen kadangkala heunteu
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: di handap ieu sababaraha artikel ngeunaan kernel leuwih jentre dina : kernel algebra kernel of a function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: dina analisa tempo hiji operator integral t nu mindahkeun fungsi f kana fungsi tf dina rumus integral the function k that appears in this formula is the kernel of the operator t this usage applies also to convolution operators such as the dirichlet kernel
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this type of kernel is used in the kernel trick which has applications in several fields of applied mathematics
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: unrelated to this if f is any function in any context then the kernel of f is a certain equivalence relation on the domain of f which is defined in terms of f for more on this in general see kernel of a function
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this notion is used heavily in abstract algebra
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: but in the case of mal'cev algebras it can be replaced by a simpler definition the kernel of a homomorphism f is the preimage under f of the zero element of the codomain
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for more on this see kernel algebra
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: finally for this last notion of kernel is generalised in a certain sense in category theory the kernel of a morphism f is the difference kernel of f and the corresponding zero morphism if this exists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for more on this see kernel category theory
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: perhaps the best known case of the concept of kernel in algebra is that of the kernel of a linear map
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the kernel of a linear map is the same thing as its null space
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the yen was introduced by the meiji government in 1870 as a system resembling those in europe
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the yen replaced the complex monetary system of the edo period based on the mon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the new currency act of 1871 stipulated the adoption of the decimal accounting system of yen 1 圓 sen (, 錢 and rin (, 厘 with the coins being round and cast as in the west
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the sen and the rin were eventually taken out of circulation in 1954 while not a usage specific to currency large quantities of yen are often counted in multiples of 10000 man 万 in the same way as values in the united states are often quoted or rounded off to hundreds or thousands
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the yen was legally defined as 0.8667 troy ounces 26.956 g of silver which is about us$6.50 in today's money
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the act also moved japan onto the gold standard
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the yen lost most of its value during and after world war ii after a period of instability the yen was pegged at 1 us dollar = ¥360 from april 25 1949 to until 1971 when the bretton woods system collapsed and the value of the yen began to float
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as of december 2005 there are about ¥115 to the us dollar about ¥139 to the euro and about ¥205 to the pound sterling
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the plaza accord of 1985 the yen appreciated against the dollar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 5-yen and 50-yen coins are holed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the date is on the reverse of all coins and in most cases the name 日本国 nihonkoku japan and the value in kanji is on the obverse except for the 5-yen where nihonkoku is on the reverse
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first 1-yen coin excluding early silver coins was a brass coin introduced in 1948 and discontinued in 1950 the first 5-yen coin excluding early gold coins in 1948 and originally had no hole
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first 10-yen was introduced in 1951 the first 50-yen in 1955 with no hole the first 100-yen in 1957 originally made out of silver
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 500-yen coin was introduced in 1982
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: 500 yen coins are probably the highest valued coins to be used regularly in the world with rates in the neighborhood of us$4.77 €3.59 and £2.49
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the united states largest valued commonly used coin 25c is worth around 26 yen the eurozone's largest €2 is worth ¥279 and the united kingdom's largest £2 is worth ¥402 as of march 2005
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the swiss 5-franc coin is currently as of may 2006 worth about ¥457
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the highest valued bill the 10000 yen bill is worth just a little bit less than the us $100 bill the highest denomination of currently circulating us currency
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: on various occasions commemorative coins are minted using gold and silver with various face values up to 100000 yen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: even though they can be used they are treated as collectibles
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: names are written in the order of family name given name as part of )
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: because a law of the abolition of currencies in a small denomination is enforced in 1953 banknotes and coins whose denominations are less than ¥1 are expired on 31 desember 1953
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the series b introduced a new high value banknote ¥1000
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the series c introduced two new high value banknotes ¥5000 and ¥10000
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: due to the discovery of a large number of counterfeit series d banknotes at the end of 2004 all series d banknotes except ¥2000 were virtually suspended on january 17 2005
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however a cabinet ordinance of this suspension has not yet been declared
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: according to a news release from the national police agency they seized 11717 counterfeit series d banknotes excluding the ¥2000 denomination in 2005
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however they seized only 486 counterfeit current issue banknotes namely series e ¥1000 ¥5000 ¥10000 and series d ¥2000
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the 2000 yen note was first issued on july 19 2000 to commemorate the g8 economic summit in okinawa and the millennium year as well
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: shurei mon pictured on the front of the note is a famous gate in naha okinawa near the site of the summit
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these notes are hard to find and many japanese consider it a novelty as it is the only denomination in the factor of 2 from 1 and 5
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some say it was a way to stimulate the economy from building new vending machines to be able to process the note to creating wider cash registers to handle the bill
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this hasn't really materialised
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: some businesses will refuse this note
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to increase the circulation of the notes some companies started paying wages in these notes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the relative value of the yen is determined in foreign exchange markets by the forces of supply and demand
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the supply of the yen in the market is governed by the desire of yen holders to exchange their yen for other currencies to purchase goods services or assets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the demand for the yen is governed by the desire of foreigners to buy goods and services in japan and by their interest in investing in japan buying yen denominated real and financial assets
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1949 the value of the yen was set at ¥360 per us$1 through a united states plan which was part of the bretton woods system to stabilize prices in the japanese economy
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: that exchange rate was maintained until 1971 when the united states abandoned the convertibility of the dollar to gold which had been a key element of the bretton woods system and imposed a 10 percent surcharge on imports setting in motion changes that eventually led to floating exchange rates in 1973
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: by 1971 the yen had become undervalued
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: japanese exports were costing too little in international markets and imports from abroad were costing the japanese too much
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this undervaluation was reflected in the current account balance which had risen from the deficits of the early 1960s to a then large surplus of us$5.8 billion in 1971
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the belief that the yen and several other major currencies were undervalued motivated the united states actions in 1971
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: following the united states measures to devalue the dollar in the summer of 1971 the japanese government agreed to a new fixed exchange rate as part of the smithsonian agreement signed at the end of the year
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this agreement set the exchange rate at ¥308 per us$1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however the new fixed rates of the smithsonian agreement were difficult to maintain in the face of supply and demand pressures in the foreign exchange market
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in early 1973 the rates were abandoned and the major nations of the world allowed their currencies to float
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in the 1970s japanese government and business people were very concerned that a rise in the value of the yen would hurt export growth by making japanese products less competitive and would damage the industrial base
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the government therefore continued to intervene heavily in foreign exchange marketing buying or selling dollars even after the 1973 decision to allow the yen to float
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: despite intervention market pressures caused the yen to continue climbing in value peaking temporarily at an average of ¥271 per us$1 in 1973 before the impact of the oil crisis was felt
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the increased costs of imported oil caused the yen to depreciate to a range of ¥290 to ¥300 between 1974 and 1976
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the reemergence of trade surpluses drove the yen back up to ¥211 in 1978
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this currency strengthening was again reversed by the second oil shock with the yen dropping to ¥227 by 1980
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: during the first half of the 1980s the yen failed to rise in value even though current account surpluses returned and grew quickly
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from ¥221 in 1981 the average value of the yen actually dropped to ¥239 in 1985
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the rise in the current account surplus generated stronger demand for yen in foreign exchange markets but this trade related demand for yen was offset by other factors
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: a wide differential in interest rates with united states interest rates much higher than those in japan and the continuing moves to deregulate the international flow of capital led to a large net outflow of capital from japan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this capital flow increased the supply of yen in foreign exchange markets as japanese investors changed their yen for other currencies mainly dollars to invest overseas
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this kept the yen weak relative to the dollar and fostered the rapid rise in the japanese trade surplus that took place in the 1980s
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1985 a dramatic change began
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: finance officials from major nations signed an agreement the plaza accord affirming that the dollar was overvalued and therefore the yen undervalued
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this agreement and shifting supply and demand pressures in the markets led to a rapid rise in the value of the yen
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: from its average of ¥239 per us$1 in 1985 the yen rose to a peak of ¥128 in 1988 virtually doubling its value relative to the dollar
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after declining somewhat in 1989 and 1990 it reached a new high of ¥123 to us$1 in december 1992
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the yen's increased value made japanese exports less price competitive and imports more price competitive which should have brought down the value of trade and current account surpluses
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the current account figures discussed earlier however indicated that such a response was slow
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the strong appreciation of the yen began in 1985 but the current account continued to rise until 1987
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its decline in 1988 was rather small although it experienced a more substantial decline in 1989
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: nyaeta kamus basa jepang make karakter cina karya morohashi tetsuji terbitan taishukan
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: mangrupa kamus nu lengkep aya leuwih ti 50000 karakter jeung 530000 kecap dina 13 volume bukuna kaasup indeksna
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the dai kan wa jiten was first published in april 1955
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: its compilation and production began in 1925 when the chief of taishukan ippei suzuki requested morohashi to edit a new kanji dictionary of a much larger scale than existing ones
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in order to print the dictionary type for most of the 50000 characters had to be created since none existed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the first volume was produced in 1943 but the printing plates were lost when taishukan's main offices were destroyed by bombing during the pacific war
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: after the war due to a shortage of skilled craftsmen suzuki persuaded mokichi ishii to make the necessary fonts
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1957 morohashi was awarded the chrysanthemum prize
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the final volume of the first edition the index was published in 1960
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 1967 morohashi received the culture prize
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: an index of the vocabulary that appears under the main entries in the original dictionary was published in 1990
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in 2000 a supplemental volume was published
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the dai kan wa jiten contains the compound words in the dai kan wa jiten are intended for reading chinese thus it does not represent modern japanese words created since the meiji era
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: due to the huge scale of the project and that many of the 50000 characters do not have any computer representation the dictionaries have still not been computerized and no cd rom form exists
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: volume 1
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: volume 13 is the dictionary's index
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: first published in 1960 several years after the main volumes this is the most useful tool of the dictionary and provides the best starting point when in search of a chinese character
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: *the index volume is divided into four main indexes total stroke count index sino japanese reading index japanese reading index and the four corner numerical system index
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: below each character in these indexes the dictionary volume number and page number are given where it can be found
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this index volume also includes an appendix
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: total stroke count index 総画索引 sokaku sakuin *this index arranges characters in order of total stroke order
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: further arrangement is by the signifier of the character or what is generally known as the radical this is the only character look up system that involves radicals sino japanese reading index 字音索引 jion sakuin *characters are arranged in this index by their sino japanese readings on'yomi and then by their total stroke count
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: japanese reading index 字訓索引 jikun sakuin *this index arranges characters by their japanese readings kun'yomi and further by their total stroke count
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the four corner numerical system [index] 四角號碼 shikaku goma *this indexing system arranges the characters using four digit numbers between 0000 and 9999 a number that is applied to the character based on the functions of the indexing system
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the characters are further classified by an extra number but only when there are multiple characters with the same four digit number
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: they are then further organized by number of strokes
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: appendix 補遺 hoi *this appendix is a collection of chinese characters that are used in definitions for reference or otherwise throughout the twelve volumes of the dictionary but which are not included as main entries
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are 1062 characters included in this appendix and for convenience only one reading of the character is given
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the volume number and page number where the character has been used in the dictionary are also given
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: volume 14 of the dai kan wa jiten is a supplemental volume published in 1990
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is the vocabulary index 語彙索引 goi sakuin which constitutes a comprehensive collection of every sub entry appearing in the twelve volumes of the main dictionary including every multi character combination general vocabulary person names place names and document text names this vocabulary index's entries are arranged in order of the fifty phonetic sounds of japanese and the volume number and page number where the entry appears in the main dictionary are given
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: *a major difference in this supplemental volume from the previous thirteen volumes is that it uses modern japanese kana not historical
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this supplemental volume 補巻 hokan published in 2000 includes approximately 800 main character entries and an estimated 33000 new vocabulary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the purpose of the supplemental volume is to supply new readings of characters variant characters etc there are four types of indexes in this volume for easy look up of characters
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: like the vocabulary index volume 14 this supplemental volume uses modern kana and is arranged according to the fifty phonetic japanese sounds
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the rekishiteki kanazukai equivalents are also provided
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this condition can be a symptom disease allergy food intolerance foodborne illness or extreme excesses of vitamin c or magnesium and may be accompanied by abdominal pain nausea and vomiting
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: there are other conditions which involve some but not all of the symptoms of diarrhea and so the formal medical definition of diarrhea involves defecation of more than 200 grams per day though formal weighing of stools to determine a diagnosis is never actually carried out
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it occurs when insufficient fluid is absorbed by the colon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: as part of the digestion process or due to fluid intake food is mixed with large amounts of water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: thus digested food is essentially liquid prior to reaching the colon
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the colon absorbs water leaving the remaining material as a semisolid stool
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: if the colon is damaged or inflamed however absorption is inhibited and watery stools result
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: diarrhea is most commonly caused by viral infections or bacterial toxins
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in sanitary living conditions and with ample food and water available an otherwise healthy patient typically recovers from the common viral infections in a few days and at most a week
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: however for ill or malnourished individuals diarrhea can lead to severe dehydration and can become life threatening without treatment
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it can also be a symptom of more serious diseases such as dysentery cholera or botulism and can also be indicative of a chronic syndrome such as crohn's disease
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: though appendicitis patients don't generally have diarrhea it is a common symptom of a ruptured appendix
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: it is also an effect of severe radiation sickness
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: symptomatic treatment for diarrhea involves the patient consuming adequate amounts of water to replace that loss preferably mixed with electrolytes to provide essential salts and some amount of nutrients
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: for many people further treatment is unnecessary
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: the following types of diarrhea generally indicate medical supervision is desirable
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: to expell the contents of the lower digestive tract the fluidity of the contents of the small and large intestines is increased
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: active transport of na + back into the gut initiates a reverse sodium transport
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this causes both cl and hco 3 to follow passively as well as water
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: now in the intestines the water dilutes toxins as well as triggers contractions of the intestine due to increase in intestinal distension
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: these contractions push the contents of the lower gi tract towards and out of the anal canal
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: medications such as loperamide are designed to prevent such contractions in response to the distension and should not be used to prevent diarrhea
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: such inhibition actually prolongs the infection or irritation and can cause a worsening over time because the evacuation of the bowel contents has been delayed
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this may be defined as diarrhea that lasts less than 4 weeks and is also called enteritis
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: this can nearly always be presumed to be infective although only in a minority of cases is this formally proven
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: with cases of acute diarrhea it is often reasonable to reassure a patient ensure adequate fluid intake and wait and see
lines.name: Sundanese

lines.value: in more severe cases or where it is important to find the cause of the illness stool cultures are instituted
lines.name: Sundanese
